PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and The Honourable Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:

``We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Australian War Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a Memorial to the dead and that the material on display is as much of a memorial nature as the building itself''.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hostilities in the Gulf
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned petitioners are appalled at the use of violence in an attempt to resolve international problems. Our concern is heightened when a peaceful resolution of the crisis in the Gulf was possible. Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a) immediately withdraw from hostilities in the Gulf.
(b) bring our naval force home from the Gulf.
(c) initiate a peace process similar to that we have negotiated in the Cambodian conflict.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYMENT) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendment made by the Senate to this Bill.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill will amend the Wool Marketing Act 1987 to suspend the operation of the Wool Reserve Price Scheme. Suspension of the Scheme will take effect as from the resumption of wool auction sales, expected to be 25 February. The suspension of the Scheme will apply for at least the remainder of the 1990-91 wool selling season.

The Bill will provide for the Australian Wool Corporation to repay borrowed funds under a debt reduction program and dispose of its wool stocks in an orderly manner in accordance with guidelines issued by the Minister. It will also make provision for the Corporation to make supplementary payments to wool growers in respect of wool sold before the end of 1990-91 wool selling season, in accordance with guidelines issued by the Minister.
The Bill will further provide for Ministerial power to appoint an administrator or interim Board for the Wool Corporation, should this be required.
This legislation is necessary to give effect to the Government's decisions last week on the future of wool marketing arrangements in Australia.

Those decisions were very difficult, and were taken only after very lengthy consultations by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy over a period of months with industry leaders, the Board of the Wool Corporation, and other members of the Government.

The decision to suspend the operation of the Reserve Price Scheme was, however, in the end, inevitable. It was no longer possible to permit the Australian Wool Corporation, on behalf of Australian wool growers, to go on purchasing greater and greater quantities of wool, levying higher and higher taxes, and incurring more and more debt to do so. The hope that consumer demand would recover and that the Corporation's stockpile and debt would be stabilised has not been realised.

At a fixed Minimum Reserve Price of 700c/kg, buyers of Australian wool have stayed out of the market. Against that, the efforts of both the Wool Corporation and the Government to maintain the Minimum Reserve Price at 700c were simply not enough.
The Historical Background

The situation in which the Australian wool industry now finds itself has been brought about by an unprecedented combination of factors. While some of these factors have been at work over a number of years, some of the most significant have had an impact only during the last year or so-and, as it turned out, were very difficult to predict.

The Reserve Price Scheme appeared to work well for a long period. Even so, it is possible, in retrospect, to see the genesis of present difficulties in events which occurred as long ago as the mid-1980's.

The introduction of floating exchange rates after 1983 put the Reserve Price Scheme under pressure. It was no longer possible to provide price stability simultaneously to both growers and buyers. Stability of prices to growers was seen as a primary objective. The sharp decline in the value of the $A which occurred in 1984-85 and 1985-86 therefore meant that wool became much cheaper in terms of buyer currencies.

China became a much more important force in the market, and there was strong growth in demand in other Asian countries. At the same time there were falls in wool production in major competitor producing countries.
As a result of these factors the demand for Australian wool was stimulated strongly.
These events in the market caused a degree of euphoria and over-optimism to develop in the Australian industry, which led ultimately to unsound decisions in the setting of the Minimum Reserve Price.

The Minimum Reserve Price for wool was increased by the AWC between 1986-87 and 1988-89 from 508c to 870c-or by more than 70%. The rate of increase over this two year period was nearly twice as large as that over the previous six years. The 1989-90 floor price was, as a result, set far above the long term trend price-for the first time since the introduction of the Reserve Price Scheme in the mid-1970's. Effectively, the Minimum Reserve Price had ceased to be a ``safety net'' to deal with sudden unexpected declines in price, but had become an instrument for chasing the market.

This began to seriously affect the competitiveness of the Australian industry. The high price of wool relative to competing fibres had the result that synthetics and cotton became more attractive to processors. It also allowed other wool exporting countries to begin undercutting Australian producers. The much higher Minimum Reserve Price, after a time lag, strongly discouraged demand, and strongly encouraged supply.

The factors which had previously worked in the market in a positive way to Australia's benefit now went into reverse. The value of the $A rose, and wool production in competitor countries increased. By the beginning of 1989-90, the market had become very vulnerable to the impact of unpredictable episodic events.

A series of such events then delivered a series of further hard blows to the market in 1990. No-one could have predicted the changes that have taken place in the Soviet Union and elsewhere in Eastern Europe. The Soviet Union withdrew from the market in mid-1990, as a result of internal political difficulties and foreign exchange problems. China further reduced its purchases, on top of the severe reduction which had already occurred in the previous year.

There was a slackening of demand in Japan, and in Western Europe as a result of a warm northern winter. 1989-90 turned out to be an excellent wool growing season in Australia. With low wheat prices there was little incentive for Australian farmers to turn to alternative forms of production. Finally, the invasion of Kuwait resulted in a further blow to the economic prospects in Western Europe, Japan, and the USA, and hence to market confidence.
Steps taken by the Government and industry over the recent period

It became clear to the Minister and other members of the Government by late 1989 that the Reserve Price Scheme was in trouble, and that steps would need to be taken to place it on a sounder financial footing-by some combination of measures, including a possible reduction in the Minimum Reserve Price, an increase in the rate of wool tax, an increase in the Wool Corporation's borrowing limit, and other supplementary measures to restrain supply and encourage demand.

The Government then took a series of steps, in consultation with the Corporation and the Wool Council, over the next twelve months designed to bring the situation under control. It will be useful to recapitulate those steps.

During April and May 1990 the Minister made persistent and strenuous efforts to persuade industry leaders to re-examine their assessment that the Minimum Reserve Price should continue at its existing level, and to persuade the Wool Corporation Board to take the necessary commercial decision to allow the Reserve Price Scheme to continue on a sound basis into the future. As the Senate knows, the Minister was unsuccessful in these endeavours.

In early May 1990 the Government had to take a decision in the context of its legislative program on the maximum rate of wool tax for the 1990-91 season. the Minister announced in the Parliament that the Government would increase the maximum rate of tax to 20%, but that the actual rate to apply would depend upon a suitable package of measures coming forward from industry to manage the situation.

In late May 1990, after intense public debate in the industry about the merits of maintaining or lowering the Minimum Reserve Price, the Government decided, with the greatest reluctance, that the Minister should direct the Corporation to lower the floor price for the current season to 700c/kg. He did so to preserve the long term interests of the Australian wool industry and of the Australian community, given the significance and impact of that industry on the Australian economy.

In giving this direction, the Minister was acutely conscious that, with the Minimum Reserve Price at 870c/kg, the price relativity between wool and other competing fibres would have been locked in at historically unsustainable levels, thereby preventing wool from regaining competitiveness with these other fibres. He was also conscious that lowering the Minimum Reserve Price would limit the cost of further purchases into the stockpile, and provide additional funds to meet storage costs. The reduced price was designed to send a price signal to growers to at least limit production. It was not expected that demand for wool would pick up immediately, but that demand would react positively after a time lag.
In June 1990, in the face of continuing speculation against the Minimum Reserve Price, the Government announced it would guarantee the borrowings of the AWC to $2.5 billion.

At the same time, the Government decided that it was necessary to look at the longer term issues facing the wool industry. A Committee of Inquiry into wool marketing was accordingly established, headed by Sir William Vines, to report back to the Government by July 1991.

After the blow to market confidence which resulted from the invasion of Kuwait in August, purchase rates at auction by the Wool Corporation increased sharply from about 40% to about 70%. In the light of this further development, the Wool Corporation recommended and the Government agreed to remove the ceiling on Wool Corporation's borrowings, to head off further continuing speculation about the viability of the Reserve Price Scheme.

In the context of that decision, the Minister called for the Wool Corporation to submit a Business Plan outlining how the Corporation intended to manage its financial exposure for the remainder of 1990-91, and a three year Strategic Plan on how the Corporation intended to trade its way out of its difficulties over the period ahead.

In the interests of widening the involvement of industry beyond the Australian wool producing sector, the Minister established an Interim Wool Industry Policy Council which brought in representatives of the downstream parts of the industry.

In October 1990 the industry presented its Business Plan to the Government. The Government subsequently took and announced decisions the objectives of which were to contain Wool Corporation borrowing requirements, to hold grower equity in the Market Support Fund at reasonably sustainable levels and to reduce wool production and increase trade clearances. These decisions essentially involved further increases in wool tax (the actual rate being increased from 18% to 25%), the flexibility to further increase or introduce a surcharge on such taxes next season, marketing quotas, and a flock reduction scheme.

After the Wool Corporation sought approval to commit to further borrowings, the Government decided in November that the Wool Corporation should be given a further opportunity to demonstrate that it could trade its way out of its difficulties at the current floor price. At that time the Corporation saw a prospect of a return to the auctions by buyers in December and early 1991-which are traditionally the peak buying months. The Government indicated that, while it had significant reservations about wool marketing quotas, it was not opposed in principle to the development of the necessary legislation, subject to being satisfied as to the detailed mechanisms.

The Government made every effort to leave no grounds for speculation as to its support for the 700c floor, and the Minister led an industry mission to talk to major overseas buying countries to reinforce the position. Trade purchases at auction continued, however, to be well below the Wool Corporation's expectations. They improved in early January, but then they fell away again. The Soviet Union did not immediately take up our $400 million credit.

The Corporation developed its longer term Strategic Plan, as requested. However, virtually from the day the draft Strategic Plan was first formulated the situation deteriorated rapidly, to a point where ultimately the Corporation found itself in a position where it could not bring forward a Plan which it unequivocally endorsed. The Plan was eventually put to the Minister, as a basis for discussion, on 1 February.

On the same day, faced with having to continue to borrow to meet its statutory obligation to buy wool not taken up at auction, and with its total debt approaching $3bn, the Corporation suspended auction sales.
Options considered by the Government

In its Plan, the Corporation put forward proposals that the 700c floor price be maintained for at least the next season, the wool tax be set at 35%, marketing quotas be introduced at 700kt, backed by export controls, and the flock reduction scheme be further expanded, together with additional measures to enhance demand.

As it was put to the Minister, tax and quota parameters in the Plan represented the extent of the sacrifice which the industry itself could tolerate-and in some quarters even this was seen as going too far. The industry, not unreasonably, had done its arithmetic and identified a breaking point.

Equally, however, the same principle applied from the Government's point of view. There had to be a turning point where we would be compelled to cut off exposure to the inexorable build-up in the Corporation's debt, guaranteed by the Government. the view put to us was that any downside risk of increased borrowings would have to be accommodated by the Government.

Now, confronted with that prospect, the best advice available to the Government-and the Corporation did not disagree with this assessment-was that stocks overall could reach some 8m bales in 1991-92, peaking at over 8.6m bales in 1992-93, with a Market Support Fund balance of some minus $4 billion in 1991-92.

This was not a commitment, in effect a blank cheque, which the Government could with any sense of responsibility contemplate or accept. In essence, it was not possible to see how the Government, in an open-ended way, could agree that the Corporation continue to borrow money to keep buying wool at 700 cents. Moreover, the Government continued to have serious reservations about the acceptability of marketing quotas, not least to increasing numbers of woolgrowers.
It became clear that the Wool Corporation proposal was not viable.

The Government examined a wide range of options in addition to the option of suspending the Reserve Price Scheme. Many individuals and industry groups came forward with proposals. While many of these proposals had elements to address part of the problem, none in the opinion of the Government provided a feasible, comprehensive response. Approaches which phased in the lower floor price over the balance of a season, either in pre-announced steps or by a progressive lowering of the Corporation's buying rate, would not have brought the problem of speculation against the scheme under control.

Even if these approaches could have been made to work, the Corporation's debt and stockpile would have continued to climb. Picking a new floor price, perhaps 500 or even 350 cents, would have involved a very strong risk of continued speculation against the floor.
The Government's decision

It was clear that whichever course the Government chose would involve a long period of difficulty for the industry, with severe effects on grower incomes. The 4.8 million bales stockpile of wool held by the Corporation-more than a whole clip in some seasons-will take years to run down and will depress the market. The Corporation's current debt of $2.8 billion will also take years to reduce.
After having considered all the options, the Government decided that there was no choice but to allow the market to set the price for wool.

It was clear that there was a much better prospect of bringing both the Wool Corporation debt and wool stocks under control in the absence of a floor price and without the Wool Corporation buying in the market.

However, we have no illusions about the impact of the Government's decision. Direct grower incomes from the sale of wool will fall sharply in the short term. Some will be hit harder than others and, in particular, the market price of the middle micron will probably be lower than those of other categories of wool. China and the USSR have been key markets for these wools, which now comprise a high proportion of the stockpile. It is in this middle range that the Reserve Price Scheme therefore most notably masked demand.

To give effect to the Government's decisions, a new Part X, dealing with ``Temporary Provisions'', will be added to the Wool Marketing Act which will, in effect, suspend the RPS provisions of the Act until a date fixed by proclamation (see section 143).

During the period of suspension, the Corporation will not be permitted to buy wool (section 143). To all intents and purposes, the Wool Corporation stockpile will be frozen, although the precise details remain to be worked out between the Minister and the Wool Corporation.

The AWC's flock reduction scheme will be reviewed, and, if it continues, will be scaled down and focus on animal welfare requirements. The AWC's proposed wool marketing quota scheme will not now proceed.

Provision has also been made for the Minister to appoint for a limited period an interim administrator or Interim Board of the AWC (section 147). These powers have been included to allow the Minister to ensure the ongoing operation of the Board ad interim and in exceptional circumstances. The Minister will have the discretion as to appointments. However, it is the intention that the Minister would consult with the industry in making such appointments.

Wool selling arrangements to apply after 30 June will be finalised in April after the Government considers the recommendation of the Vines Committee of Inquiry into wool marketing, which will now report to the Minister by 31 March. If there is to be any form of Reserve Price Scheme from 1 July, it will be self funding and the floor price will be set conservatively against the then prevailing market prices. The Government has taken this course to enable the market to find its own level, thereby permitting the long term future of wool marketing to be decided in the light of market realities.
Debt and stocks reduction program
The Government has decided that responsibility for the Corporation's debt and stockpile should remain with the Corporation.

It is highly desirable that arrangements be put in place which will allow the industry to recover from its present situation in the shortest possible time, and develop an industry structure which will maximise benefits to growers over the longer term. To this end it will be necessary not only that prices be set by the market but also that the Wool Corporation's stockpile and debt be reduced in a way and at a rate which will maximise grower incomes over the period ahead.
Indeed, the proper management of the reduction in the Corporation's stockpile and debt will be as important to recovery in grower incomes as the pricing policy decisions will be.
The Minister will issue guidelines in relation to the debt reduction program and the disposal of the stockpile (sections 144 to 146).

The Commonwealth and the Corporation will develop a management plan by early April, soon after the Vines report is received, to deal with debt management, stockpile disposal, and Wool Corporation finances.

The Government will lift the ceiling on its guarantee of AWC borrowings to $3.5 billion and extend its guarantee on all borrowings beyond 1992 for the period required to manage the run down of the industry's debt.
Supplementary Payments Scheme

The suspension of the Reserve Price Scheme in mid season leaves us with a potential equity problem. There will be two groups of sellers, namely, those who have already sold their wool at 700c, much of which has gone into the stockpile, and those who will be offering wool for sale between now and July. Those yet to sell would, in the absence of supplementary measures, bear the brunt of the initial market adjustment caused by accumulated events and industry decisions over the last two years.

Moreover, the problem for some groups of growers in the middle micron ranges will be even more severe, since this wool is already in excess supply and could be passed in at auction or sell at very low prices.

For these reasons, the Government has agreed to a supplementary payments scheme for the remainder of the season. The scheme will be administered by the Wool Corporation. The administration of the Scheme will be in accordance with guidelines issued by the Minister (section 140). The cost of the scheme will be shared between the Government and the industry. The Government will contribute $300m (see section 142). The balance will be financed through the AWC by a combination of tax receipts and further borrowings, which the Government will guarantee.
The wool tax rate will remain at its current rate of 25% for the remainder of the current season.

Underpinning the short term assistance provided under the Supplementary Payments Scheme will be the Rural Adjustment Scheme and the Rural Counselling Program, under which the Government will provide assistance to those most affected in the wool industry and elsewhere in the rural sector. The Government will provide additional substantial funds for these purposes. The details of this will be worked out in the context of the Government's consideration in April of a submission by the Minister on rural incomes, which will include the question of the Rural Adjustment Scheme and the Rural Counselling Program.
R and D and Promotion

Research and development is critical for the long term future of the wool industry. The Government will be prepared to consider increased assistance for R and D to supplement industry levies particularly in 1991-92. To ensure that R& is not compromised by Wool Corporation funding difficulties, a Wool R& Corporation will be established separate from the Wool Corporation. However, it may be expected that the R& Corporation will share accommodation and administrative services with the Corporation, unless its own Board determines that these services can be provided more efficiently by other means.
Further improvements will also need to be made in Australia's wool promotion and marketing efforts and improvement in the operating structure and capacity of the AWC.
If I may sum up.
The Government has been required to take some very tough decisions in order to secure the future viability and prosperity of the Australian wool industry.

All the parties involved, namely, industry leaders, the Australian Wool Corporation, individual woolgrowers, people involved in downstream activities, and the Government, must now work harmoniously together if the industry is to reap the full benefits of these decisions.
There is no point in looking backwards, or in engaging in a search for scapegoats. We have to press ahead, together, to see the industry through one of the worst phases of its long and proud history.

A managed operation will now be put in place which will enable the industry to pull through in reasonable shape over the next five years and beyond. The industry will retain primary responsibility for its affairs while the Government provides the support necessary to manage the recovery.
The decisions which the legislation before the Senate will permit us to implement are the correct ones for the industry, individual woolgrowers, end users, and the Australian tax payer.
I commend the Bill to the Senate, and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SELECTION OF BILLS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)-by leave-agreed to:

That Senator McKiernan be discharged from further attendance on the Selection of Bills Committee and that Senator Faulkner, having been duly nominated in accordance with the resolution of the Senate of 5 December 1989, be appointed a member of that Committee.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray, for Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That this item be discharged from the Notice Paper.
Debate resumed from 19 February, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 3), the fact that we have a third Appropriation Bill gives rise to canvass more broadly the manner in which the Government conducts its business, including forecasting the Budget, use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance and, indeed, the accuracy of predictions of expenditure which it predicates along the process. This Bill seeks to appropriate expenditure in addition to the normal appropriations process, and the usual practice for unseen or urgent payments being accommodated by the Advance to the Minister for Finance I think needs some closer scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last several days we have had before the Senate the statement of approvals that were sought to be made for payments from that Advance both by way of additional payment and payments in advance of the passage of this Bill. There are a couple of payments included in those figures which are worthy of closer scrutiny. Firstly, there is the sum of some $3.3m, which has been necessary for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for payment to various United Nations organisations of which Australia is a member. We got the sums wrong to the tune of $3.3m because of a variation in the exchange rate. In the explanatory notes supporting the application for the payment from that source, the case is made out that, as we are required to make timely payment, we had to take the exchange rate as it existed at the appropriate date, and therefore suffer the loss. I think a better effort can be made so that we do not incur losses of that nature.

Further, and more seriously, $22m was claimed by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to promote Australia abroad-again a total lack of forethought and planning. In January the total claims for the Federal bureaucracy were over $70m. A large proportion of that figure obviously could have been considered earlier. In all honesty, perhaps the description that is relied upon that the payments were required because they were urgent or unforeseen could be said to be stretching the truth somewhat. There is considerable ministerial discretion in determining what classes of expenditure are either urgent or unforeseen. Perhaps the Minister representing the Minister for Finance (Senator Button) should exercise his discretion to put greater pressure on the public service and fellow Ministers to get it right in the first place.

The legislation before us will allow for an additional sum of money to be appropriated above and beyond those figures which were contained in the Budget. Specifically the Bill seeks to appropriate $234.1m for the current financial year. Of this, $52.7m is for the Department of Defence for equipment and stores expenditures associated with the deployment of our forces in the Gulf. An additional $16.2m for this financial year is to be sought through the additional Estimates process. A further $181.4m is for payments by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to meet the Australian Wheat Board claims associated with the Iraq defaults on credit sales. This figure constitutes Australia's contribution to the insurance policy under the Export Finance Insurance Corporation and the national interest export insurance scheme. Of that sum, some $43m was sought through the Advance to the Minister for Finance in anticipation of this Bill being passed.

To put that into context, it is important to realise that Iraq has been an important export market for our wheat in recent years. It was our largest wheat market in 1989-90, representing 10 per cent of our total wheat exports. In the 1988-89 financial year Australia exported $293m worth of wheat to Iraq. That figure was increased in 1989-90 to $392m. In fact, we supplied Iraq with 50 per cent of its total wheat imports prior to the Kuwait invasion. The loss of that market amounts to a body blow for the Australian wheat industry at the worst possible time of economic recession and gives particular hardship to the man on the land. The timing for the wheat industry could not be worse. There has been world overproduction in wheat, with a bumper harvest in the Northern Hemisphere. When this is combined with the results of the farm subsidies of both the United States and the European Community and the increase of farm costs under this Government in Australia, profits have been very badly squeezed.

In addition to our wheat sales to Iraq, until 1987-88 Australia was the sole supplier of wheat to Kuwait, which earned us $13m in that year. That supply evaporated when the United States began selling to Kuwait at subsidised prices. There is a similar problem with regard to Egypt. The point is that the Budget was brought down after Iraq invaded Kuwait. It is important to note that the Budget made absolutely no provision for expenditure of this kind. It made no allowance for the fact that there would be serious payments to be made out of the Export Finance Insurance Corporation and that there would be a shortfall in our export sales. Had the Government had a modicum of foresight, there would be no need to rush this Bill through to allow for this particular expenditure. The Opposition has agreed to limit its speakers to 10 minutes to allow more senators to speak and to allow the Bill to be passed as speedily as the Government would hope, despite the fact that if there had been proper planning there would have been no need to introduce this Bill in this form in this hurry.

The Government may answer that it is all very well to say with hindsight that there should have been provision made. The fact is that the shadow Minister for trade and trade negotiations (Mr Downer) predicted at the time of the Budget that the Government would be in exactly this position. In a press release that he put out on 24 August, he said:

. . . although the Opposition totally supported the application of sanctions against Iraq, it was concerned that provision for compensation to the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) had not been made in last Tuesday's Budget.

No provision was made in the Budget under the National Interest Export Insurance scheme, which is totally underwritten by the Commonwealth, to cover this considerable debt which could be claimed by the AWB if Iraq fails to meet its payments on time.

Those words fell on deaf ears. The Government made no planning and now we are rushing an important Bill through this House. The fact that there was, as I mentioned, nearly $44m already paid out by the Advance to the Minister for Finance, which was tabled last week, pending the passage of this Bill is of concern given that this action has pre-empted the authority of the Parliament in the passage of this legislation. In addition to the $181.4m, a further $29.7m may be required to June and this will be included in the additional Estimates.

I will take a moment to point out the importance of the whole process of the Estimates committees. The Government tends to try to disparage the work that is done in the Estimates committees by saying that they are a lengthy process, that too many questions are asked or something else. The fact is that it is one of the most important links of scrutiny between the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.
—I am very pleased to hear Senator Robert Ray say that. It is very refreshing to hear a member of the Government say that.
—I am also critical of them.

—It is fine to be critical of them, but they are a most important part of the process. If it does take a lengthy period to get through some of the information, it is usually because there was obfuscation somewhere along the line in getting the information out into the open.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last couple of minutes that I have left this morning, it would be remiss of me if I did not mention the question of Austrade. We have just lost export markets with regard to wheat, so the question of increasing our exports has become even more important. I think it is important to note that the McKinsey report relating to Austrade-the Australian Trade Commission-which has been given to the Minister and placed in the hands of the Board was not available to members of the Parliament; but it was made available to members of the journalistic profession. Some of us have managed to get hold of a couple of that report. It is exceedingly critical of Austrade. I think it is important when finally we come to debate the report to note for instance that it draws our attention to statistics such as 45 per cent of the resources of Austrade being used for back-up facilities, and that for every one person on the line who is in fact having client contact and actually helping with our exports, there is an average of 1 1/2 people to back him up.

I think that there is a very serious question to be asked of the Minister responsible, who has fought so assiduously to keep control of Austrade when quite clearly the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was very keen to have it as well. I think it is most important that we ask questions of the Minister as to why, since the interception of Austrade, oversight and scrutiny have been lacking, so that we can get this very damning report that says very simply that everything from the leadership of Austrade to the deployment of resources to the philosophical implementation of policy has been lacking and poor.

As I said, when we come to look at a Bill such as a third Bill to appropriate further funds for expenditure that the Government properly ought to have taken into account at the time of the Budget, it allows us to speak on a more wide ranging series of subjects. I know that some of my colleagues will also be taking that opportunity to criticise the Government in many areas.

I find that the Bill, urgent though it is, and needing to go through, does not take away from the fact that it is poor planning on the part of the Government that has left us in this mess. The Government has time and again relied on the Advance to the Minister for Finance to overcome deficiencies of planning simply through negligence of duty in some cases. This has given us an opportunity to highlight that deficiency in Government planning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91 seeks appropriations from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for two different purposes. Today I will address only the question of funding to meet insurance claims associated with defaults by Iraq on its payments for wheat sales. It seems highly unlikely that Iraq will indeed make payments in the foreseeable future. There will be a considerable time of rebuilding and reconstructing that country once this war is over.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that this payment is one the Government cannot avoid. It therefore cannot be seen as additional support or extra assistance for the rural community at this time as the Government has an obligation under the national insurance provisions to find this money. It is on the issue of assistance for the rural community at this time that I wish to concentrate this morning. It would be very difficult to overstate the plight of rural people in 1991, in particular farmers and small business people. Nearly 75 per cent of Australian wheat farmers are likely to have a negative income this year; that is, they will be losing money despite the fact that their crop might be one of the best they have grown in recent times. The Grains Council of Australia has indicated that there is every likelihood that farmers will be unable to plant between one-third and half the nation's wheat growing area in the coming year. This has dramatic implications for their future livelihood.

It is pleasing to note that the Government is at least going to write to the United States (US) to protest that its trade practices are destroying the viability of Australian farmers. We learned yesterday that it is possible that a trade delegation might be sent to the US. Far more must be done. Farmers and their families need practical assistance. They must be able to tap into at least the existing support services available for low income city families. Hopefully, these support payments will be required only for a short time, but they must be available.

As of yesterday the National Farmers Federation has new figures which show that there will be a drop in farm income of around 67 per cent this year. This is even worse than the income figures forecast by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, which estimated a fall of 57 per cent.

It is not just the wheat farmers and many of the sheep farmers who are facing financial ruin. Many commodities right across the board are worth less than the cost of production. There is a wide variety of reasons for this crisis now being faced by Australian farmers. I suggest that the problems are related to government action or inaction. I note also that solutions to the specific problems are within the control of the Government, at least to some extent.

I would like to give honourable senators some examples of other farmers who are facing real difficulties. To do this I will read from a document prepared by the Riverland Fight for Survival Committee late last year. It is titled `Crisis in Australian Horticulture' and asks:
DID YOU KNOW?

Australian family growers of crops like dried fruit, canning fruit, citrus, apples, pears, potatoes, peanuts, pineapples, beans, bananas, sugar . . . are being forced off their land by a flood of cheap imported foods;
State and Federal Government FREE TRADE and DEREGULATION policies are actively encouraging these imports, to supposedly ``make Australia more efficient. . . .
Liberal and National parties, instead of opposing these policies, think the government should move faster to abolish protection for Australian industries;
Last year, Australia added $2.1 billion to its national debt (which we and our children will eventually have to repay!), by importing foodstuffs that COULD have been bought from Australian producers.
It goes on to say:
THESE IMPORTS COME FROM COUNTRIES WHICH:
Protect their own industries if Australia tries to export to THEIR country . . .

It gives an example of Turkish dried apricots which can come in here duty free, but if we want to send fruit to Turkey, we would face a 40 per cent import duty. It continues that these imports come from countries which:

Subsidise their growers, and land goods in Australia at prices so low, that Australian growers can't even grow their crops for these prices, let alone make themselves anything extra to live on! (e.g. Greek peaches sell for half the Australian price, and Greek growers get $200 per tonne subsidy; oranges cost an average of $150/tonne to grow in the Riverland, but growers here are expected at present to sell them for around $70/tonne to compete with Brazilian juice!)

Have wages levels and a standard of living which are clearly unacceptable to Australians (e.g. compare the $7/tonne Brazilian orange pickers get to the $40/tonne for Australians; or our apple-picking wages, compared to the $3.50/day earned by Chilean pickers!)

Looking at the plight of farmers we ask the Government: when will it make the family allowance supplement available for farming families? The Australian Democrats argue that this is preferable to special crisis payments. Why should farm families not be treated as other Australians are when they are in genuine need? Families in urban Australia can access support benefits readily if their income drops. Many farming families will have negative incomes this year, yet because of high valuations put on their properties-I emphasis these are often very high and unrealistic valuations-these families are denied any support. I stress that the family farm is not a readily saleable asset. Many farmers are already in debt and cannot go on borrowing. Indeed the banks would be very reluctant to lend for the purpose of simply providing a farming family with food and clothing. We strongly argue that the family farm is a tool of trade and should be treated as such.

What is the Government suggesting farmers should do at this stage? Perhaps the Government is still not convinced that farmers and small business people are in real need. I would like to now quote from a draft statement on wealth distribution from the Catholic Bishops of Australia. It is titled `Common wealth and common good'. The conclusion of chapter 1 on page 25 of the statement reads as follows:

We conclude this chapter by drawing attention to disturbing reports that small businesses and farming enterprises have been collapsing at an increasing rate in this country. Undoubtedly a number of factors, including the availability of easy credit in the 1980s, followed by a downturn in the economy, have contributed to this. It may not be helpful to look for culprits, but it is necessary to state that true national wellbeing will not exist unless the health of the small farming and business sector is assured.
Looking specifically at child poverty, on page 31 the statement goes on to say:

It is generally agreed that family support initiatives like the Family Allowance Supplement have reduced child poverty substantially over the past year or so. Commonly quoted figures suggest that the number of children in poor families fell from around 750 000 or 800 000 to perhaps 400 000 or 500 000 after these measures were implemented.
Recent studies make it clear, however, that child poverty in Australia remains a desperate and in many ways a scandalous problem.
Finally the statement looks specifically at poverty in farming communities. It states:

As noted in Chapter 1 . . . serious financial problems affected the rural area during the 1980s. The inquiry received a number of submissions on the plight of farmers created by reducing commodity prices, high interest rates and the resultant high exchange rate of the Australian dollar; the decreasing population in many rural areas; the lack of educational and employment opportunities; and the high cost of services and fuel in country areas.
It was pointed out that better times for agriculture did not automatically mean an end of farm adjustment problems or relief for the small businesses relying on the farming economy.

After studying the situation in 78 Victorian rural communities, Bruce McKenzie, of the Warrnambool Institute of Adult Education said that `Australia is developing an increasing peasant underclass and previously middle-class people are now in the depth of poverty'. McKenzie found that the level of child poverty in the areas was double the national rate of one in eight.

The difficulties faced by rural families are further compounded by the assets test on Austudy. Yes, it is more relaxed but it is still far too high for most farm families to access and the very unrealistic valuations placed on farm families by the Australian Valuation Office (AVO) lead to further problems. Not only do young rural people want to study agricultural practices and attend specialist horticultural colleges and other courses that would enhance their general education, but also many rural parents are actively encouraging their young people to think about leaving the farm. They want their sons and daughters to gain other qualifications as they see little, if any, future for them on the land.

I would now like to go through a number of case histories from South Australia. These are gradually building up as we talk to people who are having major problems with Austudy. I stress that I have summarised these-indeed a number of other honourable senators have copies of these, because they were presented to the committee when it looked into the assets test on the family allowance and the family allowance supplement-in such a way that the identity of the people involved is unable to be ascertained.

The family in case A lives in Balaklava in South Australia. It relied on the Department of Lands valuation, which was accepted, of $315,000 for the farm. The AVO retrospectively revalued the property from 1 January 1989 up to $421,000 and now it has to pay back $14,500, as it had already been obtaining Austudy for several children. This family suggests that the AVO looks at the highest price per hectare in the entire district-even though a neighbour may only be adding a prized piece of land to his own holding-and then extrapolates that for all other properties. The modern four bedroom home was valued down to only $68,000. For the benefit of honourable senators here, I will stress that by valuing the property up and the house down-making a larger and larger gap-it means there is even less likelihood that the family will qualify for Austudy. A local land agent looked at the AVO valuation and he believed that it was totally unrealistic.

Case B from the mid-north in South Australia is about a family with three children; all of whom are attending tertiary study. It has been asked to repay the 1989 and 1990 Austudy allowances amounting to $16,063.13. It also used the Valuer General's capital valuation which, in 1989, was $516,000; and in 1990, $578,000-although that was reduced by $21,000 due to a mistake. However, the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) did not accept the Valuer General's figures and the AVO revalued the farm upward to $735,000. After review it went down to $675,000 but this still means that it has to repay the money.

Case D is another one from the mid-north where the family has two teenage children and, in this case, was forced to pay back the family allowance supplement (FAS) because of a very large wool cheque that arrived late in the year. Despite the fact that income this year is down 55 per cent the family is now ineligible and it desperately needs both FAS and Austudy. The family says:

It is frightening to think of the future. Where will the money come from? I think having to put up with all the hardship is enough without the Government trying to squeeze us any more. We haven't got any more.

Case F is a family from near Port Lincoln which has three sons; the eldest of whom wants to go to Roseworthy Agricultural College. The family already does not qualify under the assets test, despite the taxable income last year being $21,000. It cannot afford for him to work on the farm and there are no local jobs. The family asks: what do we do?

Case G comes from Crystal Brook in South Australia. This family has eight children and, with the eldest son in tertiary education, was accepted for Austudy. But the family also had its farm revalued upwards and was found to be $32,098 over the limit. It has to pay back $1,985 and it has, I understand, appealed.

Case H is again from the mid-north of South Australia. It involves two children. On the advice of DEET, the farm assets were valued as per council rates notice less the replacement or insurance value of the house plus curtilage, and therefore they qualified. However, the Australian Valuation Office revalued the property over the limit and all payments had to be repaid. That was asked to be done within 14 days. The Commonwealth valuation was 22 per cent higher than the State Valuer General's one, and the value of the house was deemed to be 50 per cent less than its insurance value. In 1991, the family will have three children wanting to go to tertiary studies and, despite selling 600 acres, will still not have access to borrowings and will not be able to afford to send them to study.

Case I comes from Port Lincoln in South Australia. Two sons qualified for Austudy. The family was also reassessed retrospectively by AVO and has to pay back all 1989 and 1990 payments for both sons; a total of $10,512.10. I will go quickly through these last few cases. Case J is from near Kimba in South Australia. The land was valued by Elders at $68 per acre, but it was revalued upwards by AVO to $120 per acre. The children have to go away as the local school only goes to year 10. Forced sales in the area are now getting no bid, no offer. The latest sale that was made realised $25 per acre, although there was one $40 per acre sale very close to the town on excellent land when a neighbour particularly wanted a block of land. For the valuation, wool on the sheep's back was also valued, although the family argued that it should have been only the carcass valuation because effectively 18 months of wool was included. A very small value was put on the family home. The family also notes that Austudy should be available in year 11 because major problems in South Australia are caused as many 15-year-olds go into year 11 there and also that five-year averaging should be available on income.

Case K is from Cockaleechie in South Australia. The family assets were valued, less the mortgage, already over the limit, and therefore it was not even able to apply for Austudy. However, the gross income last year was $127,800, but their operating costs were $184,204; in other words, the family made a loss. It is still ineligible. It says:
I hope and pray that the Government would move to have the assets tests removed for Austudy as this is the only hope for country children to have an equal chance with city children.

Case L is from the mid-north in South Australia where the family has two children in Adelaide at tertiary studies. The family applied for Austudy on 30 June 1989 based on that year's income and the Valuer General's valuation. The property was revalued-depending on which section one looks at and I have all the details here for anyone who wants to spend some time going through them-between 31 per cent and 79 per cent upwards section by section. The family appealed but is still ineligible for Austudy. It had the Valuer General come out and do another set of valuations which put it still within the limit, but the AVO would not accept those figures. The family now has to pay back $3,202. They say:
I believe that the valuer sent here by Austudy had a figure of $322,751-
which is the limit-
in front of him and was easily able to exceed this value by either valuing our land upwards or our home downwards or a combination of both.

Case M is from Mallala in South Australia. The family has two sons. It believes that the council rate valuation is totally unrealistic even for good times. The neighbouring farm has been on the market for over 12 months with absolutely no interest. Land was sold 15 miles away for two-thirds of the asking price. The family was getting only $1.70 at the end of last year for sheep sold in Adelaide. It states that it is imperative that it retain eligibility for family allowance. This letter was written at a time when there was possibly going to be an assets test put on that as well. The family goes on to say at the end of the letter:
I'm hoping Canberra will listen to the hurting farm families and do something to help.

As honourable senators note, most of these cases have come from the mid-north in South Australia. Recently foreclosures have begun in this area and I have seen one of those notices. I visited Jamestown on the seventh of this month and attended a meeting there, at which it was explained that some 66 bank branches in the upper north, mid-north and Yorke Peninsula had been surveyed as to the viability of farmers in their areas and 51 branches replied. In the upper north, it was disclosed that 31 farmers are now declared by their bank to be unviable; in the mid-north, 94; and in the Yorke Peninsula, 38. That is about 5 per cent of the farmers in that region of South Australia. If the valuations were genuinely on market value, all farmers would immediately be able to access Austudy as their properties are not saleable. As I mentioned previously, they are already coming under the hammer and there is no bid, no offer. They are effectively worth nothing if the Commonwealth's valuer is to follow the instructions given to him and value them at market value.

Why should the family farm, a tool of trade, be valued at all for the purpose of assessing a family's ability to access education services or basic family support services? It should not be included in the assets test. The family farm and small business are not a luxury or liquid asset that can readily be swapped for cash to meet living and education expenses. The Democrats call for urgent action. We must move immediately to exempt the family farm and small business from the assets test for Austudy, isolated children's assistance payments and family allowance supplement.

I would just like to close with a quote from an article by Geoff Kitney in the Australian Financial Review late last year. It highlights the difference in attitude to farmers between people in Europe-in this case specifically the French-and we Australians. In fact, there is a very stark difference between this view and the way our farming community is perceived and, indeed, treated. Writing from Paris, he said:
Farming in Europe, they say, is not just an economic activity-it has cultural, environmental and strategic values on which it is impossible to put an economic price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) is to make additional appropriations of $234m to give effect to the Government's commitment both to the defence efforts in the Gulf conflict and the trade consequences of that commitment. To that end, the Bill provides $181m for payment by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to meet insurance claims associated with defaults by Iraq on credit sales by the Australian Wheat Board, which were insured under the national interest provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act. Iraq, as we all know, stopped payments on its wheat debt after the imposition of the United Nations trade sanctions and it is now considered unlikely that any payments will be made in the foreseeable future. I understand that there will be more funds payable in June this year of $29.7m, and further claims, totalling $247m in 1991-92 and $34m in 1992-93, are expected. There is more aid, but that is the extent to which the Government will reimburse the wheat industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I venture further into this debate, and in the event that anyone might regard these expenditures as some sort of handout from the Australian taxpayers to the wheat farmers, let me indicate that these payments are an insurance payment. That is exactly what they are, just as any insurance company has claims on it or submitted to it from people who have problems with a house or anything else. For years the Government has collected premiums to insure against such an event as this and now it is having to pay out. I repeat: it is no handout. It is no gift; it is merely a business transaction for an insurance that was held by the wheat industry. Certainly, for the wheat industry and for the Australian Wheat Board, the collapse and possible disappearance of this market through Iraq could not have come at a worse time.

The condition of the Australian domestic wheat market is, to quote the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, `extremely depressed'. I say that it is very depressed. This is largely because of a record world wheat crop. Of the world's seven largest wheat producers, six have had record or near record production and for the first time in four years production has exceeded consumption. This condition has basically prevailed through most of the 1980s. To put the Australian wheat industry into perspective, Australia produces around 16 million tonnes of wheat a year and our anticipated wheat crop for 1991 is 15.7 million tonnes. By comparison, world wheat production this year is anticipated to be somewhere in the order of 600 million tonnes. Australia's production actually just about equals the annual variation in the United States (US) wheat crop, so we are very small fry in a very large market. That must make us price takers and not price makers. That is one of the problems we have in Australia, isolated as we are.

Our wheat industry is an export industry. We grow wheat to sell overseas and last year we exported 10 million tonnes of the 14 million tonnes we produced, of which Iraq took 1.37 million tonnes, Iran took 1.68 million tonnes and Egypt took 1.83 million tonnes. To lose these markets leaves a sizeable hole in our marketing strategies. I believe the Iraq market represented 10 per cent of our total export sales. For the year 1990-91 we had already sold $600m worth of wheat on credit to that nation. To lose these markets, as I said, at a time when the world has record wheat tonnages to dispose of, increases the depressing situation for our domestic situation in Australia. Of course, the situation for wheat sales has become increasingly more difficult over the last few years.

We have seen the escalation in the subsidy war between the US and the European Community. The United States has made sales of subsidised wheat into many markets with export bonuses as high as $55 a tonne. Similarly, the European Community has continued its restrictive import levies and offered export refunds on sales in some markets of between $100 a tonne and $150 a tonne. These actions have forced the world market price down to levels which, in real terms, have been unprecedented, with subsidised sales as low as $US75 a tonne. There has also been an increase in such activities as credit sales. In the Middle East, for example, Australia was, until 1987-88, the sole exporter of wheat to Kuwait. The US entered the market taking sales from us by offering wheat to Kuwait at heavily discounted and subsidised prices. As recently as January this year, America sold 400,000 tonnes of wheat to Egypt at a subsidised price of $64 a tonne. Compare that to the Australian price of $120 a tonne or down as low as $60 a tonne on farm to the Australian wheat grower and we begin to understand the desperate situation that that puts Australian wheat farmers into.

For Australian wheat growers, the news in the last little while has been more and more depressing. The Wheat Board announced some while ago an anticipated return to growers of $135 per tonne. This was down from $180 per tonne in 1989. That figure has since been revised, again downwards, to $115 a tonne, which will be the lowest price for 60 years. Remember that the Australian farmers are receiving this at a time when US and European farmers are offering wheat on export markets at $US64 a tonne. What can the Australian wheat grower do about it? It is not a case of Australian farmers becoming more cost efficient or more productive. We are already at the forefront of technology and efficiency. We simply cannot grow wheat any cheaper than we do. Most wheat farmers are using old tractors that they may have had for 10 years as they cannot afford to buy new tractors.

This year we have the frightening prospect of 75 per cent of Australia's 45,000 wheat growers receiving a negative income-in other words, getting less for their crop than it cost them to produce it as a result of subsidies on export markets around the world. As much as half of those 45,000 farmers are thinking seriously of not planting any wheat at all. They cannot turn to wool because of the problems in the wool industry. That market is having great problems. So what do those 23,000 wheat farmers do? Of course, this has ramifications for Australia's future trade because, if we do not grow enough wheat this year to supply even our traditional markets, we are going to lose those traditional markets to the highly subsidised wheat industries of America and the European Community.

The Australian wheat growers have tried to trade in this increasingly corrupt market and, basically, we are looking at real breakthroughs in the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to do something about it. We have got to get the government of the day to remove the imposts of high interest rates and all the other problems. We have to have a decent taxation reform, so that when we produce a profit we do not to have pay it all away in tax. We have to have, as the Opposition suggests, something like a goods and services tax. We have to have a decent labour market reform. We have to have an abandonment of the accord, in my belief, to get back to a fair day's work for a fair day's pay so that we do not prop up inflation by giving wage rises just because of indexed consumer price increases.

We have to get rid of inefficiencies in telecommunications, transport, shipping and the waterfront and in power generation. We have to get disadvantages to Australian industry taken off the back of Australia. We have to have reform of government operations by contracting out of government services to the private sector, which could save in the order of 20 per cent. We have to have privatisation of some of the sleepy, inefficient government owned monopolies. They have to be shaken up and exposed to the competition of privatisation. We have got to have industry reform.

We have also got to have a decent environmental and development program, setting out clear and consistent guidelines to achieve an appropriate balance between development and conservation of the environment. That has to be done. It cannot just be talked about. We have to have an effective policy on resource security.

Getting back to trade reform, it was interesting recently, while I was at the United Nations with Senator Jones representing this Parliament, to speak with people from the European Community. We were told-and this is what concerns me about big breakthroughs in trade reform around the world-by European parliamentarians that in no way could they see their farmers having to battle with elements, currency exchange fluctuations, high interest rates or corrupt world markets. The latter statement, coming from people in the European Community, makes one laugh a little, but they intend to look after their farmers. The Americans are looking, as is the Cairns Group, for big breakthroughs in the Uruguay Round. We are looking for a substantial drop in protection in other countries and getting to a fair free trade situation around the world. Basically the United States of America supports that view, but it is a bit of a catch-as-catch-can because the Americans will not be fair dinkum about this until the Europeans are. That scares the hell out of me as an Australian farmer and as a person representing Australian farmers in this Parliament. Where will Australia sit in the next few years when we may move towards fairer trade, and when we may get the Americans and Europeans to come to some realisation that they cannot keep on propping up their industries?

The other thing that we in Australia must do in the meantime is to make sure that we get the imposts off the backs of Australian farmers-many of which have been imposed upon us by the Hawke-Keating Labor Government. Mr Acting Deputy President, we have all decided to speak for 10 minutes and I notice that my 10 minutes is up.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a great 10 minutes, a very good speech.

—I thank the Minister for that remark; I appreciate it. I hope that the Minister will take a little notice of what I said, and I know that he did take notice of some of the reforms that we believe this Government has to put in place to get Australian agriculture back to where it was 10 or 15 years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are today debating the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91, which covers the costs incurred by Australia's participation in both international sanctions and military operations against Iraq in the Middle East. I open my contribution in this debate by noting with deep regret that war is popular. Maggie Thatcher, after all, going back a little, won an unwinnable election because she led the United Kingdom into the Falklands war. We have noted how Prime Minister Hawke's popularity rating has shot up since he led Australia into the Gulf war. John Major is now the most popular British Prime Minister for 30 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who protest that sanctions applied swiftly, strongly and unanimously by the United Nations immediately after the brutal invasion of Kuwait by Iraq-which in its turn had been earlier condemned by the UN and with which condemnation I agree-would not have worked and would have taken too long have never been backed, and are not now backed, by any reputable expert opinion. The view is expressed that the virtual unanimity of support for sanctions would not have been able to be sustained for much longer than the five months that was given before the outbreak of war. After thinking and reading about this matter all this time, I have concluded that that opinion must be based on the view that the individual nations involved in the sanctions regime-nations such as Australia, which is losing a great deal of export income as a result of the sanctions; and this Bill is designed to make up that loss-with their individual self-interest at stake, would quickly have overcome their sense of international responsibility, and hence the war option was necessary so that trade could be resumed as soon as possible. I refer to trade both ways because many other nations are more interested in imports of oil from Iraq and Kuwait.

I wonder what this says about the so-called moral basis put in this chamber on Monday by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in answer to a question that I put to him. The answer was:

. . . we do not make decisions about war and peace, with all that that implies, on the basis of dollar and cents considerations; we make it on the basis of considerations of morality, considerations of justice and considerations of an intelligent appreciation of the consequences of not acting. . .

I wonder about that basis for decision making in the light of the lack of alternative opinion about why sanctions were considered not to be able to work or why further time could not be given, and that death and destruction should be seen as a more desirable option simply because the participating nations all have internal budgetary pressures, as we do in this country as a result of our support for sanctions.

What, I wonder, of the Third World nations, the children dying in poverty and starvation, those poorest and most disadvantaged people in the world who will now never see the billions of dollars which are being expended this very day on the conduct of the war and which will have to be spent in time to come as a result of the aftermath of that war. What of the casualties in the conflict-military personnel, young conscripts largely, in the case of the Iraqis, with no choice in the matter; and, in the case of the United States of America (USA), with a disproportionate representation among them of the poor, blacks, hispanics and other minorities from that nation? What also of the innocent civilians in Iraq, Kuwait and Israel, sufferers of so-called collateral damage and potential victims of the now highly likely outbreak of dreadful epidemics of cholera, typhoid and other diseases in the wake of the destruction wreaked by the massive air attacks thus far, which are continuing?

So far war appears to be popular, a fact that seems to have excited Senator Kemp so much that he has come into the chamber. I remind the Senate that Senator Kemp has pointed out how many people seem to be indicating their support for this war through public opinion polls. I am certain that, once the real story becomes clear-and if there is one thing that is clear at the moment it is that the real story is not clear-once the reality of the casualty figures, which is starting to come to the fore now, is known; and once the evidence, which again is coming to the fore increasingly this very day, that the United States is determined to wipe Iraq off the map, contrary to the United Nations position, is clearer, especially if the ground war begins; the popularity will not last.

But, given the present figures and the continual bleating by Senator Kemp and the figures so beloved of Senator Kemp, one thing that should be said at this point is that I am also confident that I shall never again hear from the Opposition benches or from anywhere else in criticism of the Australian Democrats that we are a populist political party. I have challenged the moral basis for the decision to go to war, put here in this chamber on Monday by Senator Evans on behalf of the Government, and I stand here to counter any claims of populism ever portrayed against the Party which I lead.

In my contribution to this debate, I want to focus largely on the United Nations and its role in this issue in the past and into the future. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has portrayed the war against Iraq as a demonstration of the fact that the United Nations is finally acting with the unity expected of it when it was first established. If we are to make a realistic assessment of the UN's potential to realise Mr Hawke's vision of a new world order of peace, security and freedom, it is important to examine the role of the United Nations in the crisis which was triggered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you support the UN?
—The reality of the UN's action is actually very different to that claimed by Mr Hawke and obviously believed by Senator Kemp at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: After a very sound start, with the Security Council demanding that the invasion be reversed in resolution 660 and applying mandatory and comprehensive trade sanctions in resolution 661, the UN's role has steadily regressed. It has become seriously compromised and marginalised and the Secretary-General, Perez de Cuellar, has been left on the sidelines.

The decline was triggered by the United States decision, in response to Iraq's aggression, to launch a huge build-up of naval forces in the Persian Gulf and the Mediterranean Sea and land and air forces in Saudi Arabia, and then to persuade Western allies and Iraq's regional adversaries to lend support. It appeared increasingly that the US was trying to wrest the initiative from the United Nations which did put up some resistance, particularly by challenging the moves of the United States to unilaterally blockade Iraq and Kuwait to enforce the sanctions.

Perez de Cuellar declared that only the United Nations, under article 42 of its Charter, could impose a blockade. The United States initially responded to Perez de Cuellar's declaration by claiming that the blockade was legitimised by Kuwait's right to self-defence under article 51 of the Charter. The Prime Minister parroted this view and was subsequently caught out by the revelation that he had committed our warships several days before receiving a request from Kuwait to do so.

The international community was not convinced by the US argument using article 51, so we saw a diplomatic campaign waged to secure UN endorsement of the blockade. After two weeks of that campaign and wrangling, resolution 665 was passed. It authorised countries deploying naval forces in the Gulf to board ships suspected of violating sanctions. The Security Council had been reduced to endorsing a fait accompli.

Had the United Nations been in charge, the blockade would have come under the command of its military staff committee, which comprises the military heads of the Security Council's five permanent members. Instead, the naval force remained essentially under United States control because international support for the blockade was ambiguous and also because the Bush Administration did not want any future offensive military action to be constrained in any way by United Nations control. Indeed, the official reasons given for the allied naval deployment to enforce the sanctions and the ground and air deployments which were to deter, we were told, a further Iraqi advance, were quickly revealed as smokescreens by the offensive size of a virtual invasion force and the structure of that force as it was deployed in the region and in Saudi Arabia in particular.

Resolution 665 left the UN being dragged along in the wake of the United States. The prospect of war began to be talked up. Here in Australia we had pages of war every day in our newspapers and items on the Cable News Network to see us through the night. The prospects for a resolution based on diplomacy and the most effective sanctions in world history were steadily played down, and those who advocated the sanctions strategy were branded appeasers. Inflammatory statements by Saddam Hussein and George Bush turned the conflict into a personalised macho stand-off. Iraq responded to the US-led build-up by boosting its force in Kuwait to defend the territory that it had wrongly seized, and the march to war gathered momentum.

United States dominance was firmly established by resolution 678 of 29 November last year which authorised nations to use `all necessary means' to drive Iraq from Kuwait after 15 January this year. Resolution 678 clearly demonstrated the UN's impotence. It left decisions on the timing of the war, its objectives and its strategies to the US and its allies. Its wording was ambiguous. There is no reference to the use of force and the term `all necessary means' allowed each UN member country to choose its own interpretation from continued reliance on sanctions, which is the interpretation that the Australian Democrats have called for all along the way, to an all-out military assault, which is the interpretation chosen by the United States and followed by our Government and others. But it is only an interpretation. Resolution 678 is not an exhortation to the use of military force and never has been.

The marginalisation of the Secretary-General's role is evident from leaked UN reports of his meeting with Saddam Hussein just before the war broke out. At that meeting Hussein stated his willingness to withdraw from Kuwait, but to do so in the face of the Bush Administration's war threat would involve a loss of face for him.

It has been argued that the Security Council has not been hijacked because it freely endorsed the United States moves against Iraq on the grounds that they were principled and necessary. While it is true that world opinion was freely expressed against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and in favour of sanctions, support for war rests on much more shaky foundations.

To begin with, China and the Soviet Union-two members of the Security Council which were under some pressure to veto the war push-had compelling self-interested reasons for not doing so. The Soviet Union's economic and political crisis has left it in dire need of Western aid. China is trying hard to restore its credentials with the West following the Tiananmen Square massacre.

Pressure was also applied to bring other nations into line. Yemen, a Security Council member and a critic of the Western military role, had its aid budget slashed by the United States. Jordan's aid allocation is, even now, under review following statements by its king sympathetic to Iraq. The Palestine Liberation Organisation has been excommunicated by Western nations for similar reasons. Egypt and Syria have received substantial political and economic favours for committing troops to the allied force.
