The fragility of the UN `consensus' is evident from the divisions which are opening up now as the carnage and destruction mount. Some countries are now under serious domestic pressure to reverse their stance and oppose the war-the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Pakistan and Egypt being the obvious examples.

The Bush Administration also attempted to stifle opposition by a strategy of pre-emption. United Nations support for the naval blockade and the war was sought only after-not before-the necessary military forces were in place. This ensured that the rejection of any proposals in the UN would have handed a major psychological victory to Iraq. The Secretary-General, Perez de Cuellar, according to those leaked reports of his meeting with Saddam Hussein, agreed with Hussein's opinion that the UN resolutions leading to war were virtually US resolutions. The evidence supports that view.

The credibility of the United Nations in this crisis has been further undermined by the yawning gulf between the massive international response to the invasion of Kuwait and the continuing inaction against acts of aggression and repression elsewhere. The Senate will recall a range of resolutions recently moved by me and my colleagues seeking concerted action supporting the UN in Tibet, East Timor, Eritrea, Cyprus, the Kurdish homeland, the Occupied Territories and on China's support for the Khmer Rouge. Each of these is as equally deserving of the UN's urgent attention as is Kuwait, yet there are few signs that the rhetoric of a new world order of peace, security and freedom will be applied in these cases.

Along with colleagues in the Rainbow Alliance I have put forward a proposed peace plan in order to look beyond the war and into the future. The proposal assumes a central role for the United Nations. As well as an immediate cease-fire, it calls for humanitarian aid to restore basic services in Iraq and Kuwait; the maintenance of sanctions on non-humanitarian trade; the negotiation of essential trust-building measures to prevent further accidental break-out; a UN peacekeeping force, which is obviously necessary, between the two sides; a phased withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and allied forces from Saudi Arabia and the Middle East waters; and an ongoing UN task force which would be required to establish an embargo on arms transfers throughout the Middle East, initiate a Middle East peace conference to deal with all the outstanding regional security questions, supervise a referendum in Kuwait on its political future and status, and set up what would need to be a large UN fund for post-war reconstruction and environmental rehabilitation.

Of course, a peace plan is on the international agenda right now-the so-called Soviet peace plan. I believe that peace plan has been too readily dismissed by President Bush and I call on Prime Minister Hawke to urge the United States to reconsider its position and, along with that, to respect the United Nations will and authority. As yet the United Nations has not spoken on the Soviet peace plan. I suggest that the Bush Administration's approach to the rejection of the peace plan at this point is further evidence of its aim to cripple Iraq economically, by destroying its industrial base, to wipe out its armed forces and to remove President Saddam Hussein from power.

This goes well beyond the United Nations' authorisation for the war which, even if we interpret that resolution as permitting war, has been complied with. The authorisation is merely to remove Iraq from Kuwait. Perez de Cuellar has previously said that the removal of Hussein is `not justified from the United Nations philosophical point of view'. To go beyond the UN objective is a disproportionate response to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, particularly when there is clear evidence that a negotiated outcome could be achieved. It is also in violation of humanitarian norms, compounding the suffering already caused by Iraq's brutal occupation of Kuwait. It is isolating the United States internationally, and this in time will rebound on Australia unless we take action.

The Soviet Union has now parted company with the United States on this question. China, which abstained on Security Council resolution 678 authorising war, is likely to be considering to do so now. India has just ended its token support for the US war operations after a political row which threatened to unseat its government. The UN Secretary-General and several European nations have expressed the hope that the Soviet plan will help resolve the crisis.

The international community, including the Australian Government, must prevail upon the United States to show respect for the will and authority of the United Nations, rather than using it selectively in the pursuit of purely national objectives. All of this is not to ignore the fact that there is an urgent need for the debate about the future operations of the United Nations to be under way. Reforming that body, democratising the Security Council and the General Assembly, are issues which should be on the table. Perhaps, without such changes, we are bound to repeat the tragedy which continues to deepen in the Middle East.

As my colleague Senator Bourne has already said in this debate, the Democrats will not oppose the Appropriation Bill, or even those parts of it related to the military aspects of the conflict in the Middle East, on the basis that throughout the debate we have always sought to separate our opposition to the political decision that has been made by this Government to take the war option in the Middle East, a decision with which we disagree on the basis of a different interpretation of the Security Council resolution 678. We have distinguished that political decision from the consequent military decisions.

We have never moved away from understanding that those people, who are sent to the Gulf in the course of their duty, must never be saddled with the responsibility of their political masters. Therefore, we understand the need for these appropriations in the interests of those people and, of course, we strongly support that aspect of these appropriations which support the sanctions. Hence, we will not be opposing this legislation while at the same time we continue to oppose strongly the political decision that has made necessary that part of it relating to the military.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never cease to be amazed by the convoluted thinking of the Australian Democrats when it comes to this particular issue. Not only am I amazed, but I might say that two-thirds of the Democrats own supporters are amazed by their thinking on this matter. I had quite a number of things to say on this particular matter but, as has been mentioned, we are restricting our speaking time to 10 minutes, so my speech will be very much curtailed as to the things that I wanted to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, I want to highlight some of the inconsistencies and absolute hypocrisy of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and its mates in the Australian Democrats on this particular issue. I listened with some amazement to Senator Powell talking about the United Nations (UN) and how it has been hijacked by the United States. From what I have heard about the present Democrats and the previous Democrats under Senator Chipp, who were quite different from this lot, I understood that they supported the UN organisation and they were very concerned to make sure that the United Nations' business and resolutions were supported.

It seems that the support for the United Nations is very selective. It is okay when the United Nations has issues on other matters but when those issues have an American influence, the Democrats become totally opposed to them. I simply cannot understand that. It seems that the Democrats say, `It is okay to support the United Nations resolutions on other things but when it comes to Kuwait, that is an entirely different thing. We no longer support the UN; we no longer support the UN's resolutions on Kuwait, but we want to support it on everything else'. What absolute hypocrisy. It is that type of convoluted jumping around on the issues that leads the Democrats further down from the days when they were a respectable Party under Senator Chipp.

When their leader, Senator Powell, makes a major speech on the Gulf war, it is interesting to see the number of Democrats' supporters in the gallery. This is where all of the Democrats supporters are; in this gallery. Not one bothers to come to hear the revered leader pontificate on the Gulf war. That is to be understood because two-thirds of the Democrats' supporters agree with the United Nations' action. The number of Democrats' supporters is falling every day-it is down to about 9 per cent-and will continue to decline while they follow the convoluted issues of the Democrats' regime. This used to be a respectable party under Senator Chipp.

From what Senator Powell said it seems to me that she is arguing that Hussein should be kept there after the war finishes. As I understood Senator Powell, she was saying that the United States should keep out of it. It is doing the wrong thing in trying to destroy Hussein and, after the war, he should be kept there to continue the genocide, to continue the absolute havoc that he has wreaked not only on his own country but on the Middle East generally. That is the type of proposition being put to us by the leader of the Australian Democrats.

I was also surprised to listen to Senator Coulter giving a list of problems in various countries throughout the world which he said had resulted from the Gulf war. I agree with him. It is very saddening. It is something that the world will seriously have to look at later. I ask Senator Coulter and his colleagues: can they not realise that their support for Hussein is the only thing that makes him continue? He cannot win this war. He knows that; everybody knows that. It is the peace groups around the world, the loony Left of the ALP, the fourth wing of the ALP and the Democrats, who are even loonier in their left wing stance, who are encouraging him to keep going. If the Democrats only had a solidified approach with the rest of the world, Hussein would realise that there is nothing to be gained by continuing the war. If the world took the unified approach, Hussein would realise that he cannot grandstand, that his grandstanding will count for nought and that he should end the war.

It is only people such as the Democrats who continue this war and they should be ashamed of that. I ask Senator Coulter, when he thinks about all the problems in the rest of the world, in the Third World countries, to consider that if there were a unified approach this war may well have been finished many weeks ago. Senator Coulter says that the reason for the war is oil. He says that it is not about freedom, invasion, democracy or human rights; it is about oil. I do not agree with him. Let us see the absolute hypocrisy of Senator Coulter and his mate. If we say: `Okay, let's forget about oil; in Australia we have many other forms of energy available, such as uranium and electricity, say from the Tully-Millstream dam', the Democrats will say, `You can't have that. It's clean, cheap energy, but you can't have electricity out of the Tully-Millstream dam'. Are you going to support that? I challenge you to support cheap hydroelectricity from the Tully-Millstream dam. Are you going to support this cheap, clean energy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Macdonald will address his remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I issue a challenge to the Democrats. I will pause, just after I issue the challenge, to ask whether they are going to support me when the Tully-Millstream hydroelectricity project comes up. It will provide clean, cheap fuel for Australia. I now pause, but I cannot hear the support I would have hoped for from the Democrats who berate the world over this war which they say is about oil. They keep on about the oil, yet when we ask about uranium, which is a clean, efficient fuel, where do they go?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bourne gave us a very interesting exposition on the Cypriot problem and the Turks. I ask Senator Bourne whether she is saying that we should get the United Nations to get a force led by the United States and invade Turkey. Is that what she is calling upon us to do? She was making these comparisons with Kuwait, asking why it did not happen in Turkey and Cyprus when it happened in Kuwait. Do I understand her to want us to get a US-led force to invade Cyprus? The sheer hypocrisy and convoluted thinking of the Democrats' proposals are absolutely amazing.

Senator Bell gave us a lecture on the Democrats' perverse view on the environment. He wanted to tell everybody of the scientific matters and kept using what must be the new Democrats' buzz words for this month-`pedestrian thinking'. Those seem to be the new buzz words: we are all pedestrian thinkers.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has his foot in his mouth.

—Exactly. Foot in the mouth-that is the Democrats' pedestrian thinking. If Senator Bell is concerned about the environment and what has happened as a result of the Gulf war, I ask him why he and his Party are the ones that have encouraged people such as Hussein to keep going.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lees also said that the war was all about protecting oil and it was critical. She went on to give us a lecture about the rural crisis, which is very important. I agree with many of the things she said, but the hypocrisy of this, again, is just too much to be contemplated. Senator Lees criticised this as being a war over oil. I do not agree with her. But, if she is right, she goes on to say that the Democrats are the farmers' friends. I ask Senator Lees to tell me who is hurting most from the price of oil when it goes up. It is the farmers that these people are supposed to be befriending. The Democrats criticise this war because they say it is about oil-I repeat that I do not agree with that-but then they try to protect the very people that increases in oil prices would hurt.

Senator Lees went on to criticise all and sundry about deregulation, how the rural industry was suffering because of free markets. But any time we want to deregulate the labour market and reform the waterfront industries, what do the Democrats do? They run over and support the left wing of the Labor Party and stop the real things that will help farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have sold out to the unions.

—Great farmers' friends they are! They have sold out to the unions, as has always been the case under the current regime of the Democrat leadership. Senator Lees then spoke about small business. Important though small business is, I had some difficulty in establishing what it has to do with an Appropriation Bill which extends money for the Gulf war.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the Bill, regrettable though it is. However, it is good to see that wheat farmers will now be paid for the money that was due to them, which Iraq reneged on. Unfortunately, I must curtail my speech, but I do want to say that the world will certainly have to look at greater aid contributions to many parts of the world when this conflict is over.
I am pleased to see that a number of Democrats have come into the chamber. I hope that some of them will answer some of the questions that I have raised and try to explain their hypocrisy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is too late to support Senator Powell.
—The number of people in the gallery has certainly increased since I started speaking.
—That is because you are so fascinating.

—Thank you, Senator Button. I have been called many things. `Fascinating' is one that I will add to my curriculum vitae. I thank him for the compliment. Even Senator Faulkner has stopped reading the newspaper. That is indeed a compliment and I thank him.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, I was privileged to be able to travel to South East Asia on a parliamentary delegation and, by coincidence, we were in Singapore when HMAS Success was there on its return from the Gulf. Captain Graham Sloper and his crew were very gratified by the support that this Parliament, with the exception of the Democrats, had given to him and his crew overseas. They did note this and it gave an enormous boost to their morale to know that the people of Australia generally were behind them.

I was terribly impressed with Captain Sloper and his crew and the efficiency on their ship and the attitude that they had to the duties they were called upon to perform. I might say in passing-this has not come to me from people from the Success-that I have heard that the ship that replaced the Success may not be as suitable for the role that it is being asked to perform as it could be. That disturbs me somewhat. I ask the Government to very seriously consider sending any ships, troops or military units into a war zone when they are not properly equipped to deal with it. Morale on the Success was excellent. I was told that the morale of the crew's colleagues on the other ships was very good and that they are grateful for the support given to them by the Australian people. I was very pleased to have had the opportunity of meeting that very professional group.

My time has almost run out and I can see the ire of our Whip. But I wish to add, briefly, a lighter note to the debate. When I visited the Success I was able to meet many of the lower deck crew as well. I had the opportunity of meeting a very special member of the crew by the name of Oscar. I had been corresponding with Oscar because, as many honourable senators will remember, before Christmas a note was pushed through our door asking us to write to sailors on the various ships and send them Christmas greetings. I wrote to two people and got replies from them. One was from Oscar. Oscar is a dummy. I suppose many of my colleagues would say that at last I have found my level in terms of parliamentary representation. I might say that Oscar had far more sensibility and seriousness about things than many Democrats do, even though he is a dummy.

Oscar leads a very exciting and very full life. Oscar is a sort of ship mascot. He is the dummy who is thrown overboard in rescue exercises. Indeed, Oscar is very well regarded because if he was not thrown overboard to be rescued, one of the sailors would have to perform that role. As a result, all of the sailors like Oscar a lot and they certainly support him.

Oscar often corresponds with the Captain on the ship. He writes the Captain lots of letters and he has become a sort of a folk hero on the boat. He is the sort of person whom I will enjoy continuing to correspond with in the years ahead. It certainly will be a relief to be able to write to a dummy rather than having to listen to the dummies on my left as they pontificate so hypocritically about the Gulf war.

I congratulate those in the Navy who initiated the program of asking parliamentarians and other people around Australia to write to the sailors in the Gulf fleet. It certainly is good for morale. It is the sort of thing that does help and which makes the Australian Navy the professional force that it is.

I close by indicating my support for the Bill, regrettable though the legislation is. I understand that the Bill will receive unanimous support. I congratulate all of the military people from Australia who are participating so well in Australia's efforts to get this madman Hussein back to reality.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation. This is in fact a preemptive strike. I am about to leave the chamber for a 11.30 appointment. I want to avoid the necessity to make a subsequent personal explanation in that I believe that some other speaker in this debate is likely to misrepresent the fact that I have left the chamber. I am not doing so because of what has been said by Senator Macdonald; I am doing so because I have an 11.30 appointment.
—Order! That is not a personal explanation, Senator Powell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented by the previous speaker, Senator Macdonald. The honourable senator said at one point in his speech that I had been calling for troops to be sent into Turkey. If he had listened to my speech last night, he would know that at no point did I say that. In fact, I said the very opposite. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, we would like to see economic and trade sanctions also applied against countries such as Turkey . . .
I invite Senator Macdonald to read the Hansard and find out exactly what I said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address issues that arise out of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91. We have been treated once again to a childish diatribe from Senator Macdonald. I shall not waste the Senate's time to respond in detail to the nonsense that he has been spouting. However, I wish to advert to one particular point. Senator Macdonald mentioned that our leader, Senator Janet Powell, addressed the chamber without being backed up by other members of the Australian Democrats team. I simply point out to him that it is not necessary for leaders of the Democrats to be concerned about their position. Democrat leaders do not have to cover their backs. We have better things to do. We believe that the Democrats are charged with a responsibility to represent those people that the old parties do not represent. We have a responsibility to deal with the issues that those parties choose to ignore. We believe that our time is better spent in substantive work rather than simply sitting here--
—You would be one to talk about old parties. You have been around a while.

—I used the expression `parties'. In turning to some of the issues of substance which are raised in this Bill, I wish to address basically three topics-sanctions, casualties and, specifically, the recent bunker bombing.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the dismissal of the sanctions strategy was an essential part of the justification for going to war against Iraq. However, the world's premier authorities on sanctions-three analysts from Georgetown University and the Institute for International Economics in the United States, namely Mr Kimberly Elliott, Gary Hufbauer and Jeffrey Schott- have made a convincing case that sanctions had a high probability of forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Their analysis was published first in the Washington Post and then in the International Herald Tribune of 11 December. I propose to quote extensively from their assessment. They say:

But sanctions can work, and in circumstances far less favourable than those present in the confrontation with Iraq. A review of 115 cases since 1914 shows that success was achieved 40 times when economic sanctions were threatened or imposed against individual countries. The current United Nations sanctions are among the strongest and most complete ever imposed against any country.
These comparisons strongly suggest that, given time, the UN economic boycott can achieve by peaceful means what President Bush and his advisers say can only be won by force.

. . . The current boycott covers virtually all of Iraq's trade; this is three to four times greater coverage than the average in all previous successful sanctions cases. Beyond that, Iraq, geographically isolated and dependent on oil for 90 per cent of its export revenue, is far more vulnerable to economic coercion than target states in other sanctions actions.

Because of all these factors, it is likely that if the embargo persists, Iraqi output will shrink by about half from its 1988 total of $45 billion. This is a decline of GNP 20 times greater than the average impact in other successful sanction episodes. Meanwhile, the economic costs to the sanctioning countries of suspended trade with Iraq are being addressed in unusual ways and substantially mitigated. These efforts give the current sanctions a cohesion and possible longevity never seen outside the setting of global conflicts.

Economic sanctions have been used in this century in pursuit of a wide variety of goals. They range from the relatively modest, such as Britain's 1933 sanctions against the Soviet Union to gain the release of British citizens accused of spying, to the difficult, such as the US sanctions against Poland from 1981 to 1987 to force the Communist regime to lift martial law and loosen political restraints.

In judging whether the imposition of sanctions was a `success' we looked for evidence of two things: that the boycotters substantially met their goals, and that sanctions contributed at least modestly to the outcome. Successful actions include, for example, the trade embargoes and financial sanctions to weaken the enemy's fighting capability used by the allies in World Wars I and II and by Britain and its allies during the Falklands conflict in 1982.

On two occasions in the 1920s, the mere threat of sanctions by the League of Nations was sufficient to settle border conflicts: Yugoslavia withdrew troops from disputed territory in Albania; Greece renounced territorial claims in Bulgaria. In the postwar era, the UN embargo of Rhodesia, much less stringently enforced than the present sanctions against Iraq, helped bring about the demise of the breakaway regime of Ian Smith.

Such examples argue strongly for the likely success of the sanctions against Iraq. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney has said that the embargo `clearly' has been effective `in closing off the flow of spare parts and military supplies.' And the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Colin Powell, conceded that sanctions would have `a debilitating effect' on Iraq's military capability. Last Thursday, the CIA director, William Webster, told the House Armed Services Committee that by next spring `Probably only energy-related and some military industries will be fully functioning.'

The sanctions against Iraq are unique in the history of such economic weapons in the 20th century. There is inevitably some leakage, but the embargo affects virtually all of Iraq's trade and financial relations. Historically, when the sanctioning country or group accounted for half or more of the targets trade, the sanctioners had a 50 percent chance of achieving their goals. In the average successful sanctions case, the boycotters accounted for 28 percent of the targets trade, far below the Iraqi situation.

This quotation clearly shows that the United States, and by implication our own government, should have considered much more carefully than they did the effectiveness of sanctions in this particular case rather than proceed to violent conflict, in which we are involved now, and which is showing casualties much higher than apparently expected by those who favoured the war-although why they thought that casualties of this magnitude would not happen is beyond me, bearing in mind the extensive ambit of the actions contemplated and the intensity of the attack mounted.

We have heard extensive reports of the level of Kuwaiti casualties resulting from Iraq's brutal occupation of Kuwait, and that must be on the table. Just recently, there have been more horrific descriptions given in testimony to a British parliamentary committee. These acts of torture and violence by Iraq in Kuwait have been taken as one of the major reasons for our sanctioning the military action taken by the United States and its allies. The level of casualties resulting from Iraq's occupation is difficult to estimate. Amnesty claims that hundreds of civilians were killed between 2 August 1990 and the end of the year. The Association for Free Kuwait estimates 7,000 dead and 17,000 missing or in detention. The Association has an obvious incentive to overstate its case, but there is no doubt that, whatever the number, unacceptable atrocities have occurred and are occurring.

Let us look at the other side. According to an Iranian report, Iraq now claims that 20,000 Iraqis have been killed, with up to 7,000 of these being civilians, and a further 60,000 have been injured. This seems a credible estimate, given today's allied claims to have destroyed 1,800 tanks, each with two or three personnel inside. Whatever the figure, it must be pointed out that civilians and young conscripts are by any definition innocent victims, and they comprise the bulk of the dead and injured. It seems reasonable to conclude that many more innocent Iraqis have died than Kuwaitis. This raises the obvious question: is this war a proportionate response to Iraq's initial crime of invading and occupying Kuwait? Should we not now take every opportunity to assess whether it can be stopped on the basis of Iraq's statements that it is ready to leave Kuwait?

I wish to advert briefly to the bunker bombing. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has questioned the accuracy of Iraqi casualty figures and appears to base his opinion on the notion that allied bombing has been so accurate as to largely spare civilians. But we have this example of the quite horrific bombing of the Baghdad air raid shelter last week which casts serious doubts on the Prime Minister's position. It is becoming quite clear that the United States has made an appalling error. Having initially claimed that it was a fortified, camouflaged command and control bunker with military personnel coming and going, its claims have been thoroughly rebutted by journalists on the ground. I quote Jacques-Marie Bourget, a correspondent for the magazine Paris-Match, who said:
Of all the journalists here, many with war experience, I haven't found one who can cast doubt on the fact that it was a civilian shelter . . . and that this was a mistake, a big mistake.
The article continued:
Bourget said local people he had questioned never had seen the military around the shelter.

The Iraqi civil defence was in charge of the facility and, ``for quite a long time, there have been arrows in streets pointing to the shelter'' . .``They didn't drive people into it with truncheons at night,'' he said. ``They went because they felt safe. It had 1,400 places. There were videos, and they showed films.
It had a convivial atmosphere. So it was normal that locals, particularly women and children . . . should have gone there (during raids).
He also said:
Not one of the bodies had a uniform. If there had been military people, I would think they'd have been killed like the rest.

These accounts cast serious doubts on the claims by the United States military that its activities have pinpoint accuracy and are directed at purely military targets. I am not suggesting it is intentionally putting civilian populations at risk. However, particularly now, this week, this House passed the Geneva Conventions legislation, drawing attention to the need to extend the protection to civilians. It was-to its shame-not supported by the Opposition, and I believe it behoves us to ask people with whom we are associated in this conflict what measures are being taken to protect the civilian population and reduce civilian casualties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) I would like to make a couple of comments on some of the previous speeches made here, particularly those from the Australian Democrats and the position they have adopted on this whole issue. I certainly fully endorse the comments of my colleague Senator MacDonald. I have to say to the Democrats that their activities are giving Hussein encouragement and in fact are encouraging him to continue. It will never cease to amaze me that they have adopted their stance on this issue, particularly when we go back to the early days when they opposed the blockade but now they are running with this line on sanctions. I think they are totally inconsistent.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that while Senator Spindler was speaking he had one supporter sitting alongside him: when his Leader spoke she had none. Does that mean that there is a leadership coup on the road? You have one supporter and she has none. I think it is a reasonable question to ask.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Crane, I ask you to address your remarks through the Chair.

—Certainly. Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I now go to the two main points I want to speak to on this portion of the Bill. First, there is the provision for the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) insurance payments following the non-payment for wheat as a result of the sanctions applied and now because of the war with Iraq. I note in this Bill there is an amount of $181.4m for payment now and $29.7m for payment in June. There are further claims for $247m in 1991-92 and $34m in 1992-93. These are just and fair payments, but one must remember they are not a government handout; they are a legitimate insurance claim.

SPEECH.PARA: The grain industry has been paying insurance premiums for years and this is the first payment under this EFIC arrangement. I put to Senator Button that he should acknowledge this point both to his colleagues and the general public because there is a perception out there that this is a handout to the grain industry, which it is not. If we look at the figures, we see that the wheat industry since 1983-84 has paid some $94m in insurance premiums--

TALK.START.PARA: —You should look at the exposure to a country like Egypt.

—I am not arguing about that. I am making the point that it is not a handout. My next point is the $123m that is not insured, which leads to a number of questions: does the Government believe the cost of the Iraq problems are to be borne by all Australians or, in this case, by the wheat industry? I believe this question in terms of that $123m is about justice and fair play.

SPEECH.PARA: I will quote from a Grains Council of Australia press release that was put out at the time by its President, Mr Inglis. It reads as follows:
`Australia's wheat growers back the Government's decision to support the UN sanctions,' said Mr Inglis.

`However, this is a decision taken by the Government in the national interest as a responsible member of the international community. It is therefore incumbent upon the Government to ensure that the nation as a whole shares responsibility for any consequences of the decision for Australia,' Mr Inglis continued.

The Government has identified the total outstanding wheat debt to Iraq at approximately $US485m ($A613m), comprising $US388m ($A490m) insured with the Government under export credit arrangements and $US97m ($A123m) uninsured, or in other words to the account of growers.
Wheat growers, as Australian taxpayers, are of course prepared to shoulder their fair share of the burden of any sanctions.
But, our concern is threefold. Firstly, that if the debt if repudiated the Government will impose on wheat growers the full cost of the $123m uninsured loss.
Secondly, the opportunity cost of re-selling the 350,000 tonnes remaining against this year's contract . . .

Thirdly, the potential for the Government to increase the premiums or reduce the level of cover on credit sales in response to its decision would amount to the industry's impeccable no-claim record being tarnished by a decision of the insurer.
We will not accept this approach.

I say: why should they? I have previously in this chamber asked questions of Senator Cook on this matter, and I have not received a satisfactory answer. I think it is incumbent upon the Government to give us an answer now. Is the Government going to pick this up or, because the decision was made in the national interest, will it be the taxpayers of this country? Alternatively, are the individual grain growers going to be left to carry the can? I think it is very important that that decision be made in terms of fair play in the sharing of costs. Of course, it does not end with the wheat industry; it goes into the chickpea and other industries. I particularly mention the chickpea industry here because it is a small and growing industry with a very bright future in the markets of the Middle East. But it would be unfortunate if it was inhibited in its development now because this cost was handed down to individual growers and they were forced into a situation where they could not continue.

The next point I raise coming out of this Appropriation Bill looks to the future. We have to look at the mechanisms by which Australia is going to rebuild its trade with the Middle East. It is worth noting that, prior to the Iraq crisis, Australia's trade with the Middle East was in excess of $1.5 billion in exports and $1.4 billion in imports. So the Middle East was a very important trading partner of Australia. Kuwait and Iraq have been important components of that.

I shall quote some figures to put a perspective on the importance of the Middle East to Australia. Ninety-three per cent of the total imports from the Middle East comes from the countries of Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Iran, Israel and the United Arab Emirates. On the exports side, 80 per cent of the total goes to those countries. In breaking these figures down a little, we find that 8 per cent of the total imports to Australia from the Middle East comes from Iraq and Kuwait and that 22 per cent of our exports to the region go to those two countries. If we add the figures for Saudi Arabia to those for Iraq and Kuwait we find that the import figure for those three countries jumps to 53 per cent of the total imports from the Middle East to Australia and 36 per cent of our total exports to the Middle East go to those three countries.

Let me take these figures a little further to emphasise the importance of the region to Australia. In terms of the export of wheat, 54 per cent of Australia's total export trade goes to the Middle East. In live animals it is 99 per cent of Australia's total export trade. Thirty-seven per cent of the total of our exported unmilled barley goes there. Looking at the other side of the equation, the import figure for petroleum and crude oils amounts to $0.7 billion and the figure for refined petroleum products amounts to half a billion dollars.
The point that I make in addressing this matter is that the Middle East is a very important part of Australia's trading spectrum. I seek leave to have these figures incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I throw down to the Government a challenge in relation to these figures. I ask: what strategy or plan does the Government have in terms of rebuilding this trade when the conflict is over? Will the Government convene a senior strategy group or some mechanism to coordinate Australia's trade position in the Middle East after the Gulf war? I put this to Senator Button in all seriousness because I believe that it is absolutely imperative that we start planning now for the rebuilding of this trade. It is very important not only to the individuals involved in the industry but also in terms of addressing our current account problems. It is quite clear to me, following the McKinsey report, that Austrade does not have this capacity, certainly not unless changes are made in that particular area.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, in the time remaining to me, I re-emphasise the two questions that I have asked. The first relates to the shortfall that is not covered by the insurance cover. I do not believe that it is the responsibility of those affected individuals to pick up that cost when the Government's position was supported by the grain industry and by the Opposition. Steps should be taken to overcome that particular injustice. The second point which I have just finished outlining is: do we have a strategy to rebuild our trade in the region when the Gulf conflict is finished?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) seeks to appropriate $234.1m from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to meet costs arising from Australia's response to the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on 2 August last year. Of that amount, $52.7m is to be allocated to the Department of Defence to meet additional equipment and stores expenditure arising from the deployment of Australian warships and personnel to the Middle East. A further $29.7m will be appropriated in Additional Estimates, which will bring the total extra expenditure to $82.4m. As has already been stated by other speakers from the Australian Democrats, we will be supporting this expenditure to make it clear that we distinguish between our opposition to the political decision to deploy Australian military forces to the Gulf on one hand and the need to support our forces now in the war zone on the other. It should be restated that the only circumstances under which we would support a decision to send warships to the Middle East is to enforce trade sanctions as part of a naval force under United Nations (UN) command. Those conditions have yet to be met.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that the real growth in the Defence budget from the last financial year to the present one was reduced from the one per cent allowed in the Forward Estimates to none in the actual Budget-a saving of $161m. The extra expenditure associated with the Gulf deployment will wipe out half of that saving. This Bill, once passed, will raise the total amount appropriated to Defence in 1990-91 to over $9 billion. That is about $530 for every woman, man and child in the country. It is the Democrats' contention that this Budget is both excessive and inadequate. It is excessive in that it throws huge quantities of money at weapons and operations which are of little relevance to the defence of Australia. It is inadequate in that our real defence needs are grossly underfunded.

Since the Hawke Government came to power, and particularly after the previous Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, took over the Defence portfolio, it became fashionable to assume that Australia's defence policy was undergoing a profound change. Gone were the days of forward defence, we were told, under which Australian forces were structured for an expeditionary role in support of a great and powerful friend. The era of defence self-reliance had arrived, where Australia would provide first and foremost for its own defence.

The deployment of Australian forces in the Middle East makes it blindingly clear that nothing really has changed. Once again, our major ally has launched a massive military assault in response to a dispute best settled by non-military means. Once again Australia has leapt into the fray, with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) offering our warships to serve as an arm of the United States (US) Navy, before being asked. The analogy with Vietnam, the costs of which are still being counted here, in the United States and particularly in Vietnam itself, is clear. So, too, are the differences, as this Government has been an pains to point out, but these differences may not be cause for comfort. There is no doubt that from the allied viewpoint desert warfare makes a far more likely military victory than did jungle warfare in Indo China. However, on the other hand, the political quagmire into which we are now sinking is much deeper and more dangerous. Vietnam did not rebound against the West across the Arab and Muslim worlds, as this war is now doing, and from which the thin veneer of United Nations respectability will not protect us.

How is it that, when the day of reckoning arrived, the Hawke Government blindly repeated the patterns of the past? Why is it that, after the 1986 Dibb report advocating defence self-reliance, the 1987 Defence White Paper announcing the policy of defence self-reliance, several parliamentary statements by Mr Beazley reporting on the progress of defence self-reliance and the publicity blitz which accompanied the Kangaroo `89 exercise-supposedly the first major test of defence self-reliance-all the rhetoric and action appear to have been thrown out of the window in our haste to out-Menzies the conservative governments of yesteryear?

The answer is that in reality defence self-reliance has always run a poor second to the strengthening and deepening of integrated operations with United States forces. The decision to trumpet self-reliance while playing down allied operations was politically motivated. The Hawke Government in the early 1980s was under pressure from a huge anti-nuclear movement, which found political expression through the Australian Democrats and briefly through the Nuclear Disarmament Party. That movement demanded an independent and nuclear-free defence posture. What it got was the veneer of defence self-reliance, while all along the defence of Australia has been neglected.

A great deal of attention was focused on the Prime Minister's decision to deploy naval forces to the Middle East, following the Bush administration's decision to send its forces to the region. However, by the time Mr Hawke had made his decision, Australia was already providing crucial support to US military operations automatically and without any decision taken by the Prime Minister. The United States-Australian bases at Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape had supplied vital intelligence, surveillance and communications to the Pentagon from the outset. Furthermore, the deployment of Australian frigates to the Gulf was virtually a foregone conclusion when one considers that our major warships regularly practise protecting United States aircraft carriers conducting offensive operations and are fitted out with equipment designed to maximise their ability to operate in that role.

Every two years some of our warships take part in the mid-Pacific RIMPAC naval exercises with the United States, Britain, Canada and Japan. In 1986 HMAS Darwin, one of our guided-missile frigates, took part. I have obtained a report of its activities, which describes in detail how the Darwin formed part of a US carrier battle group and performed various defensive and offensive tasks in that capacity. This is the reality of our defence policy. A large proportion of our military budget is spent not on defending the nation but on our traditional role as an arm of the forward projection forces of our allies. The vast majority of funds now being spent on big-ticket items such as submarines and frigates is dedicated to that outdated strategy. In the wake of the Gulf deployment, the Opposition and defence analysts are calling for an even greater emphasis on forward defence.

Meanwhile the defence of Australia against low-level threats is suffering from a lack of interest and resources. We lack the sort of medium-tech civil and military force which could provide protection against low-level threats and also perform useful peacetime tasks such as maritime zone protection, remote area firefighting and search and rescue. This current deployment to the Gulf makes it even less likely that these important priorities will be adequately resourced in the future. That is to the detriment of our national defence.

In this place previously, I have drawn the analogy between what is occurring in the funding of Australian defence forces by citing the fact that on the one hand we spend $9 billion on a relatively impotent, demoralised defence force in the roles that I have just outlined, yet at the same time our volunteer coastal patrols, our bushfire brigades and our volunteer State emergency services are funded by selling lamingtons on street corners. The realities of our defence expenditure must be drawn to the attention of the nation. Let us look at some of the realities.

We have purchased 75 F18 fighters at a cost of $45m each. I find it difficult to do that mathematics-75 times $45m each. I am told it will be nine years before those F18 fighters are all piloted and then it will be with inexperienced pilots. That is assuming there is no attrition of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) pilots. Of course attrition of RAAF pilots is one of the major problems that that service faces.

I have it on good advice that our high-tech and superb over-the-horizon Jindalee radar system-our eyes to the north; our surveillance of what is approaching us-will cost us an estimated $750m. I believe that, by the time it is commissioned five years from now, it will probably be nearer $1,000m or possibly $1,200m. Who knows? I am also advised that those eyes-the best eyes in the world-will be open only during office hours. In other words, personnel will be on duty eight hours a day. We have created the best eyes in the world and we choose to keep them open only during office hours because we cannot, out of our Defence budget, meet the inherent costs associated with using that surveillance to its maximum effect.

These are inherent contradictions present circumstances in our Defence budget under even normal circumstances. However, to commit ourselves to a military option that will not be a solution to the Gulf crisis when other options were in place and were in fact proving to be effective, is simply to commit our military resources to an exercise which is inhuman, inappropriate and without logic and which will probably have a totally negative outcome for decades to come.

The Australian Democrats are simply attempting to draw to the attention of the Australian people that these contradictions simply fly in the face of logic and contravene any rational policy to truly defend Australia. We advocate that Australia should pursue a vigorous, viable, well-equipped, appropriately roled and tasked defence force and that the developments of the past month are simply clear evidence of the fact that the Hawke Government is enunciating one defence policy and pursuing another and that these inherent contradictions and stupidities of the way in which we are expending our defence dollars must be drawn to the attention of the Australian people. This Appropriation Bill which, as I said, directs $234.1m from the Consolidated Revenue of the Australian people is peanuts alongside the tens of billions of dollars that the American Congress is now appropriating to this war which, in military terms alone -who knows what it is in reality-is often estimated to be $1 billion or $1,000m a day.

I suppose we can consider ourselves blessed to be appropriating only $234.1m from our Consolidated Revenue. The Australian Democrats will support this appropriation, not because we support a military solution or believe that in any way it will resolve the crises of this part of the world, but because we accept the fact that once Australian troops are committed to any role they have to be supported financially.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91 and would like to make a few remarks about the manner in which Australia's participation in the Gulf has been handled by elements of the media and some media personalities. I was disappointed initially by the selective indignation that some people were expressing in the media, people such as Peter Smark in the Sydney Morning Herald and the Age. This selective indignation drew everyone's attention to the fact that war was terrible and that we were nonetheless participating in it, but without, of course, being equally indignant about what Saddam Hussein was doing in Kuwait, had done in the past in Iran, and showed every indication of wishing to continue in the future in terms of expansionism in the Gulf area.

SPEECH.PARA: That selective indignation was, I believe, bad enough and dishonourable enough. But what I now find to be absolutely intolerable is the selective compassion that we are hearing in this chamber from the left hand corner-and I use the word left in every sense, coming from the Democrats-for the civilians in Iraq who unfortunately have been killed in this confrontation. This selective compassion comes from many elements of the media for the people in Iraq.

I quote as an example the otherwise marvellously successful concert in the park in Sydney where the Sydney Symphony Orchestra performed in the Domain. The compere was Mr Andrew Denton, a television `personality' on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. As a compere he did a very good job and was most entertaining, except that at the end he drew to the audience's attention the fact that while we were having a great time innocent civilians in Iraq were being bombed by the Americans.

He did not find it possible to say that at the same time innocent civilians in Israel were being targeted by Saddam Hussein, or that innocent civilians in Saudi Arabia were being targeted by Saddam Hussein. But, of course, he did draw to everyone's attention the fact that innocent civilians were being killed-the inference being as targets-in Iraq when, in fact, any killing of civilians in Iraq has not been because they were targeted. On the contrary, despite the fact that the Americans and allied forces have been targeting what they firmly believe to be military targets, any civilian deaths are incidental to and unfortunate consequences of that targeting of military installations.

Quite frankly, I am sick and tired of this selective compassion; I am sick and tired of the nonsense we keep hearing. We have just heard it from Senator Spindler-once again, selective compassion. I believe it is disgraceful that people like Senator Spindler come into this chamber, with their one-eyed, closed mind approach. It is quite proper that people like Senator Macdonald are not only irritated but also angered by this disgraceful and, intellectually, totally dishonest behaviour.

On the question of intellectually dishonest behaviour, this Bill, being a wide ranging finance Bill, gives me the opportunity to talk about some other monumentally intellectually dishonest behaviour on another major, but far less significant, issue; that is, the question of sporting links with and other sanctions against South Africa. I draw the Senate's attention to an incredibly dishonest political stunt which is being pulled at the moment by this Government on the question of whether or not there should be an early lifting of the South African sports boycott.

Ever since the weekend conference in London we have been hearing a whole host of prime ministerial statements indicating how quickly we will be resuming sporting links with South Africa. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in a doorstop on Sunday-he received some publicity for it-said:

. . . as a result of that meeting in London . . . where there is an integration of sport within South Africa . . . then there will be no reason why sporting contacts cannot be initiated . . . these processes can proceed straight away.

I say that that is 100 per cent bunkum and the Prime Minister, if he did not know it was bunkum at the time, should have known. It is a disgrace that the Prime Minister should make statements like that when the reality is exactly the opposite.

Yesterday the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) eventually stopped misleading this place on this matter. He admitted, in reply to a question I asked, that the communique from the Foreign Ministers meeting in London at the weekend called only for unified sports to be recognised by the international community, not for their boycotts to be lifted. There is not one sentence in that communique which indicates, let alone states, that the boycotts are to be lifted in any kind of early time frame; in fact, exactly the opposite is indicated.

Senator Evans admitted that the working out of the principles for the lifting of the boycotts `will take some time'. He also admitted that the communique said that Commonwealth countries would continue to be guided in this respect by the views of the non-racial sporting bodies which, of course-I am not putting any value judgment on this-just happen to be African National Congress (ANC) dominated. Senator Gareth Evans eventually admitted that the process of moving from `recognition' of unified sporting bodies to the point of actually having sporting contacts is `something else again'. It certainly is something else again and so is his and the Prime Minister's performance on this matter. It certainly bears no relation to the truth; their behaviour is something else again.

Senator Gareth Evans conceded that there is to be consultation with the ANC and other bodies before there is any actual implementation of international sporting contact and that the London decision is such that the ANC agrees with it. I remind the Senate that the ANC still totally opposes ending the sports boycott. Here we have a situation where the ANC totally agrees with the London decision and, on the other hand, it totally opposes the early removal of sporting boycotts until its political agenda is met. We were told that only last week by Mr George, the President of the National Olympic and Sports Congress of South Africa, which is ANC controlled. Of course, Mr George is an executive of the ANC.

I am not saying whether it is right or wrong that the ANC should control this, or whether that should be the ANC's view. The ANC obviously has strong arguments as to why that is its view. What concerns me is that if the ANC is committed to the view that it is far too soon to remove the sporting boycott, if the ANC is determined that it will not be removed until various political agendas are met-to quote Mr George `it will be a long process'-and if the ANC has agreed, as Senator Evans admitted yesterday, with the London decision, how is it possible that that London decision can also allow Mr Hawke to say that there is no reason why sporting contacts cannot be initiated simply after sports become integrated, like cricket, which is on the way now? It should be only a matter of months before cricket is an integrated sport.

Obviously, someone is telling fibs; someone is simply not telling the truth. Who is that someone? Is it Mr Hawke, who says that there is no reason why sporting contacts cannot be initiated and the process proceed straight away, following the London meeting? Is the official communique false? Is it Mr Joe Clark, the Canadian Foreign Minister, who has a totally different view to that of Senator Evans of what the decision really was. There is no doubt in my mind that the London decision leaves the matter of resuming sporting links with South Africa basically up to the ANC because it requires the ANC to be consulted. In other words, the unified sports body is to be consulted in any further developments on removing sporting links.

I also remind the Senate that the sporting boycott has been distinguished, totally taken out of the general question of sanctions. The lifting of sanctions is to be discussed at a meeting in New Delhi after the end of April, presumably in May. If that is the case, it is clear that the sporting boycott is not to be discussed in May, despite the misleading attempts by Senator Evans to suggest that it will. It is not to be discussed in May-that is purely the sanctions element. In fact, the next Heads of Government Meeting will be held in Harare in November of this year. On the face of the communique, that will be the first opportunity for there to be a further meeting on the question of removing the sporting boycotts.

Frankly, I am sick and tired of this stunt being run by the Government where we have two possible scenarios: either Mr Hawke is being the good cop and Senator Evans the bad cop all the time or Senator Evans, as Foreign Minister, is simply not doing what Mr Hawke wants him to do. In other words, Mr Hawke is being continually rolled by his Minister for Foreign Affairs.

The reason I say this is simple. Mr Hawke keeps on trying to attract the support of those people who want to see sporting links resumed. After all, the Gleneagles Agreement requirements will have been met by the time the present legislative changes announced by President De Klerk are completed in this session of the South African Parliament. Mr Hawke is appealing to those Australians-and I believe it is the great majority of Australians-who believe that it is now time to provide an incentive to the South African Government, a reward if you like, by resuming sporting links. After all, there is no better way of revealing the benefits of removal of apartheid at the grassroots than seeing how well people can combine on a sporting field so that their race, religion or anything else is ignored.

In fact, a senior member of the ANC executive strongly promotes the view that it would be wonderful for sport to be a part of this move towards getting rid of apartheid so that South Africans could shout together for their united teams and we could see people of all colours and creeds on sporting fields playing sport together. Apart from that, it is vital politically that the far right, the ultraconservatives, in South Africa who still resist the trend away from apartheid should be shown that there are rewards for decency, that there are rewards for pressing on with the removal of apartheid, and that those rewards are not simply all talk, but are reality.

At the moment we keep changing the goal posts. The South Africans achieve something and we keep saying, `No, no, you have got to achieve something else before we'll recognise South African sport as being capable of participating in world competition'. We keep saying, `No, no, you have got to do something else'. It concerns me that the ANC, quite sensibly, keeps saying that there are a lot of other objectives, including political objectives, other than the Gleneagles Agreement to be met before sport should be resumed. The Government has locked itself into that pro-ANC position and I believe that it is wrong to do so.

There are plenty of other organisations in South Africa who are anti-apartheid. There are plenty of coloured people who do not support the ANC. There are seven million Zulus who, overwhelmingly, do not support the ANC. The Inkatha movement is much more rational, in my view, in its approach. We have the Prime Minister seeking to appeal to that large section of the Australian society that wants to resume sporting links-on very sound grounds, I believe-while the Foreign Minister keeps on saying, `We are close to and will be guided by what the ANC says'.

When Mr Hawke made all those whacko, you-beaut statements last Sunday night, which were reported in Australia, about how quickly we should be playing sport with South Africa, the journalists reporting them did not have access to the communique from London. They did not have the actual document which showed that what Mr Hawke was saying was bunkum. I guess one of the problems in the media is that once someone sets off down one track saying, `It is going to be soon. Isn't everything wonderful?' it is a bit hard to change course. It has intrigued me that the bulk of the Australian media-having now seen the communique and having heard Senator Evans's response yesterday-still will not in fact reveal the truth. I am appalled at the level of journalistic response. Now that the facts are there the media are still leaving on the record, unchallenged, the hoax over sporting ties that the Prime Minister has perpetrated on the Australian people.

Of course, it may be that this Government intends to dump the ANC, to ignore the instructions which were given to it only last week by Mr George. Maybe this Government is going to say, `No, we will not be bound by the ANC's opposition to sporting links. We will, in fact, resume them'. If that is so that is a major change of policy and I am unaware of it. I believe that if that is the basis on which the Prime Minister is making these statements-after all it seems to be the only basis on which he could be making them-then I think the Prime Minister or the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has got to say that, that we will in fact not necessarily be bound or guided by the ANC's statements. It has got to be one or the other. Either we are going to have an early resumption of sporting links despite the ANC or we are not because of the ANC. They cannot have it both ways. Of course, this is simply a replay of the same stunt that took place last October. Once again, I do not know whether last October's stunt was because the Prime Minister was playing the good cop to Senator Evans's bad cop or whether Senator Evans was simply rolling the Prime Minister once again on this issue.

Honourable senators will remember last October, the week before Mr Mandela came to Australia, Mr Hawke in Darwin said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio, I think it was, that he would look forward to a resumption of sporting links with South Africa as soon as was reasonable and gave a clear indication that `reasonable' meant pretty soon. Then Mr Mandela came and gave a lunchtime speech in the Great Hall-Madam Acting Deputy President, I think you remember it-in which he said, `No, no, there should be no early resumption of sporting links. There are a whole lot of political objectives to be reached before that can take place'. Lo and behold later that week what did Senator Evans say? Exactly the same thing: `No, there will be no early resumption of sporting links'. Good cop, bad cop, political stunt-Mr Hawke is trying to appear as the champion of sporting links while his Government continues with its policy of total subservience to the ANC and its policy of no early resumption of sporting links.

I find it extraordinary that Mr Hawke has been allowed to get away with this by the media. Only a few talkback radio stations-and thank heavens that talkback radio exists in Australia-have been prepared to question Mr Hawke's and Senator Evans's statements on this matter. I single out in particular John Tingle on 2GB in Sydney, to whom of course, with many other members of the media, I faxed the details of Senator Evans's responses. I faxed the details of the communique and they have been prepared to say, `Yes, what is going on?'.

I believe this Government has a responsibility to do something serious, not to engage in the sort of petulant nonsense that Senator Evans tried yesterday when he even put on the Notice Paper an objection to my having challenged what is clearly an indefensible set of statements by the Prime Minister and by Senator Evans. That was of course withdrawn this morning, but it is a measure of the sort of web, if you like, of deception being drawn by this Government over this issue that Senator Evans thought it was clever or smart to propose a motion that I be criticised for having raised this matter.

It seems to me that unless the Government comes clean pretty shortly on this issue the Australian public has as much right now to be as cynical as it was last October when the Government pulled the same stunt. I want, and I think the people of Australia want, Mr Hawke either to apologise for the nonsense he has spread around about early resumption of sporting links or else to say how the lifting of this boycott will be achieved. How does the Government intend doing so? Does it intend doing so unilaterally without the support of the Commonwealth and, if so, how is that going to happen-if it is going to require the support of the Commonwealth-before November? That is when the next meeting of the Commonwealth at which this can be dealt with is scheduled for. Alternatively, is the Government going to do it despite the ANC's opposition or does it have some other trick up its sleeve?

On the face of it at the moment, the Government's policy, its commitment, to the ANC position and its continued rhetoric indicate that it is locked into a situation where there cannot be an early resumption of sporting links with South Africa no matter how sensible or rational it may be, and no matter how often the Prime Minister says, in the face of all the facts, that it is going to happen.

This kind of government by deception is not unusual. It has been happening continually on a whole range of issues. What annoys me is the way the media in Australia, by and large, keep allowing the Government to get away with it, and when we in the Opposition point out this deception and this dishonesty we are totally ignored. I beg your pardon: the Age newspaper did the other day run a couple of paragraphs relating to my objection. But, by and large, the media have sat idle in the face of the facts and reported absolute nonsense with headings such as `PM Tips Early Move For Sanctions'. The image creation process is going on unrestrained by an alert media and that image creation process is a phoney-just like this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said by most of the previous speakers here today, we are speaking on a Bill to allow the appropriation of $234.1m to meet defence costs and various insurance claims associated with the default by Iraq on credit sales of wheat by the Australian Wheat Board. There is no doubt that at some time in the future we will be called upon to allocate more funds to support our presence in the Gulf and, if one can take notice of the media, we are now approaching a new phase of the war which will be not only expensive in financial terms, but also expensive in human lives. It is a great pity that the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein-who we know has no respect for human life, including his own people-has failed to see the writing on the wall. His contempt for humanity is well documented and we all know of his human rights abuses.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's commitment to the Gulf war, while it may seem significant to us, is only a token compared to a lot of countries participating. Madam Acting Deputy President, you can be assured, of course, that it is not a token representation for the families of our personnel serving there, who of course would find this event most traumatic. For our service men and women, separation from their loved ones must also be heart-rending to say the least.

Of course, it is not the first time that our service men and women have fought in the Middle East and surrounding areas. Two world wars where Australians have fought with honour alongside their allies remind us of the tremendous tradition that our armed forces have earned. Our forces in the Gulf now are no different from those that have gone before them. They too are a credit to our nation. What a pity it was that only last week or so the Government tried to charge admission to our magnificent War Memorial-a memorial for all Australians to remind themselves of those Australians who over the decades made a supreme sacrifice to ensure that this nation remained free from tyranny similar to the sort of tyranny that Saddam Hussein is inflicting upon the people of Kuwait.

To me, the most fascinating part of the Gulf war is the space-age technology being used. The highly sophisticated nature of weaponry is mind-boggling: smart bombs, Scud missiles, Patriot missiles and cruise missiles, just to name a few. What hope would we as a nation have if that type of weaponry were used against us? Sure, we have some sophistication, as much as we can afford, but for our defence we rely on our allies and our friends, just as Kuwait is relying on the United Nations coalition to help it.

The new world order that is much talked about by President Bush and Mr Hawke is now a fact of life. The last time our troops were in the Middle East they fought against Germans, Syrians and Vichy French. Today, of course, those particular nations are on our side along with some 24 others. Not only do we have a moral commitment to defeat the aggression of Saddam Hussein, but we would expect the United Nations to come to our defence if it were ever needed-and let us hope it is not.

As Senator MacGibbon said earlier in the debate, we cannot just rely on our Jindalee radar system or our F111s or our F18s. We certainly are not overburdened with sophisticated weaponry and, as I said before, we are relying on regular army troops to man RBS70 surface to air missile systems aboard supply ships HMAS Success and HMAS Westralia to provide for their anti-air defence. This just shows how under-resourced our armed forces are.

The armed forces are not the only ones in financial difficulties at this point in time. As my colleague Senator Panizza said yesterday, the wheat issue is fast approaching a crisis. The appropriation in this legislation for defaulted payments is only a grain in the silos, so to speak, compared with what our grain growers will need to survive in the future.

Whilst we have a crisis in the Gulf, a crisis in the wheat industry and a crisis in the wool industry, we have the ongoing crisis of the Federal Government's economic mismanagement of this country. The economic mess this country is in has been swept aside to some extent by the events in the Gulf. The war has also shored up the personal approval rating of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I suspect it saved him from being unseated as leader by Mr Keating. I guess all this will change when Australians come to realise where our economy is heading.

Whilst we on this side of House have no doubt about where the economy is heading, the Government seems to have lost direction and also lost touch with the community. In March of 1990, and again in December of 1990, Mr Hawke repeated his claims that there was no need for people to fear the consequences of a recession. Now his story has changed. On Tuesday of last week in answer to a question from Dr Hewson, he acknowledged `that many people around this country have suffered pain'. Unfortunately, what Mr Hawke was not prepared to acknowledge was the level of pain which his Government has inflicted upon our country.

The Government has sought to diffuse the issue by blaming our dire economic situation upon external circumstances beyond its control, and no doubt further down the track when we have more and more serious balance of payments problems it will be blaming the expenditure on the Gulf war. However, the fact remains that it is the Government and, as a consequence, it is responsible. On 11 March 1990, Mr Keating told the Sunday Age:
Before 1985 Australia was run by the bureaucracy. This Government runs the whole outfit. I run economic policy and the Government.

What a mess he has made of it. If Mr Keating is so keen to acknowledge his responsibility for economic policy, then he should be strong enough to accept the consequences of his actions. Despite the repeated assurances by Mr Keating that there would not be a recession, he has ultimately been forced to accept the obvious and now both he and Mr Hawke attempt to delude us all into believing that they have the answers.

It is unfortunate for many, especially those associated with small business, that any answers at all will be coming too late. The dramatic increase in small business bankruptcies indicated by the December 1990 quarter figures clearly shows that the recession inducing policies instigated by the Labor Government have brought about an unprecedented decline in the small business sector. It is a decline from which Mr Hawke is not even prepared to admit we have bottomed out.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to reports of the Gorbachev peace initiative and ask: was the Australian Government consulted about this initiative? Is the Government aware of the contents of the Gorbachev proposal and does the Government support the rejection of this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has received a letter from President Bush concerning the Soviet proposal which was put to the Iraqi Foreign Minister on Monday. That letter outlined both the content of the proposal and the United States view of it. I do not propose to go into the details of the proposal. The Soviet has asked that details not be made public. The United States has respected that and so will we. Clearly, at this very delicate stage, it would not be helpful to canvass the issues in detail. President Bush has not said that he has rejected the proposal; rather, he has said publicly that the Soviet proposal falls well short of what would be required to bring the war to an end and he communicates that view also in the letter to Prime Minister Hawke.

ANSWER.PARA: Having looked carefully at the Soviet proposal, the Prime Minister and I certainly understand President Bush's concerns. It is clear that as the proposal stands-and it may be that it is amenable to modification-there are some elements of it which do pose real and practical problems for ending the conflict in accordance with United Nations (UN) resolutions. Equally, it is very clear from President Bush's letter that the United States, like Australia, does continue to seek a peaceful end to the crisis in accordance with UN resolutions, if that is at all possible. Obviously, no cease-fire proposals could be accepted which did not include specific and concrete steps for their implementation. That, I guess, is the crucial element that is necessary in any viable proposal that may now emerge.

I should say that there has been a great deal of speculation, particularly in this morning's media, that there is a gap between the United States' publicly stated war aims, which are in accordance with the UN resolutions and involve the liberation of Kuwait and the so-called actual war aims, which are said to extend to the removal of Saddam Hussein and the further destruction of the Iraqi military.

I want to say very clearly on behalf of the Australian Government that, in our judgment, it is very clear that the United States war aims continue to be as publicly spelt out and articulated by President Bush throughout the crisis, namely those specifically mandated by the UN resolutions to ensure the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait and, of course, the restoration of the legitimate government of Kuwait. I believe that there is no doubt whatever that the coalition, the United States and its other partners, would respond to an immediate and unconditional Iraqi withdrawal. The Iraqis unwillingness to undertake such a withdrawal remains the single obstacle to peace in the Gulf. We can only, again, urge Iraq to fulfil the demands of the UN resolutions. The ball remains at Iraq's feet, as it has been ever since it embarked on its current course of destruction and self-destruction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister said that it may be that the proposals are amenable to modification. Does that indicate the possibility now of some negotiating phase, and is Australia supportive of such action?

—No, I am not talking about any negotiation exercise. I am talking about some conceivable willingness on the part of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to rethink and perhaps further refine and develop some aspects of its proposal. I do not think it would be appropriate for anyone to embark, at this stage, on any course of negotiation so far as this is concerned. It is a matter, essentially, of simply, as I say, getting Iraq to unilaterally, unconditionally, unequivocally and immediately withdraw from Kuwait.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of criticisms of the Federal Government's new `deeming' rules for pensioners by the Brisbane Lord Mayor, Alderman Atkinson, in today's Brisbane Sun? What is the Minister's response to the Lord Mayor's claim that pensioners would be `bled dry' of their concessions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
