TALK.START.PARA: —During the time it took for Senator Colston to ask the question, I noted that Senator Panizza was seeking to interject to the effect that the criticism by Alderman Sallyanne Atkinson was okay. In fact, if he were to take the time to look at the newspaper article in question, he would see that first off Alderman Sallyanne Atkinson referred to `deeming' as a tax. All the honourable senators who voted for this-and I would remind Senator Panizza and his colleagues that he and they were among them-would know that it was not a tax.
—You will have to do better than this if you want to get votes for Labor in the Brisbane City Council election.

—We will handle this, Senator Macdonald. I would have thought that if Alderman Sallyanne Atkinson wants to be so miserable as to pinch pensioners' money just because of deeming, she will suffer an enormous electoral backlash. What happens in the Brisbane City Council area is that a 40 per cent rate concession is offered to maximum rate pensioners. This occurs in a number of Queensland councils. It is pretty well isolated to Queensland because councils around Australia when offering pensioners concessions offer them on the basis of the production of a pensioner health benefit card, which does not mean that a pensioner is on a maximum rate pension.

ANSWER.PARA: Far from any pensioner having to be bled dry, as she put it in that article, the Commonwealth protected the position of each and every pensioner who had fringe benefits and said that if they were to be affected by deeming they would not lose those fringe benefits. It would not cost the Brisbane City Council one penny to protect those pensioners who live within its boundaries from this action. The ones there are already on a concession. All that needs to be done is for that concession to be continued.

I would have thought that not just in the Brisbane City Council area but in any council area in Queensland councillors, especially those who are facing election, would want to have a long, hard think about how clever it was of them to rob pensioners. The reality is that quite a number of councils in Queensland have reconsidered the matter and are looking at the production of a pensioner health benefit card just for the purpose of looking at those concessions. If the Brisbane City Council does not do that, if it is miserable enough to put its hands into pensioners' pockets in that way, one wonders how goes the Liberal philosophy of self-reliance. If Opposition senators do believe in self-reliance, maybe they should have a word with Sallyanne Atkinson because I, too, am absolutely outraged that anyone could accuse the Commonwealth which deliberately built into the deeming laws-and those opposite voted for them-that same protection for pensioners. Why cannot they do that now? It is another example of Liberals picking on the poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree with his colleague Senator Cook that the $12 a week pay rise will have no impact at all on unemployment?
—I have not seen the precise quotation from Senator Cook and therefore I am not in a position to comment.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister whether he will consult his colleague Senator Cook to confirm the veracity of the quote that I have given. I also ask him, in further considering the question: if he agrees with Senator Cook, why is it that his colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training is advocating increases in wage subsidies to employers which are specifically designed to reduce labour costs in the interests of saving jobs?

—Nothing has been announced by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, so Senator Chapman is dealing in speculation again. As far as the $12 wage increase is concerned, without knowing what Senator Cook said-and if Senator Chapman wants to find an exciting difference between us, or a difference in emphasis between us, here is his chance-I will chance my arm and say that I do not think that would have any effect on employment in the current circumstances.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Hungary led by the Deputy Speaker of the National Assembly, Dr Dornbach. I point out that this is the first parliamentary delegation from Hungary following the historic free elections. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and I trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Did the Minister see the feature article in yesterday's Age newspaper headlined, `Germany's Secrets of Success'? Did the article note that Germans worked shorter hours, had longer holidays and got more pay than Australians while living in one of the most successful industrial economies?
—That is your recipe for recovery, is it? It sounds good.
—It was Senator Alston's question a few days ago which provoked this.
—Order! Senator Crowley, ignore the interjections.
—Thank you, Mr President. What particular industrial relations features have contributed to this and, if they are relevant to Australia, what are we going to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I saw the article and it is a welcome reminder that if we work more smartly we can enjoy a growth economy while at the same time ensuring that ordinary working men and women enjoy the advantages of that economy.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the second part of Senator Crowley's question, the article said that workers in Germany enjoy six weeks annual leave and work on average a 38-hour week, which includes their lunch breaks; that metalwork tradesmen, at a minimum, are on a salary of $32,000 but most get much more; and that if workers lose their jobs in that country they are entitled to two-thirds of their annual salary for a year and go through compulsory retraining. It also says that, comparing Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development figures from 1985 to 1990, prices rose by only 7.1 per cent in that country while real wages rose by 16.7 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about their output.

—I hear the interjection, `Tell us about their output'. Their output shows a dramatic growth in export production and output per head. The point is that they work more smartly in that country than some managers in this country are prepared to enable their work forces to work. It also means that high levels of worker remuneration and working conditions are not inconsistent with a highly productive economy.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the third question that Senator Crowley asked. I think it ought to be said that we cannot automatically transfer from one country a set of conditions that apply there to another country because, obviously, there is a different cultural milieu, a different economic setting and so on. What we can do is look at what applies in one country, distinguish the principles that make its application in that country effective, and see whether we can transfer those principles to give effect to them in Australia in an Australian way. I also should say that we cannot isolate industrial relations from the whole because, clearly, in Germany there is a big commitment to education and training, a huge investment in research and development, and a very tight monetary policy, and the role of government there is quite important.

The article identified that worker participation and codetermination are two critical factors in leading to a more harmonious working environment and a very low, if not infinitesimal, level of disputes in Germany. There is a sense of shared objectives between workers and management because of that. That is not something that applies in Australia. The article also identifies that in a country with a high union membership-43 per cent of German workers are members of unions-there are only 17 unions, and that executive remuneration in that country travelled at the same increase levels as worker remuneration, unlike some other western countries, and unlike Australia I might say.

What are we doing about it? Through award restructuring and workplace reform, we are trying to engineer, with the assistance of some enlightened employers and many unions, the same type of internal enterprise-based harmony and codetermination that applies in Germany--
Senator Kemp interjecting -

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the accord mark VI with the Australian trade union movement, is the basis for that. The blueprint is laid out there. Senator Kemp should read it for a change, rather than criticise it. Last year we put through legislation to encourage the amalgamation of unions.

ANSWER.PARA: On executive salaries-I have maintained a continual criticism of Australian executives who take wage rises well above those of ordinary workers. I will continue to do so. I believe that the trend still shows that some grasping executives are taking wage levels, even in a recession, well above those to which ordinary workers are entitled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the timing of the announcement of the proposed Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) watchdog simply a pay back for the national broadcaster's perceived reluctance to act as the Government's media liaison office during the Gulf war crisis? What is the hurry? Why can such drastic legislative surgery not be deferred until the Government reveals its total review of the broadcasting legislation and we all have the chance to debate the finer details? Could this rush and the timing of the announcement be tied in any way to the pending Government decision on the ABC's triennial funding as well as senior appointments to the Corporation's board?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. The establishment of what Minister Beazley is talking about is simply in accord, I might say in terms of the allegation of knee-jerk reactions, with something equally as significant which is going on currently in the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT). The ABT is concurrently conducting an inquiry into--
—Why are you smiling?

—I was smiling because I was thinking of how glad I am that I am not chairing this inquiry into the accuracy, fairness and impartiality of current affairs broadcasting in Australia. I am very grateful I am not chairing it.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter is one simply of legitimate public interest. I think that all honourable senators would agree with that, if the debate in here yesterday on the same matter is anything to go by. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation is our broadcasting corporation. It is the national broadcaster. Because of that, this Parliament has a very legitimate interest, as I have said in this chamber on many occasions, in maintaining what I think is essential, that is, that vital principle of allowing the ABC to make its own decisions in terms of broadcasting.

In respect of bias-I thought that Senator Cooney put it very succinctly yesterday in a speech that I thought was worthy of Abraham Lincoln: bias is often bias in terms of criticising bias and that is usually the problem. People see bias in the ABC on the particular bias it has on the particular issue--

TALK.START.PARA: —What bias did Mr Hawke see?

—That applies to the Prime Minister as much as it does to anyone else. It is not a matter of high government policy, I can assure Senator Kemp. I simply draw the attention of honourable senators, including Senator Kernot, to the fact that this is a matter of continual public interest. The ABT is currently conducting an inquiry into this very issue. Now that I have alerted Senator Kernot to that fact, no doubt she will make a submission to the inquiry.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How many complaints have been made to the ABT about the coverage, by Cable News Network on Channel 10, of the Operation Desert Storm?
—I have no idea, but I will find out.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BREATH TESTING OF AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL STAFF

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. I refer to a report of Commissioner Peter Nolan of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission stating that drivers on the Ghan and Indian Pacific trains and other operational staff should be subject to random breath tests. I understand that staff on the Overland Melbourne-Adelaide train are already subject to random breath tests. Can the Minister advise whether the intention is to extend random breath testing to all Australian National train drivers and operational staff?
—It is in train.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume has pinched my best line! The Minister for Land Transport has provided me with this information: Australian National introduced random breath tests on operational staff on a six-month trial basis. So, in response to Senator Baume's interjection, it is not in train; it is well down the track!

ANSWER.PARA: This had effect from 29 May 1989. The minimum acceptable blood alcohol concentration is 0.02 grams per 100 millilitres, which effectively, of course, is no alcohol. Random breath testing has been operating successfully-there you go!-at Australian National since then and was recently endorsed by the Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I ask: on what basis does the Minister reconcile his previous statements in this place regarding the so-called success of the Government's waterfront reform program with yesterday's strike by ship crews and tug operators which resulted in six of Australia's major ports being closed for 24 hours? What is the likely financial cost which will be incurred by the Australian maritime industry as a result of yesterday's strike? Given that the Minister has claimed that the subject of waterfront reform has been a priority of the Federal Government, why has there been no action on the issue of the Seamen's Compensation Act since March 1988? Does the Minister believe that the action by the Federation of Australian Maritime Unions and the tug operators in conducting this strike was reasonable given that a date for a meeting between the unions, the Australian Maritime National Association and the Government is currently being finalised? Finally, is the Minister still committed to his promise of 6 May last year to resign at the end of 12 months if he fails to wrap up at least one major enterprise agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the last bit first. The commitment that I gave-that if I did not wrap up one significant enterprise agreement after 12 months I would resign-I absolutely stick to. I point out to the honourable senator, as I have said publicly on a number of occasions-it has obviously escaped his notice-that target, I regret to advise him, has already been reached, so resignation is not required. So far as the rest of the question is concerned--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Look, your colleague deserves to get an answer to this. The detail of the question is ill-informed, as was Senator Calvert's concern about the rescue boats that were disposed of by Hobart Airport. In fact, I found out that it was 15 years ago. Yesterday I said it was 10.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason that I can reconcile the waterfront reform program with the recent industrial action by the seamen is that the one has nothing whatever to do with the other. The reason for the industrial action that was taken by the seamen was in respect of the Seamen's Compensation Act. That Act, which was enacted in this Parliament in 1911, has not been amended substantially since. People came to the view in this Government, I am pleased to say, that after almost a century of being unchanged it was about time it was brought up to date.

Senator Calvert's assertion that nothing has been done is not true. The Government-I think it was the Minister for Social Security at the time-commissioned Professor Luntz to conduct a report and make recommendations to the Government as to how the Act could be overhauled and brought up to date. He brought this report down in 1988. Frankly, I think that most of the recommendations are very sensible and hardly radical. This matter went to the industry. It was decided, sensibly I think, by all parties that it would be better to achieve the introduction of this very far-reaching matter because it is both complex and substantial in terms of the issues involved. It would be better to reach an agreement on that between the shipping companies and their employees first before any solution had to be imposed on the parties.

That process was undertaken. It did not succeed. It has been an ongoing process. In fact, a great deal has been done. I am quite happy to brief Senator Calvert on this, if he wants me to do so. In 1989 the responsibility was transferred to this portfolio from Social Security. Halfway through last year we decided that it was about time to take a hand. The Department has since actually taken charge of the convening of the meetings. Senator Calvert is quite right-a tripartite meeting was set up this month. The unions were in fact advised of that.

In response to the particular matter that Senator Calvert raised, I think the action was regrettable. I do not think it was a particularly helpful response to a matter that is being resolved. Having said that, I can understand the union's frustration with this matter not having been resolved. Last week I wrote to all the parties as a result of concern raised, again, with me. All of the parties are well aware that the Government does intend to resolve and finalise this issue in the first half of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to a report in today's Australian newspaper detailing the aerial overspraying on 7 February of electricity lineworkers on Tasmanian's north-west coast and the possible link between this incident and the death of one of the people involved. In the light of this further example of problems with aerial spraying of agricultural chemicals, can the Minister say what has been done to implement recommendations by the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia that there be a uniform, national approach to the regulation of aerial spraying of agricultural chemicals or, in the absence of that, the banning or phasing out of aerial spraying of agricultural chemicals? Will the Minister now give consideration to the phasing out of this method of chemical application? Will he also acknowledge that the use of these `cocktails' of chemicals makes virtually impossible the task of rural communities concerned about the toxicity of sprays, as information exists only for specific chemicals used in isolation? Will the Minister please take steps to ensure that the use of these `cocktails' is discontinued?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article in the Australian newspaper refers to the death of Victor James Connelly, aged 53, a Tasmanian Hydro Electric Commission linesman who died eight days after he was oversprayed by a crop duster in Tasmania, and who was buried yesterday without post-mortem or inquest. The report in the paper also said that he died on Friday of an apparent heart attack while picking potatoes with his wife. The doctor, apparently, was not aware of the overspraying and that is the reason, I presume, that there was no inquest to determine whether there was any other cause of death.

ANSWER.PARA: I assume from the question that the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia is the July 1990 report and that the relevant recommendations are 16.48 and 16.49. I had some notice of this question. I have obtained an answer from Mr Kerin. On his behalf I can say: Firstly, the Government response to the Senate Committee report is being prepared now and should be completed by early March. The Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council has had an input into the Government's response. The Government recognises the importance of the issue of aerial spraying and is aware of the submissions made to the Senate inquiry on this matter. Aerial spraying is, of course, critical to the maintenance of certain crops. However, the Government is looking very closely at the whole issue because of the concerns raised.

Secondly, as to the question of chemical `cocktails' used in aerial spraying, it is not unusual for chemicals to be mixed and this does not necessarily make them more toxic. However, of course, the necessary safeguards need to be instituted to ensure the appropriate handling of chemicals. Thirdly, as to the incidence in Tasmania, this is more appropriately a matter for the relevant State and Commonwealth departments of health.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the statement issued on 31 January by Bill Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in which, amongst other things, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: To support the Australasian Meat Industry Union to take industrial action.
In consideration of the direction given by the umpire, Deputy President Riordan, on 11 December 1990-this is in the document that I have in front of me--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got to have good vision.
—Would the Minister like another look? Has the Minister read it? If he has not, I think he should. The direction states:

QUESTION.PARA: The AMIEU and its officials and members in Victoria are hereby directed to desist from further work stoppages . . .

In view of the mention of the word `harmony' in the Minister's answer to a question asked by Senator Chapman, does the Minister support the actions of the ACTU in its blatant defiance of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission-actions which can only escalate the dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the statement of 12 January by Mr Kelty that has been referred to, so I am not clear on the context in which it was made. From my discussions with Mr Kelty and officers of the ACTU, I do know that the ACTU supports the achievement of `the accord increases' in the meat industry, and has done so consistently since it decided to embark on the campaign in September last year.

ANSWER.PARA: We have a quotation of a statement which the honourable senator says Mr Kelty has made, and a decision which I understand was brought down by Deputy President Riordan of the Federal Commission yesterday. In that decision he makes observations about the behaviour of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) in the State of Victoria-and only in the State of Victoria, as I understand it; I have not read the decision-and proceeds to award a wage increase to all meat workers in Australia, except in Victoria. In Victoria, because of industrial action taking place there, the increase was granted only to meat workers in the retail trade.

So we have something in January, alleged to have been said by Mr Kelty, and now a decision based on the facts by Deputy President Riordan, and the honourable senator is asking me whether I support the continuing campaign of the Meat Industry Employees Union. No, I do not. I believe that the decision by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is the proper outcome of a case. The Commissioner is in the best position to make a decision about that, and I ask all parties to observe the terms of the decision. That is the appropriate response from any Minister, and it is the appropriate response from the Opposition as well.

If there is any concern about ongoing breaches of directions or orders of the Commission, then it is in the hands of the parties to take the appropriate action open to them if they so choose in the Industrial Relations Act, which is an Act constructed and competent to deal with those problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. In view of his comments that he does not support the industrial action by the AMIEU, on receipt of these documents from me, will he discipline the ACTU for taking action which will escalate this dispute?
—I would be interested to know what the honourable senator regards as my powers of disciplining an organisation of this nature.
—What about deregulation?

—I am glad the honourable senator made that interjection; it is one of the many inane interjections he makes. One cannot deregister the ACTU because it is simply not a registered organisation. As a lawyer, he should have known that. If Senator Crane has documents which he wishes to put before me, which he thinks I should see, I will have a look at them and make a decision accordingly.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of claims by the medical experts that rural health services are substandard and at crisis point? What plans does the Minister have to combat these two claims? Are any special efforts being made to attract medical personnel to rural Australia? Does the Minister intend to offer incentives to people working in the health industry in rural Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Jones, particularly from his duties in outback Queensland and provincial centres in that State with decentralised populations, is very concerned about the provision of good health care to those Australians who live outside the major metropolitan centres. I know that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) shares his concern in that regard. I know that the Commonwealth Government has been working with those members of the general practice service-medical practitioners, paramedicals and nursing staff-in country and provincial centres of Australia to ensure that the conditions which obtain which might attract doctors to those centres are as attractive as possible in order to ensure that those services are provided.

ANSWER.PARA: I recall giving an answer on this matter before Christmas last year. I believe that it is incumbent on me to check whether any further elaboration of that answer might be in order to ensure that Senator Jones is brought up to date on the continuing concern of the Minister for Health, Mr Brian Howe, to act in conjunction with those general practitioners, in country areas particularly, who are very concerned about this particular problem of ensuring that all Australians have equitable access to health care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of the insecurity and uncertainty which exists in the Australian National University (ANU) arising from the Government's failure to respond to the two reports that it has before it? One of these recommends that the Institute of Advanced Studies and the faculties remain together and the other recommends that the ANU be dismembered and destroyed. When will the Government respond? Will the Government totally reject the recommendations of the Chubb Report on Higher Education in the Australian Capital Territory which would destroy the ANU?

—I am not in a position at this stage to reject the report that Senator Reid refers to, nor am I in a position to give conclusive dates of responses to those reports. However, I will get that information if it is at all possible and I will provide it to the Senate.

—I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to an article by Hugo Kelly in yesterday's Age newspaper reporting a significant decline in the domestic aviation sector due to the Gulf war. I ask the Minister whether that report is accurate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not. Without any criticism of Mr Kelly at all, it is simply a very good indication of how careful we need to be when using statistics. The fact is that business has never been better. At the moment we are doing more business in the aviation sector than we have ever done before. In fact, we have record levels. I am glad that this question was asked. What Mr Kelly's article was based on, and the significance of this--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hill interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of fact, I did not. The importance of it is that the Kelly article asserted that Australians were staying away from aircraft because of fears they had-that they were frightened passengers because of the Gulf crisis and they were not flying. It is not correct. The article was based entirely on a drop in the load factors of the aircraft. The load factors did fall over the week ending 1 February from 71.5 per cent to 62.5 per cent. But the load factors are of course the percentage of passengers that are being carried as a percentage of the total seats available. The reason for the decline has nothing to do with nervous passengers; it is to do with the dramatic increase in the additional capacity that is currently being provided by the airlines as a result of deregulation.

ANSWER.PARA: The correct measure for business being done is revenue passenger kilometres (RPK). It is self-explanatory: the number of fare paying passengers divided by the kilometres travelled. Passenger numbers were slightly down on the weekly average for February, but they were well above the figures for February 1987 and 1990, which includes recovery from the effects of the pilots dispute. Airline performance, measured by RPKs, which is the accurate measure of actual business that is being done at the moment, was in fact a record 251.3 million revenue-passenger-kilometres for a February week. In fact, this is 8 per cent above the previous record for February of the weekly average level recorded in 1989.

A record level of capacity for February was provided by the airlines, with 402.1 million available seat kilometres being provided. That is 25 per cent above the previous record level of airline capacity provided by the airlines for February, and that was in 1987. The latest load factor is 62.5 per cent, which is the lowest in recent years. Again it is a direct result of the record level of capacity currently being offered by airlines, with capacity currently growing at a greater rate than the numbers of passengers. I refer to the figure I have just given: that the amount of business being conducted in the passengers carried on domestic travel in Australia is currently running at record levels.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALARIES FOR PERTH CONSTRUCTION SITE WORKERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and particularly follows his criticism of executive salaries again today at Question Time. The Minister is no doubt aware of the unrealistic wages being paid on Perth construction sites in his home town, reaching $904 per week, or $47,000 per annum for fourth year apprentices, and the lollipop men with `Stop/Go' signs who gross about $1,000 a week. How can the Minister justify these salaries? What does the Minister plan to do about these extortionate wage levels for apprentices and unskilled labour in an industry that is predicted to drop at least 30 per cent of turnover this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Assuming those figures are right and not a fabrication--
—They are smart workers.

—No authority for these figures has been presented but, assuming that they are right, I would be interested to know what the employers who are paying those rates say in justification for doing so. I am not aware of them--
—They are being blackmailed. Strongarm tactics.
—I am not aware of them, but according to Senator Knowles's allegation they are being paid and, obviously, there is an explanation for it that the employers would be aware of.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston, you will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—I did not hear what that interjection was, but I am glad Senator Alston withdrew it. Senator Knowles asked me what I propose to do in general terms about the building industry. This could almost be a dorothy dixer. This Government, alone among governments over the past 30 or 40 years, has taken a significant initiative to conduct microeconomic reform in the building industry. Last year we had a meeting of all the major players representing all the organisations on the employer, consumer and construction sides of the industry, as well as the unions. We have set up working parties dealing with industry policy, training and education; the legal aspects of contracts; and industrial relations. The working party dealing with industrial relations is to report at the end of this month, and I understand that its deliberations are on track and we will have a report.

ANSWER.PARA: The problems of the building industry are reasonably well known, if not notorious--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are hopeless. Put your glasses back on with earphones in them. You are not answering the question.
—I thought Senator Knowles actually asked the question. If she would not mind, I would like to answer it.
—You are not answering it.

—I am answering it. This is an industry in which the lowest tenderer presumably wins the contract. It is a jobbing industry and an industry in which there is no accreditation for trade skills, although there is some accreditation for ticketed operators in the industry. It is an industry which reflects the economic cycle, which is unsafe and which is notorious in terms of industrial accidents. It is an industry in which the industrial militancy of the union is reflected on the employers' side by seedy practices that are the mirror image of some of the allegations made on the union side. It is an industry in chaos and in need of sorting out. The answer to Senator Knowles's question is that this is the only Government over the past 40 years in this country that has the guts to do it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. In view of the serious plight of farming families throughout Australia and the fact that numbers of rural families and students are being forced to repay Austudy payments because of retrospective assessment of their assets by the Australian Valuation Office (AVO), is the Minister aware that valuations conducted by the Australian Valuation Office on behalf of the Department of Employment, Education and Training under regulation 20 of the student assistance regulations are consistently well above valuations on the same assets from local councils for rate purposes, rural land agents-usually for purposes of sale-and State government valuers? How does the Minister explain such inconsistency, which in some documented cases has resulted in the Australian Valuation Office valuation being 70 per cent higher than other valuations on the same property? Finally, what action will the Minister take to ensure that the AVO's valuations reflect local market reality and also reflect the fact that the family farm is a tool of trade and not a readily realisable asset, particularly at the moment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —To pick up the last point of Senator Powell's question first, which is how will we ensure that local market reality is reflected by AVO valuations-the point to make at the outset and through the answer is that, in fact, that is what is done at the moment. The valuations for Austudy are conducted by the Australian Valuation Office and they do reflect the market value of property. They reflect the market value at a specific time, which has been determined by the Department of Employment, Education and Training under Statutory Rules 1990 No. 443, and Regulation 20 of the Austudy regulations is the applicable one.

ANSWER.PARA: The basic point is that the market value is the one that is assessed by AVO under those regulations. Secondly, it is at market rate at the specific date which has been determined under those Regulations. It differs in two specific ways from other valuations that apply: firstly, it differs in terms of a differing date of application; and, secondly, and most importantly, it differs in terms of the statutory requirements that apply to local councils and State government valuers, for instance. In those instances both with the local government and also with the State governments for land tax purposes, what is assessed by valuers is the unimproved or site value of the property without taking into account any improvements thereon. That is, as I say, a statutory requirement.

Under Austudy we have a regulation requirement that we look at the market value. So what is reflected in the AVO valuations is the local market reality, and it is assessed by AVO assessors who are conversant with the local market. I also indicate to Senator Powell, and to those who may be interested in the answer to her question, that there is within Regulation 20 a mechanism for appeal for those who are dissatisfied with the valuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister confirm that the Government is proceeding to have a paper prepared for the 12 March economic industry statement on ways to support the development of growth industries? If so, would the Minister inform the Senate what the terms of reference of this paper are? Will it be addressing the inequity of funding between potential clever country incentives such as the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority offering $800,000 over two years for expansion of the local fine wool processing industry, and the luxury type grants such as the $3.9m given to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) for just this financial year and for which there is no future benefit to Australia?

—If I might use a culinary analogy, that is a potage of a question if ever there was one. There is certainly not one paper being prepared in relation to growth industries. Any assessment of these matters requires numerous papers, I would imagine. Accordingly, there are no terms of reference as set out by Senator Walters. I have no knowledge of any grant to the ACTU and I will endeavour to find out about that for her. I do not know what the purpose of it is but, whatever it might be, it is certainly not comparable with a grant made in the textile industry in relation to fine wool. I assume that that grant would have been made for very specific purposes relating to research and development and matters of that kind. Senator Walters cannot compare apples with oranges on these things, and I suggest that she have another go at her question tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. The question relates to recent media speculation within the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) that a redundancy package was being developed. This, in turn, has caused some concern and consternation among employees within the Authority. Can the Minister enlighten the Senate and the work force within the Civil Aviation Authority about the reasons behind such a package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an important question because the CAA not only is a large organisation of, currently, 7,000 employees but also performs, as all senators would know, an extremely important task. The reason for the concern being expressed in the press-I have noticed some more press reports today-about the proposed redundancies in the CAA stems from a letter that the Chairperson of the CAA, Dick Smith, sent to all employees of the organisation. The letter provided an explanation of what the CAA was currently doing in terms of its efficiency review. It is a comprehensive efficiency review being conducted under the direction of Frank Baldwin, the new Chief Executive Officer of the CAA, who was appointed on 14 January this year. The matter that caused the concern was the statement in the letter that the board's initial policy of no involuntary redundancies had been changed and the board was simply opening the opportunity up for this to be negotiated, if it was necessary. It is important to point out that the provision for involuntary redundancies already exists within the awards that cover the employees of the CAA. The provision has always been there.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason the letter was sent out-I commend Dick Smith for doing this-was that, despite the fact that the award provision already existed, the board had taken a decision as a board that there would be no involuntary redundancies. The Chairperson of CAA took the first opportunity he had to tell all employees of the organisation directly that the board had changed its position. It is an efficiency review. There has been no target set in terms of targets for the number of employees that may have to leave. Numbers will not be examined until after the review is completed, and that will take three months. It will be finished in May. All staff and all staff organisations will have an opportunity to contribute to that review.

I conclude by providing a further piece of information-bad news as Senator Calvert would see it. I see that he is coming back into this chamber. He is entitled to have this information because of his previous question: another three enterprise agreements have been concluded between the union and its employers; that is, between the Waterside Workers Federation and the Union Stevedoring Co.; and those agreements are for the ports of Sydney, Melbourne and Hobart. The agreements were delivered to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority on Monday morning for its assessment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. According to recent press reports, instead of raising the $100m promised, the luxury car tax will in fact see a revenue fall by at least $350m. Given that the $100m was promised to fund provincial cities and rural highways, can he confirm whether it is true that the tax will see revenue fall? How will the shortfall on road funding in those areas be made up?

—I do not have the precise figures in front of me, but I think it is probably correct to say that the luxury car tax will not meet the anticipated revenue levels which were claimed for it. The reason for that is that there has been a considerable downturn in the motor vehicle market generally. That is compounded, in the case of luxury imported vehicles, by the application of the luxury tax. It would be better if I got a more precise estimate for Senator Panizza because the estimates provided to me by the industry are sometimes queried. I think they are reasonably accurate, but they are sometimes queried. I will try to get an accurate assessment of those figures for Senator Panizza. As far as the implications for road funding are concerned-that is the second part of the question-I will first have to get the answer to the first part.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia said publicly yesterday:

QUESTION.PARA: If we were to become aware of a problem in a State bank, we would press the management board to clarify the nature and extent of the difficulty and to put in place strategies to maintain the viability of the bank, and if it was particularly serious the Reserve Bank would seek to ensure that the owner was fully aware of the problem.
In light of that fact, did the Reserve Bank inform the owner of the South Australian State Bank, Premier John Bannon, of the bank's problems? If so when, and if not why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to what Mr Fraser said took place in relation to the State Bank of South Australia, let me say that that bank provided the Reserve Bank of Australia on a voluntary basis with a range of information. Some of this was published in the Reserve Bank's monthly bulletin. The bulk of the information is supplied, however, on a strictly confidential basis which the Reserve Bank is committed to respect. It is worth reiterating that this regularly provided information does not include details of individual loans. The Reserve Bank, I am advised, had a number of discussions with the State Bank of South Australia management during 1990, particularly in the light of its results for 1989-90 which showed an operating loss. These discussions covered many issues, including its policy on provisions for potential loan losses. The questions raised in these discussions would have been one factor behind the State Bank's decision to engage J.P. Morgan as consultants.

ANSWER.PARA: To come to the nub of the question, if I can identify it, the magnitude of the State Bank's problems began to emerge progressively as its end December 1990 accounts were being prepared. The Reserve Bank was informed of this during January 1991 and immediately engaged in discussions with the bank and its owner on measures to restore its capital and to maintain its viability. That answer is in part an answer to the question asked by Senator Olsen today and in part an answer to the question he asked the day before yesterday in respect to which I had a prepared answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Social Security seen the article in the Brisbane Sun of 16 February alleging that fraud teams from his Department conducted a blitz on unemployment benefit recipients. Is such a blitz being conducted and, if so, why now and why Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that it depends on the definition of `blitz'. In the last Budget the Government announced that there would be additional review teams appointed because of the success of review teams in the past. In large part the purpose of having extra review teams was to make sure that we could get visits to more country areas and remote areas from review teams which were tending not to be visited while the concentration was on the cities. This has meant that the new teams have been deployed in doing that.

ANSWER.PARA: We have five teams working in and around Cairns, Rockhampton, Gladstone, Mackay, Bundaberg, Maryborough and Toowoomba in Queensland, but also in Broome, Kununurra and Port Hedland in Western Australia. If one includes those teams, there are now 60 teams working throughout Australia-working not just on dole recipients but on recipients of all benefits and pensions. They are better able to target those in higher risk areas. It is worth remembering that in the 1989-90 financial year 50 teams undertook 84,000 reviews, and that resulted in the cancellation of 14,652 payments. That gives an idea of the breadth of success.

Of those 60 teams, 20 are on unemployment benefits, 10 are on long term unemployment benefits and eight are on sole parents; there are nine public information teams, three follow-up teams, five sickness benefit teams and five smaller local teams reviewing payments of all types. So, yes, there are teams in Queensland and, yes, they certainly are looking, at the moment in particular, at unemployment benefits in those towns, but they are part of a much wider effort and I would not define it as a blitz.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. The Minister will appreciate that the failure of the Pyramid Building Society in Victoria, the disastrous affairs of the State banks of Victoria and South Australia and the financial problems of the major banks in Australia have caused much community concern about the security of deposits, especially investment accounts. In particular, that concern deeply affects the pensioner community. These people do not want to risk their hard earned savings, especially when their working lives have finished. No doubt the Minister is also aware of the limitations of the obligations on the Reserve Bank of Australia to guarantee deposit investment accounts, especially as Mr Fraser is trying to bring that to the attention of the public of Australia at the present moment. I ask the Minister whether the Government, in the light of all those facts, would be prepared to guarantee the investment accounts which pensioners, in effect, are required to make under the Minister's deeming provisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am sure Senator Lewis is aware, I have never made any attempt to disguise the fact that pensioners all over Australia have concerns about the security of deposits. That is why, in literature to them and in any public statements that I have made, I have emphasised what is available through the four major banks rather than other financial institutions. I say I have emphasised the four major banks, but I have not excluded the other financial institutions. We have made an effort to communicate to pensioners all accounts where they can get 10 per cent, whether they are with the major banks or not.

ANSWER.PARA: While it is certainly true to say that the large banks, such as the Westpac Banking Corporation, have fairly public financial problems, I think it is also true to say that no-one in Australia would regard any of the major banks as under threat of falling down at the moment. Therefore, I certainly have not experienced amongst the pensioner community, either in terms of correspondence that has been received directly or from representations from those groups which represent them, any reluctance about investments in the major banks. I might say that that probably carries over to some of the major building societies as well.

I do not really believe that there is this problem of confidence in investments accounts, especially in the major financial institutions. We will continue to emphasise, as a department, that that is where our efforts are concentrated, and I hope that that satisfies pensioners over time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Government consider guaranteeing special deposit accounts for pensioners, or does the Government reject that proposition?
—I would have to take that up with the Treasurer, and I will undertake to do so, but I do not personally see any need for the Government to extend any further guarantees than exist at the moment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Crichton-Browne asked me whether Radio Australia had moved to fill the position of executive producer of Radio Australia's Vietnam program by seeking applicants from the Hanoi Ministry of Culture, Information, Tourism and Sports. Senator Crichton-Browne also asked me whether I was aware of a communique from the Australian Ambassador that seemed to indicate that that had been the case.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, has provided me with the following information: the answer to the first part of the question is no. The position of executive producer of Radio Australia's Vietnamese service has been filled by one of Radio Australia's own broadcast officers. In accordance with normal practice, Radio Australia advertises positions in Australia and overseas when it is considered necessary to do so.

In particular, effective non-English language services require that broadcast officers are highly proficient in English and that their skills in the relevant language enable them to communicate effectively in the current idiom. Radio Australia management had identified some weaknesses in this regard in the Vietnamese service and, in the interests of attracting a wider field of applicants, decided to explore recruitment opportunities in Vietnam as well as in Australia which, I must say, seems an eminently reasonable thing to do.

In answer to the second part of the question, as part of a visit he made to Hanoi to sign an agreement of cooperation between the Voice of Vietnam and Radio Australia in July 1990, Radio Australia's General Manager, Richard Broinowski, interviewed several candidates as possible broadcast officers for the Vietnamese service. The Australian Ambassador, Mr Alliband, who sent the communique referred to, had been asked to use his contacts to help locate suitable applicants. Three persons were considered: one nominated by the Voice of Vietnam, one employed in the Australian Embassy and a journalist working privately in Ho Chi Minh City. Recruiting for the position was also carried out among Australian Vietnamese, with standard advertisements in Australian newspapers. An Australian Broadcasting Corporation selection panel was established to consider all applicants. The successful applicant was appointed on merit and, as it turned out, was one of the applicants from within Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crichton-Browne on 19 February 1991, relating to the Radio Australia Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EARLY RELEASE PROGRAMS: UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFIT FOR PARTICIPANTS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the Senate Senator Lees asked me a question about the cancellation of unemployment benefits paid to some Queensland prisoners. I am now in a position to answer her question. Section 167 of the Social Security Act provides that a benefit is not payable in respect of any period during which a person is imprisoned in connection with a conviction for an offence. For the purpose of that section, imprisonment includes detention in an institution other than an actual prison, for example, custodial hostels, youth training centres and the like, and detention on remand.

ANSWER.PARA: Under early release, home detention and community service order programs, prisoners may be released into the community to serve their remaining sentence outside formal detention centres such as prisons and youth training centres. Such persons are not considered to be imprisoned and benefit may be granted if the usual conditions are satisfied.

The program to which Senator Lees refers is not an early release program; it is a work release program and the participants are in custodial hostels. This work release program was introduced some years ago, initially for prisoners whose former employers would re-employ them on final release, and was extended in 1988 to prisoners who did not have fixed future employment. However, payments were not made to prisoners in this program.

About 18 months ago, payments were made to prisoners in this category, based on information from the Prisons Department of the previous Government in Queensland. The Prisons Department made inquiries about the availability of payment for prisoners on home detention programs and was advised that such people could be paid. It then placed prisoners who did not have homes to go to into work release centres but led the Department of Social Security to believe that they were home detention cases. This meant that payments were made to people still imprisoned.

Following a review of these cases and the clarification of their status with the Queensland Department of Justice and Corrective Services, it was clear that these people were still imprisoned for the purposes of the Social Security Act and were ineligible for payment. Consequently a decision has been made that no further claims from this group of prisoners will be approved and that the 22 current payments have ceased.

The Department of Justice and Corrective Services was consulted informally over the period October 1990 to January 1991 and, when details of the prisoners involved were finally received in January, was advised of the decision to cancel payments and the reasons for it. A formal meeting was held with that Department on 29 January, when the decision and its reasons were once again explained, and the decision confirmed.

This is not, as Senator Lees referred to it yesterday, a savings exercise; rather, it is a clarification of the law relating to prisoners. Because of the number of cases involved, the savings are minimal and no overpayment will be raised against those affected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I wish to raise a matter of privilege that you have already dealt with in this Senate. It relates to the matters that Senator McLean raised last week in trying to table some documents relating to the Westpac Banking Corporation and legal action. On 12 February in the Senate you ruled that the matter was sub judice and that therefore the material could not be tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, I understand, Senator McLean has circulated the same documents through the mailing system within the Senate to all honourable senators. They arrived in my office at about lunchtime. After reading the documents I can understand why they are sensitive to the particular legal case. Senator McLean advised me that under the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 he is able to circulate such material to senators and to have some sort of privileged protection but is not able to table it or incorporate it in Hansard. If that is correct, I would like that made clear to all senators so that, if in the future any of us run into the same problems of wanting to table material that is sub judice, we know our rights about circulating such material to other senators.

I also want to raise another matter with you, Mr President. When I read the documents, I found there was material in there that, as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs presently conducting an inquiry into the cost of justice in Australia, would consider very germane to our inquiry. I would very much like to be able, as a member of that Senate Committee, to use this material and, if necessary, subpoena the people responsible and ask them questions. I believe that would be very helpful in reaching a conclusion that the Committee is looking at in that inquiry. I want to get some understanding from you, Mr President, about the rights of the Senate's Standing Committee conducting the inquiry at the moment, which was going on long before this Westpac matter arose, and how we can deal with this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You proposed the reference.
—Senator Collins quite rightly points out that I was a leading advocate on the Committee to have this inquiry on the cost of justice conducted.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I want to raise with you, Mr President, the question of sub judice and documents being able to be tabled or incorporated in Hansard. After reading the documents, it is my view that, in fact, justice may well be denied to many other Australian citizens if they are unaware of the material that is in the documents.

Honourable senators can argue that the present case could be affected by this document being tabled and incorporated in Hansard. I would say, after reading it, that there are many other citizens who, if they were aware of this information, would have their legal rights enhanced by being able to take action, or consider taking action, and therefore have their rights protected. Unaware that this material is available, they would not know of those rights. I know that this is a very vexed question. I do not in any way attempt to proclaim that I have any knowledge, or technical knowledge, about this very difficult matter. However, I do make the point that, after a preliminary reading, we may well be prejudging and precluding the rights of many other citizens who do not have access to this material. But that is just a comment.

The real questions I want to ask are: firstly, what are the rights of other senators about circulating material, such as Senator McLean has done today, that has already been excluded from being tabled; and, secondly, what are the rights of the Senate Standing Committee conducting the inquiry in this area now that we have had access to the information that apparently has been quite appropriately circulated to us all?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Schacht raised this issue with me quite late in Question Time today. I will definitely need more time to consider the matter. I also point out to Senator Schacht that I am not the only Presiding Officer in Australia who has ruled this way already. In fact, there are three that I know of. Tabling the documents would certainly make them public documents; circulation to honourable senators does not make them public documents. I will examine all the issues that have been raised by Senator Schacht, including the point he made about the Committee. I will advise the Senate accordingly as soon as is reasonably possible.
—In relation to Senator Hill's interjection, naturally I will take all that into account.

—I have a very short answer to a question which Senator Kernot asked me in Question Time today. As she is still in the chamber, I will provide it now. I have been advised by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that it received 99 complaints between 17 and 31 January relating to the coverage of the Gulf war on all stations. The complaints related to the blanket cover given to the war and the fact that the majority of the coverage emanated from the United States. There were only two specific complaints concerning Channel 10: both criticised the fact that Channel 10 did not provide blanket coverage-that is, 24-hour coverage.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time yesterday and again in the course of a personal explanation last night, Senator Bishop asked a number of questions relating to the anti-war protests at Parliament House. I am now able to provide the following information.

INTERJECT.PARA: Since the beginning of the autumn sittings on 21 January, one person has been arrested in the vicinity of Parliament House. I understand the arrest was in connection with outstanding warrants and not related to the anti-war protest at Parliament House.

It is not true that the Presiding Officers have declined to have charges laid against the protesters. Neither the Australian Federal Police nor the Australian Protective Service officers operating in the precincts have considered it necessary to charge any person in relation to the anti-war protests.

Following Senator Bishop's question, I have been advised that on Sunday, 17 February a brief scuffle broke out involving two, or possibly three, people attending an anti-war rally within the parliamentary precincts. There were a total of eight people in the protest area at the time. An Australian Protective Service officer attended the scene of the incident. However, the cause of the scuffle had been resolved before the officer arrived and neither the participants nor bystanders wished further action to be taken.

As with any large public building, minor incidents occur from time to time which are attended to by the security authorities. The Speaker and I receive regular reports from the Security Controller on such security matters. Any serious incidents are immediately reported to us.

As to the existence of holding cells in the building, I advise that, consistent with the architects' brief for the new Parliament House, two small cells were constructed in the basement of the building. The cells are currently used to provide secure storage for equipment and documents. There are no plans to vary their current use.

Senator Bishop also referred to the fact that a member of her staff had been required to move her vehicle, which had been parked at the Senate entrance. As part of the security measures currently in place, the Speaker and I accepted advice that vehicles should not be permitted to remain unattended in the immediate vicinity of the entrances to the building. The reasons justifying the advice, I believe, would be clear to all honourable senators. Inquiries relating to the specific matter raised by Senator Bishop have not yet been completed. I will advise the honourable senator of the results of these investigations as soon as possible.

Finally, I advise Senator Bishop that, while the protesters are maintaining their vigil in the usual demonstration area at the front of Parliament House, their camp is outside the parliamentary precincts. Under guidelines issued by the Speaker and me for the control of the precincts, camping is not permitted within the precincts.

I might add that close contact has been maintained between security authorities at Parliament House and the anti-war protesters. Throughout the vigil at the front of the building, the protesters have at all times complied with the directions of the Australian Protective Service officers on duty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I asked my question yesterday in the light of tightened security arrangements. I thank you, Mr President, for the answer that you have given today. I also note that you, the Black Rod and I had the opportunity to discuss this matter before lunch. I am somewhat concerned that perhaps the statement in its final form does not reflect some of the discussions we had. I refer, for instance, to the fact that the scuffle which took place on the seventeenth of this month was not reported to you, as I believe it ought to have been reported to you as the Presiding Officer.

There are one or two things that I think ought to be included in the investigation. There are no restrictions to entry to the public car park, unlike the three other underground car parks. Protesters were seen sleeping in the car park on the night of 21 January, which was the day the Parliament resumed to discuss the war. On occasions since that date they have, on a continuing basis, left their chattels in that public car park. These items are not subject to being checked for security purposes. This comes at a time when security at the entrances to other Parliament House car parks have undergone considerable tightening.

The Australian Protective Service is apparently part of the Department of Administrative Services and, therefore, is not directly reportable to you, Mr President, but merely to the security services and then by them to you. Protective Service officers are analogous to police officers without strict evidence training and are presumably the people who would be better able to report to you.

It would also appear that there is not one group of cells but indeed two groups of cells, the other being located in the security area in the basement under the Executive Wing and subject to the jurisdiction of the Protective Service as distinct from the Security Service, which controls the cells at the front of the building.

Lastly, the skirmish that occurred on Sunday amongst the protesters raises the question of just how long these people are entitled to camp under or near the building; what sort of security risks are maintained by these people not being checked; and, quite frankly, just how long does a protest go on?

With regard to the question I raised with regard to my staff-the way in which it was reported in your answer, Mr President, as I pointed out to you earlier, was incorrect. My concern was not that she was asked to move her car, which was quite proper, but that it had been simply a fortuitous announcement to her to move her car because other people were about to rip its doors off, remove its engine and otherwise destroy it without giving her any notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish someone would remove your engine and rip your door off.
—Those are the matters that I raised and perhaps Senator Collins will have due time to consider them when he spends one hour in the cell.

—Order! If there are any issues that Senator Bishop raised that I did not address-I believe in reference to that last matter I did say in the statement that further investigations were continuing-and if there are any unanswered questions, I will provide an answer to her and to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Under standing order 191, I claim to have been misquoted and misrepresented. It has been brought to my attention that on three occasions yesterday I was rather seriously misrepresented. The first occasion was by Senator Vallentine in a speech on the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps it comes down to Senator MacGibbon's expressed concern that such guidelines might prevent the use of weapons of mass destruction-chemical, biological and nuclear.
Nothing could be further from the truth. In my speech on the Geneva Conventions Bill, the exact sentence reads:
There is no argument that we would want to see nuclear, chemical and biological weapons banned.
That is the direct converse of what Senator Vallentine said. The second incident relates to Senator Coulter where, in his speech on the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill, he said:
As Senator MacGibbon almost proudly pointed out in the debate yesterday, war has been part of human history, in his view, for 500 years.
I made no reference at all to the history of war in any part of my speech. I cannot think where Senator Coulter got that from except in a passage where I said:

Australia has respected not only the Geneva Conventions as they exist but the whole body of international law which, as the ALP and the Australia Democrats do not understand, goes back not 50 years or 100 years, but hundreds, if not thousands, of years.
The third case deals with Senator Bell, who turned up for once in the chamber. In his speech he said:
As a preamble to his speech-
talking about me-
he expressed the attitude that the theory of greenhouse could not be proven through mathematical modelling.

Had Senator Coulter any knowledge of physics and had he any knowledge of current research practices, he would know that the mathematical computer modelling for the greenhouse effect, in the same way as with Carl Sagan's nuclear winter scenario, has never been done.
