SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC) report is for the period from 1 July 1989 to 30 June 1990. The report begins with the usual letter to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) and concludes with the signature of the Chairman, Nancy Millis, who is a very well known microbiologist. I note that GMAC is still an advisory committee. The report states:
Although GMAC's recommendations are advisory, sanctions exist for noncompliance. These include the withdrawal of government funding for research and development . . .

These sanctions are effective only in relation to research which is carried on with government grants; that is, mainly research which is going on in universities and government-funded institutes. The report continues:
. . . and the possible withdrawal of any tax concessions.

That relates to research in the area of genetic manipulation which is going on in private companies and which may or may not attract tax concessions. If the research work which is being done does not attract a government grant or a tax concession, there are no sanctions whatsoever which the Advisory Committee can recommend be brought against those who are manipulating genetic material, perhaps to the detriment of either the environment or the Australian population.

The Committee comprises people who are all scientists. I have no objection to that at all in relation to the biological nature of many of the hazards which arise from genetic manipulation. Perhaps it is worth reminding the Senate that what we are talking about here is the deliberate cutting of genetic material into pieces and the incorporation of some of that genetic material into other species where it would not normally come to reside through the normal biological processes of breeding.

To some extent this work involves the creation of completely novel species that the evolutionary system currently does not provide. In that connection, I draw the Senate's attention again to the debate which we had in this place in relation to the patenting of these new life forms. This Advisory Committee has no capability of taking into account the commercial pressures under which people will come because of the ability to patent those life forms.

The report goes on to talk about the establishment of institutional biosafety committees which exist in most institutes and universities and says that they are expected to abide by the relevant GMAC guidelines. Further on it states:
A scientist working with full length HIV DNA incorporated into a plasmid-
that is, a piece of genetic material that occurs in a bacterium-
and using appropriate conditions of containment and safety precautions pricked a finger.

Although the scientist was found not to be infected with HIV, nonetheless a risk existed. The report goes on to talk about cases in which there has been an unwillingness by institutional committees to refer a matter to GMAC. One of those cases involves precisely the use of the HIV virus.

I simply draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, given the ability to patent these life forms and given the fact that, in this case, the Fairfield Hospital did not think it necessary to report to GMAC, we are indeed in a dangerous situation if these types of experiments can be carried on under a more commercial aegis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC) says in its report to the Parliament, it is funded by appropriation. It does not receive any funding from other sources and it does not have a granting function. No revenue is generated. In fact the total appropriation for running costs for 1989-90 was $243,000. Of that amount, $162,000 was allocated to salaries and related expenditure and $81,000 to administrative expenses. The Committee has a staff of only five, comprising one scientist, who is the secretary, and four administrative staff, including the director.

SPEECH.PARA: The work of the Committee is very important indeed. I know the Chairman of the Committee, Nancy Millis, has expressed her view on a number of occasions about the importance of proper surveillance taking place in this area. I think the point Senator Coulter made is quite valid. Clearly there are fast bucks-ultimately-to be made in the area of genetic manipulation. However, a good deal of research has yet to be undertaken, but because there could be a substantial amount of economic pressure applied it is important that the Parliament keeps a continued overview on what is happening. Up to this stage we have not really done so. I know there is a House of Representatives committee inquiry into this matter. Indeed, somewhere in the report it indicates that GMAC had a hand in the suggested terms of that inquiry. I hope the inquiry by the House of Representatives is conducted in such a way that the scientific aspect is not the major consideration but rather that it is the human aspect.

While I am on that subject, it is of note that in appendix A the membership of the Committee is outlined. I note also that all members of the Committee are scientists. Frankly, I have some quibble about that. That is not to question the sincerity of the scientists at all, but I feel that there is more at stake in this whole area of research than simply scientific endeavour, whether it be for the purpose of economic exportation or of development as perceived by the scientists.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with you.

—I feel that at some stage we have to look at this. I have been on the record in various places and in the various speeches I have made expressing concern about the acceptance of certain views expressed by scientists or of certain actions taken by scientists. As an example, the Deputy Chairman of this Committee, Professor David Danks, and I have disagreed with the development of a search-and-destroy system whereby DNA probes are made on the unborn not for purposes of correcting or curing disease but for the purpose of eliminating the bearer. In my view, that is a concept which is unacceptable. It is also unacceptable in the view of Disabled Peoples International (Aust), which appeared in a newspaper article I read recently. I am sorry my time has expired because I would like to have commended some of the work of the Committee.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to commend the Tiwi Land Council for the sort of report it is producing. Its eleventh annual report is an ideal one for others to follow. It clearly shows that the Tiwi Land Council is adopting a very responsible approach. Perhaps some other land councils could examine the sort of sensible entrepreneurial activity, aimed at advancing the benefits available to the Tiwi people, that is taking place under this Council, which is not preoccupied with the political battles that seem to have been uppermost in the minds of some other land councils.

I would also like to mention-I am not singling out this or any other land council-in keeping with my general complaints about the delays involved in producing many governmental bodies' reports to this Parliament, that this has taken a long time to get here. It is now 20 February 1991. The audit, as I understand it, was not signed until late in November. I cannot see why because, as the auditor says:

As an audit procedure it has not been practicable to vouch all individual transactions of the Council during the year under review. However, on the basis of tasks and procedures undertaken, I am of the opinion that the receipt, expenditure and investment of monies, and the acquisition and disposal of assets by the Council during the year ended 30 June 1990 have been in accordance with the Act.

That is a fairly broad audit statement and I would not have thought it would take from the end of the financial year until 16 November to come out with it. I guess that it has spent the rest of the time in the office of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner). We have sat for a fair while since then, and I would encourage the Minister not to add to any delays. Once again, I commend the Tiwi Land Council for its eleventh annual report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The annual report of the Northern Land Council is an important document and one that we should read carefully. There is a great deal to differentiate it from the other two reports that have been tabled today-those of the Tiwi Land Council and the Central Land Council-both of which I would commend in general terms as excellent documents which adequately report the activities of those land councils, put the information before us very fairly, and comment on the activities that they are charged to do under their charter and the job that they carry out.

However, the quality and the tenor of the report of the Northern Land Council reflects its poor leadership. The Chairman, the Director and, of course, the senior staff have a radical political leaning which is very deliberately reflected in the report. One has only to look at the photography of the demonstrations and the protests, the style of the caricatures and cartoons, and the preoccupation with issues such as the treaty, demonstrations and the approaches to major resource projects from an activist point of view. The Northern Land Council report would do well to copy the style and details that are presented by the Tiwi and Central land councils.

I would like to highlight for the Senate's attention some specific issues such as the redundancy of staff. It is noted in the report that some 31 staff are to be made redundant. This obviously has a very high cost factor. I believe that that information should be shown in more detail, particularly where any of those officers are now being redeployed to other Aboriginal activist organisations that are also on the Government nipple for funding. That area of expenditure has to be closely scrutinised. There are audit qualifications that expenditure has exceeded the budget and, again, probably the most appropriate place to examine those matters will be in the Senate Estimates hearings.

The funds allocated to the land councils from the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account always require careful scrutiny. The funding made available at the discretion of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs under section 67 of the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account legislation is important. The Northern Land Council has not got on with the job of adequately processing mining exploration applications to proper development projects in the Northern Territory.

I believe that the large amounts of money allocated to the Northern Land Council under this special ministerial top up fund, which was put up in considerable detail by the former Minister, Mr Hand, unfortunately now seems to be still pervading the ongoing budget, rather than operating within appropriate budget limits and allowing the funding to be made more generally available for Aborigines in the Northern Territory as direct grants.

As I said, I am critical, as I have been for the past couple of years, of the administration of the Land Council. I note that in recent days the Director named in this report, Mr John Ah Kit, has left the employ of the Northern Land Council. As I mentioned in my comments on redundancy, I believe he has recently been appointed to another Aboriginal organisation in the Northern Territory. We will certainly have to look carefully at the extent of his financial redundancy when he retired from the Northern Land Council and the terms and conditions under which he is now being employed in another government funded organisation.
Again, I draw the Senate's attention to the quality of the report, and highlight the ongoing issues that, obviously, have to be kept under review with regard to the Northern Land Council.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to start off by saying that my colleague in the other place the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Michael Wooldridge, has spoken to me about how grateful he has been to the Central Land Council for the very cooperative way it has been dealing with him, and on his behalf I would like to thank it for that.

I should mention that my obsession about timing of annual reports is equally applicable here. This annual report was signed on 19 December 1990, which is late, and is only coming to us today, 20 February. I would like to commend on my own behalf the Central Land Council for the direction that it is now showing as revealed in its annual report:

The Land Council is now focusing more of its attention on questions of economic development. Last year's report on Aboriginal Economic Development in Central Australia found that while Aboriginal money remains the mainstay of the Central Australian economy, Aboriginal people share few of the benefits of economic activity. Aboriginal people remain trapped in a cycle of dependency and poverty with little real access to meaningful employment.

One of the important recommendations of the Report was that more emphasis be placed on the economic development of Aboriginal land. As a result, the Central Land Council has undertaken further research into the provision of basic infrastructure to Aboriginal communities, existing economic activity on Aboriginal land, and the possibility of further development of land use within the Central Land Council region.
The Land Council is now concentrating more effort into land management and community development as the land claims process begins to require less of our resources.

There are many people who would be saying that this is a welcome change in emphasis and direction. However, with that change I hope that the temptation to have cracks of a very political nature at various governments will be diminished as well. For example, I notice what the report says about the Territory Government:

The Territory Government kept up its attacks against Aboriginal organisations and their leadership as a political tactic during this election campaign year. Often this has involved attempts to misrepresent the policies of organisations and divide the Aboriginal community for the sake of some short term party political gain.

The Territory Government can defend itself on that matter, but my view is that, whatever the merits of the case, it does not do the Land Council much good to canvass it in this way in this kind of report, which is otherwise so useful. Also, I suggest to the Central Land Council that it encourage the Minister's office to be a little more efficient. I note on page 38 of the report:

During 1989-90 negotiations were held with staff of the Minister's Office to proceed with minor amendments to allow for anticipated overexpenditure in the Recruitment/Relocation, Temporary Accommodation Allowance and Legal Costs allocations. Savings to cover such amounts were rationalised in economies in other areas across the organisation. Due to delays in the processing of the amendments by the Minister's staff and officers in ATSIC, the Minister was unable to consider the amendments prior to 30 June. Accordingly the Council exceeded the 20 per cent allowed under Section 34 of the Act in these three allocations.

The result is that the Auditor-General has been required to qualify the accounts. I notice on page 49 of the notes that it is said that a formal request to the Minister to approve the revised estimates in respect of the above matters only arrived in a letter dated 25 June 1990. Once again, I do not know the rights and wrongs of this; but if it is, as indicated earlier by the Land Council, that it is the office of the Minister and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission that were dilatory and causing this sort of qualification, I hope that the Minister and his office and ATSIC will smarten their act up.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account (ABTA) was established to receive and distribute mining royalty equivalent moneys derived from mining operations on Aboriginal land. It is very interesting to note that during the year ended 30 June 1990 aggregate royalty equivalents of $34,302,336 were credited to the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account. There is a predetermined formula for the distribution of those funds. It is acknowledged that, under section 64(1), 40 per cent of this funding is automatically applied to the three Northern Territory land councils to meet administrative expenditure. That is a fixed; it is determined.

Under section 64(3), 30 per cent is required to be distributed through the land councils for various purposes and then the residual of 30 per cent can be distributed either for the benefit of Aborigines or for additional administrative costs as approved by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. As I said earlier in my comments on the Northern Land Council report, I note that this year the funds under section 64(7)-that is, the ministerial discretion top-up administrative moneys-amounted to some $3,694,827. When that is added to the section 64(1) funds of over $11m, it means that automatically $15m is being applied to the administration of the land councils.

As I said earlier, I am concerned that this continual ministerial top-up for administrative purposes is at the expense of Aborigines in the Northern Territory, who ought to be receiving these funds for grants in their respective communities.

I note that in the report there is discussion of the various consultancies undertaken for the review of the ABTA during the year by Mr Crough and others in a number of areas. It seems that the various results of working parties, et cetera, have been dragged out and not settled as at 30 June to enable the funds that have been built up in this account to be properly distributed.

I also note on pages 5, 6 and 7 of the report that the ABTA has canvassed and sought from Aboriginal people an identification of their various needs, whether for traditional and cultural activities, for social and recreational activities or for enterprise and economic activities. When it sought applications, it is interesting to note, some 661 applications were received from across the Northern Territory with requests for over $43m. I imagine that the great majority of those applications were deliberately and carefully constructed and would be meaningful in the results that they could achieve for Aborigines. But the ABTA has been constrained by its policy decisions and investment criteria as to how much can be allocated.

It concerns me that, as is shown in table 4 on page 7, only $768,715 was allocated to meeting needs. Therefore, there is a wide disparity between the applications that have been put forward on behalf of or by Aboriginal people and the actual allocation of funds. This report always needs the close scrutiny of this Senate. This issue is bound up with the whole future of the Northern Territory. It is important to the economy of the Aboriginal people and to the Northern Territory generally. I hope that, as the Northern Territory proceeds down the constitutional track towards full statehood, we will see a deliberate way in which this account can be transferred to the Northern Territory Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to point out to the Senate the enormous impact of mining royalties on revenues available to the Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory and to point out the significance to the Aboriginal community of the activities of those people who perhaps seek to encourage many Aboriginal people to resist mining activity, no matter what, in the Northern Territory. I note in this report, as Senator Tambling pointed out, that total mining royalty benefits paid to the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account (ABTA) equal $34.3m in the year ended June. The Australian Democrats would probably be appalled to note that uranium royalties totalled $9.2m. That amount could be significantly increased were approval given for further uranium mine developments.

SPEECH.PARA: As it is, the amount available to the Aboriginal community is falling. It is falling because of a mixture of reasons, but the main one is that other developments which could proceed are not being allowed to proceed by present Government policy. Bauxite royalties totalled $2.7m; manganese royalties, $14.4m, a very substantial increase; oil royalties, $335,000; gas royalties, $1.9m; gold royalties, $750,000; and on top of that there are additional determinations for manganese and gold royalties of just under $5m, giving a total royalty equivalent of $34.3m.

The significance of mining royalties is well known to ABTA because, following concerns regarding the apparently declining level of funds in the previous year, as Senator Tambling said, the then Department appointed a working party to examine it. That working party completed its report in December 1989. Subsequently the annual report notes that there was a significant increase in estimated royalty or equivalent income for the year owing primarily to a substantial rise in forecast royalty equivalent receipts by the Northern Territory relating to mining operations of the Groote Island Mining Company Pty Ltd, Gemco. As a result the Minister asked the working party to review its findings.

As Senator Tambling said, these mining royalties are a very significant benefit to the Aboriginal community and I hope that this annual report will be a constant reminder to those people seeking to diminish and restrain mining activity in the Northern Territory, perhaps to extreme levels of restraint, that there is major benefit to the Aboriginal communities emerging from mining in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support my colleague because what is not understood, when we play politics with mining operations, is the personal cost to the Aboriginal community. The three mines at Koongarra, Jabiluka and Coronation Hill could go into production tomorrow if the Government did not play politics. This is enormous wealth that is available to the Aboriginal community.

That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects.
It will give effect to the personal tax cuts announced on 20 November 1990, and make a consequential amendment to the rebate allowable for medical expenses.

Capital gains tax amendments to be made by the Bill will ease restrictions on the availability of capital gains tax rollover relief, and also ensure capital losses are not brought forward artificially as a consequence of asset transfers between companies under common ownership. Some technical amendments to the capital gains tax provisions as they apply to disposals of partnership assets are also proposed.
A Budget announcement to be given effect by this Bill will limit the franking credits available to life assurance companies under the imputation system.
It will also provide for the taxation treatment of various bereavement payments that have replaced the special temporary allowance and funeral benefit.

Other amendments contained in this Bill will modify the foreign income legislation presently before the Parliament to remove some potential double taxation, to correct technical deficiencies and overcome tax avoidance avenues, and to implement the Budget announcement to extend the deductions for certain capital expenditures on particular activities in Australia to similar offshore activities that generate income to be taxed here.

The Bill will also ensure that a deduction is not allowable for bad debts of a foreign branch of a money-lender who has not derived assessable income from those debts. Finally, the Bill will amend certain provisions of the Taxation Administration Act that deal with the protection of taxation information.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
Personal tax cuts

The Government announced on 20 November 1990 that it had reached agreement with the ACTU to replace the first wage adjustment under Accord Mark VI with personal tax cuts to cement in place Australia's decelerating inflation rate which is now lower than the average for OECD countries.
The Bill will amend the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 to reduce the lowest marginal rate of tax, applying in the income range $5,401 to $20,700, from 21 per cent to 20 per cent.
This reduction will only apply for resident individuals and trustees.
As the change applies from 1 January 1991 a composite rate scale will apply for the 1990-91 financial year.

That scale will comprise a weighted average of one half of the rate scale applying from 1 July 1990 to 31 December 1990, and one half of the new rate scale that is to apply from 1 January to 30 June 1991.
The lower rate of tax will be reflected in pay-as-you-earn deductions from 1 January 1991.
It will not be used in the calculation or recalculation of 1990-91 provisional tax, but will be available to provisional taxpayers on assessment in 1991-92.
The cost to the revenue of the personal tax cuts is estimated at $430 million in 1990-91, and $1 billion in a full year.
Rebate for medical expenses

As a consequence of the reduction in the lowest marginal rate of tax from 21 to 20 per cent, which I have just mentioned, the level of the rebate of tax for net medical expenses exceeding $1,000 will be reduced to 20 per cent for 1991-92 and subsequent years.
The revenue savings from this measure are estimated at $2 million in a full year.
Capital Gains Tax

Capital gains tax rollover relief will be made more accessible for asset transfers in a company group. Existing anti-avoidance rules require the issue of shares or securities equal in value to the transferred asset as consideration for the transfer. Taxpayers and professional groups have made a number of representations over difficulties that company groups experience in reorganising their business affairs to meet these requirements.

The Government has considered the arguments put to it and has decided to replace the existing requirements with a new anti-avoidance provision-to be inserted by this Bill-that will deem a transferred asset to have been disposed of at market value if the group subsequently ceases to have effective control of the asset.

The Government believes that this change will make it easier for company groups to reorganise without suffering any adverse capital gains tax consequences, while still maintaining the Government's anti-avoidance objectives.

The Bill also proposes a number of technical measures to ensure that no artificial timing advantages are obtained by shareholders in a company as a result of the transfer of an asset to another group company for reduced consideration. At present, such asset transfers between 100 per cent commonly owned company groups can result in the early realisation of capital losses or reduced capital gains on the disposal of shares in the transferor company. Advantages can also arise in some cases in respect of loans made to the transferor company.

The Government believes that no taxpayer should obtain tax advantages by reason of an internal reorganisation of a company group's affairs, as a result of which assets are transferred within the group. To prevent this, the Bill proposes a series of cost base adjustments to shares or loans held, directly and indirectly, in the respective companies, that is, the transferor and transferee of the asset. The adjustments are intended to reflect changes in the value of shares or loans held within the group following the transfer of assets from one group company to another.

These provisions will generally apply only where actual consideration paid for the transfer of an asset is less than its indexed cost base or, if less, its market value. In other words, companies will be able to avoid the need to make any cost base adjustments by ensuring that consideration equal to the indexed cost base of an asset is paid for its transfer.

Finally, the Bill will make a number of technical amendments to make it clear that the capital gains tax consequences on the disposal of a partnership asset will be accounted for by the individual partners, and not by the partnership.

The capital gains tax rollover and partnership amendments will not substantially change the operation of the existing law and should have no revenue impact. The amendments to deny timing advantages for asset transfers between commonly owned companies will prevent significant but unquantifiable revenue losses.
Dividend imputation arrangements for life assurance companies

Under present law, tax paid by a company gives rise to a franking credit which may be used to frank dividends paid to shareholders. This is also the case for mutual life assurance companies and government insurance offices which have no shareholders to whom dividends can be paid.

Amendments contained in the Bill will give effect to the Budget announcement to deny mutual life assurance companies and government insurance offices the right to maintain a franking account, and cancel any surplus of franking credits held by them at 21 August 1990.

As also announced in the Budget, franking credits arising to non-mutual life assurance companies from the beginning of their next franking year on account of tax paid on the income from statutory fund business will be reduced by 80%.

These measures will stop double dipping of imputation credits and prevent the potential loss of significant but unquantifiable amounts of revenue. New shareholders of companies that were previously mutuals, or of privatised government insurance offices, will not have access to franking credits that arose before such companies changed their status.

The Bill will also give effect to the Government's decision that franking credits should arise to non-mutual life assurance companies for 20% of franked dividends paid on assets included in their insurance funds. This will apply to franked dividends received by the companies from the beginning of their next franking year.
Bereavement Payments

The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No.4) 1989 gave effect to a number of measures announced in the 1989-90 Budget, including a scheme of bereavement payments to either replace the tax exempt special temporary allowance and funeral benefit, or to make such payments in a number of situations not previously covered by the special temporary allowance.
This Bill will ensure that the taxation treatment of bereavement payments is broadly the same as the treatment which applied to the benefits they replaced.

Specifically, the Bill will exempt from tax the additional pension payment that is made following the death of a pensioner without a pensioner spouse, and the payment made to a third party in the situation where the death of the first deceased pensioner is not notified until after the spouse has also died. Further, the bereavement payment made following the death of a child to a person who was in receipt of a child related payment will also be exempt.

Sole parent's pension is now continued for 14 weeks after the death of the only qualifying child. These payments will continue to be included in assessable income. The continuation of carer's pension for 14 weeks after the death of the person being cared for (not being the carer's spouse), will be exempt in certain circumstances where the recipient is under age pension age.
The Bill will also exempt from tax the bereavement payment made to a widow or widower of a veteran or mariner who was in receipt of a disability pension.
The estimated cost to revenue of these proposals is less than $500,000 in a full year.
Foreign Source Income Measures

This Bill will give effect to the proposal announced in the Budget to extend the scope of certain special deduction provisions of the income tax law relating to capital expenditures incurred in particular activities or investments which take place in Australia.

Those provisions are to be broadened to allow these deductions for relevant capital expenditures incurred after 7.30 pm Eastern Standard Time on 21 August 1990 in the derivation of income that will be assessable in Australia.
In particular, the Bill will extend, in relation to foreign activities that generate assessable income-
* the deductions relating to mining and petroleum activities in Australia;
* the deductions for industrial property granted, registered or subsisting in Australia; and
* the deductions for capital expenditure on buildings in Australia.
It is estimated that the cost to revenue of extending these deductions will be less than $15 million in 1991-92 and subsequent years.

It was also announced in the Budget that, because of the way the income tax law dealing with bad debts is couched, it is arguable that a financial institution is entitled to an income tax deduction for bad debts of its foreign branch that are written off even though, under the proposed new foreign income measures, the income of the branch will generally be exempt from Australian income tax. Measures in this Bill will ensure that a deduction will not be allowable for bad debts in these circumstances.

An appropriate apportionment arrangement will apply where a relevant loan has been created or acquired after 7.30 pm Australian Eastern Standard Time on 21 August 1990, and some of the income derived from the loan debt will be assessable to Australian tax.
While there is no revenue gain or loss from this measure, it could be significant in protecting the revenue.

Other amendments contained in this Bill are directed at removing some potential for double taxation and correcting technical deficiencies in legislation now before the Parliament (the ``Foreign Income Bill''), and at removing tax avoidance avenues.

Some of these amendments are aimed at ensuring continuity in the capital gains tax treatment of assets when an entity either ceases to be or becomes an Australian resident. For the purpose of calculating the attributable income, the assets will be treated as having been disposed of and reacquired on the change of residence. This will ensure that no part of any capital gain is taxed twice.

Also to eliminate double taxation, income of a controlled foreign company (CFC) will not be attributed to Australian taxpayers where they hold interests in the CFC through another entity resident in a country that taxes the income under its accruals tax measures.

Other measures in the Bill will extend foreign tax credit and exemption arrangements to certain deemed dividends subject to appropriate notification within one year of the end of the relevant financial year. These credits and exemptions would then be available in much the same way as where an actual dividend is paid.

The definitions of ``exempting receipt'' and ``notional exempt income'' in the Foreign Income Bill are to be amended to ensure that premiums paid for insurance or reinsurance with non-residents are not categorised with income that has been subject to full rates of Australian tax. The cases covered are those where, under special provisions of our domestic law, only 10 per cent of the premium income is subject to Australian tax.

Changes being made to the foreign branch exemption provisions will create greater certainty about the time at which the tests for exemption are to be met, and close off tax avoidance opportunities. They will also align the treatment of foreign source capital gains and losses of an overseas branch of a resident company. This will be done by ensuring that a foreign capital loss is not available for offset against capital gains where, had that loss been a gain, it would have been exempt from tax.

Other measures in the Bill will close potential avoidance avenues by the use of interposed partnerships and trusts to prevent Australian residents being assessed on income from a CFC, and will allow a deduction for interest payable on certain convertible notes in calculating the attributable income of a CFC.

This Bill will also amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986, to effect minor technical changes consequential upon the proposed introduction-in the Foreign Income Bill-of a new system for the quarantining of foreign losses.
The revenue impact of the amendments to the foreign income measures is not quantifiable.
Protection of Information
The Bill will amend the provisions in the Taxation Administration Act in two respects.

The existing law makes it an offence for a person knowingly to take action to obtain information held under or for the purposes of a Commonwealth taxation law, unless the person does so in the course of exercising powers or performing functions under the law.

This is having the unintended effect of hindering enforcement activities by State and Territory taxation authorities who, for purposes of their own revenue laws, are seeking access to information collected by businesses and used for the purposes of a Commonwealth taxation law.

The law will be changed so that an offence is committed if a person takes action other than in authorised circumstances to obtain access to records containing information about a person's affairs, but only if those records are in the possession of the Commissioner of Taxation and are held by the Commissioner for the purposes of a Commonwealth taxation law.

The relevant provision will no longer operate to prohibit access to records that are in the possession of someone other than the Commissioner. The amendment will not adversely affect the confidentiality of tax file number or other personal information as the taxation and criminal laws contain safeguards which ensure that any unauthorised conduct in these areas is an offence.

Finally, the law will be strengthened to create an additional offence if a person uses information in respect of another person's affairs held by the Commissioner, where the information was obtained by breach of a taxation law.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Brownhill) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the luncheon adjournment I was speaking on the Appropriation Bill which, as we all know, was to source extra funds for the commitment we have in the Gulf and also to cover the shortfall of credit payments or insurance payments for wheat. I was making the point that not only do we have on our hands a crisis in the Gulf and a crisis in the wool industry and in the wheat industry, but we certainly have a crisis and a battle on our hands in Australia with our economy. Indeed, before the luncheon adjournment I was talking about the decline in the small business sector and the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was not prepared to say when the decline would bottom out.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that falling consumer spending, rapidly escalating unemployment and crippling interest rates have resulted in over 11,000 small businesses being forced into bankruptcy in the 1990 calendar year. This figure is up some 32 per cent on 1989 and, as I have indicated on previous occasions in this chamber, the actual figures do not reflect the true situation because they do not indicate the countless number of people who have simply just closed up shop and walked away while they are still able.

The Confederation of Australian Industry has recently released its barometer of economic activity for January 1991. The aim of the barometer is to provide an objective test by which Australia's overall performance against other industrialised economies can be gauged. It is a means by which Australia's relative performance can be assessed. Not surprisingly, Australia's current ranking on that barometer is 10 out of 10. I seek leave to incorporate this table in Hansard.
