TALK.START.PARA: —The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The data in the accompanying table shows that the Australian economy is the worst performing economy amongst the ten major economies surveyed. When the same analysis was conducted in October, Australia's ranking was seventh. As at January, Australia is dead last.

The report accompanying the barometer makes it clear that Australia has a huge potential which is not being tapped. I think my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne referred to that just a few moments ago. We are now in the bottom place, trailing New Zealand in those 10 economies.

I note that in the Mercury of 5 February 1991, the National Director of the Australian Small Business Association, Mr Peter Boyle, makes no bones about the disastrous consequences which the members of his Association are experiencing because of the drastic slump in the economy. Employment in manufacturing fell by 2.9 per cent between August 1989 and August last year. On an individual basis, it fell by a further 42,500 in the month of October.

The Australian Director of the Chamber of Manufacturers, Mr Graham Chalker, reflects the views of many in the manufacturing sector when he says that his industry is unlikely to pick up in the first half of this year. Similarly, the Chief Executive of the Metal Trades Industry Association, Mr Bert Evans, has indicated that there are no signs this year of anything to make him optimistic about a quick recovery.

In my own State of Tasmania, during the period 1989-90 there were some 440 bankruptcies, of which approximately one-third related to small business with the rest being individual bankruptcies. For the September and December quarters of last year that figure was already 212, indicating that a future rise is inevitable.

In conclusion, we have a crisis and it is not just in the Middle East, it is here at home. The whole nation has a fight on its hands. While the Australian Democrats may be speaking, as they did this morning, about rehabilitating Iraq after the war, I would ask the question: who is going to rehabilitate this country?
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91 I think it is very important to note that there are certain sections of it which are worthy of support and others which are not worthy of support. For example, the roughly $6m which is allocated to this special support for the forces in the Gulf, I would support. These people are taking great risks, not of their own choosing but of the choosing of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Because those people are there, doing the bidding of the Prime Minister-obeying the Prime Minister's order to go to war-I support that part of the allocation. I do not believe that they should be penalised or suffer in any way for their contribution although, of course, I totally oppose the fact that we are having to spend any extra money whatsoever because the Prime Minister has decided that this country should go to war. That is the only exception that I would make to this funding. I think the rest of the defence expenditure should not be an extra allocation, but should come out of the defence budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The rest of the money which is to be allocated for compensation for lost trade, particularly for our farmers, is worthy of support because, as I have said so often, I believe sanctions were the appropriate way to make sure that Iraq withdrew from Kuwait. The use of force was not necessary. Our farmers, who are under great attack and at great risk from the policies of the United States, I might add, should be compensated.

I do not think that the defence part of the budget-with the exception of that $6m or so that I referred to-should be coming out of Consolidated Revenue. It should be coming off the existing defence budget. I know some people will say that the defence budget is already strapped and we do not have enough money to defend Australia. I maintain that if we spend our money wisely and cut back on some of the unnecessary expenditure items-such as the submarine project which is $5.6 billion-that kind of cut would more than adequately provide for this war game with very serious consequences that the Prime Minister has engaged in. No money whatsoever should be going out of Consolidated Revenue for this special defence expenditure.

As well as the cost to the defence forces, the other negative side of the expenditure is that there will not be moneys available for social programs and for other rescue operations that are needed to ensure that the rural sector does not go completely down the gurgler. Other elements in Australian society will suffer because of this expenditure out of Consolidated Revenue.

The other aspect that has to be taken into account is the situation with the nations which are recipients of Australian aid, many of which are suffering indirectly because of the Gulf war. They are suffering because they are not getting the remissions that the workers who were previously engaged in Kuwait and Iraq-the people who have had to leave in their hundreds and thousands-were sending back to their families.

I would submit that any extra money that the Government is requesting to come out of Consolidated Revenue for this war exercise at the Prime Minister's bidding, should not be going to defence, but that an equal amount should be going to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade because there will be so many costs and consequences of this war.

It is pathetic to note that so far the Foreign Minister has allocated a miserable $2m to the refugee program. Let us put that against the total amount that is being requested here today in the special appropriations. While we are paying roughly $56m for the killing operation, $2m has so far been allocated for the refugees, who will be an ongoing problem for a very long time. The direct costs that we can see now are not the only problems of this dangerous and totally immoral engagement in war in the Middle East. The others will be longstanding and will come back over time into the future. We will have further requests for the casualties.

We are creating another generation of veterans when we have not dealt with the last ones adequately. It is very significant that the Vietnam veterans in the United States are amongst the most vocal critics of the United States Government's policy in sending the United States forces to war. They are making a plea-a very heartfelt plea-not to create another generation of veterans when the last generation has not been dealt with. It is important for the Senate to know that more veterans-leftovers from the Vietnam war-have committed suicide than were killed in action in that war. That is a huge total. Over 50,000 people, mostly men, who served in Vietnam were shattered emotionally, physically and psychologically by that experience. More of them have taken their own lives since that war than died in the war. We are likely to create another generation of veterans in the same way.

Once this ground war starts, which the United States seems absolutely intent upon, there will be massive casualties on both sides. As has already been demonstrated in this war, atrocities have been committed by both sides; the Iraqi atrocities in the first place going into Kuwait and, of course, the bombing of the civilians in the bomb shelter in Baghdad last week-just to mention one, and I am sure there have been others that have not come to light-resulting in the killing of several hundred civilians, mostly women and children. There is no doubt that we are creating enormous social, psychological and physical problems amongst the people who will be the ongoing suffering victims of this war-that is, quite apart from the dead ones who will never come home except in body bags.

This will not be the last time when extra appropriations will be called for to pay for this folly, if we could use such a mild word to describe a war. It will be the first of many times that extra appropriations will be called for to pay for this disastrous policy of the Prime Minister of Australia to blindly follow the United States Administration into a war.

It is very interesting to note that, on the 7.30 Report on Monday night in relation to the United States, the President of the National Farmers Federation quite clearly stated that, with friends like these, who needs enemies. He said that the United States pricing program was cutting Australia out of the market and that it was having a disastrous effect on the wheat farmers in particular. This is not the first time that the agricultural policy of the United States has worked to the detriment of Australian farmers. It is not the first time that the National Farmers Federation has spoken out against it. It is not the first time that it has suggested that we should not follow so blindly the United States foreign policy which gets us into this enormous difficulty. The National Farmers Federation understands that the livelihood of its members is at risk. It is very likely now that the Government will not even accede to the requests from the rural lobby to get it out of this trouble, other than to pay compensation, which is part of the Appropriations Bill, which I support.

It is also interesting that the Prime Minister is considering sending an all-party delegation to the United States on a trade mission to see what can be done to talk to the United States about its rural policy. I can imagine how much notice will be taken of that delegation: absolutely no notice whatsoever, because the Prime Minister has already committed us to join with the United States-led forces in the Gulf. He is quite happy to do that and yet he is quite careless about the plight of Australian farmers on the other hand, and he is quite prepared to pay lip service to a trade mission which he knows very well will get nowhere whatsoever because the United States Administration knows that it has Australia exactly where it wants it. The United States has never taken much notice of the Australian rural lobby. Why should it begin to do that now when it has the full support of the Prime Minister in this war machine that is raging so outrageously in the Middle East?

I now want to look at the military implications of these extra costs. Firstly, this represents an addition to the defence budget which, as I said earlier, I do not think should be counted for a moment. I only wish real social needs in the Australian community along with the overseas aid budget could have these extras tacked on in response to the economic recession. For some reason the military always gets the positive nod while other departments come under the intense scrutiny of the cost cutters.

This is a very expensive war. The types of weapons involved cost millions of dollars or more apiece. If any of these weapons are used by Australian warships, we shall face an additional appropriations request to pay for replacing them at a future date. It also means greater dependence on the United States military, which supplies us with these expensive, high-tech weapons.

In addition, I must question the way in which the Prime Minister got us into this war last August by volunteering our ships for service with the United States Navy, without even being asked and with minimal consultation with his Ministers. In fact, the truth of the embarrassing matter is that in conversation mark I with George Bush-I do not know who rang whom; it does not matter much any more-he offered five Royal Australian Navy (RAN) ships to the United States and the Navy had to say to him, `Prime Minister we do not have five ships to send'. So his great enthusiasm had to be curbed. It was quite an outrageous situation for the Prime Minister to jump in with both feet without even having consulted his Ministers, without even having consulted the Department of Defence in this country.

Even then it was obvious that the costs would escalate and the longer the war drags on, the more it will cost, especially if weapons are fired by Royal Australian Navy warships. Of course, some have been but I fear that there is more to come. As I said, despite the Soviet initiative, despite the attempts to get an unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait by Iraq-which I believe Iraq wants because it sees that it has been almost decimated-we should be working towards a negotiated settlement so that the human and financial costs of this war do not drag on.

It is also important to remind the Senate that this is not a United Nations-led war, in the correct sense of the word, as the Secretary-General himself has said. If that were so, the United Nations command force structure would have been put in place. In the first place, when Bob Hawke so generously made the original offer of the five Australian warships, no United Nations resolutions had been passed on the subject, so it was not to support the United Nations resolution.

Of course, the militarists have suffered quite a setback in the past 18 months or so, before this war became imminent. With the demise of the Cold War, militarists and arms manufacturers were probably beginning to panic about what they would do with all of their expertise and high-tech weapons, and all of their men and women in uniform. They have certainly found a use now for all of their expensive equipment and for their person power as well. It is a great shame that this is happening when the world was on the brink of finding another way to solve important international disputes.

It is also important to note that one of the major differences between this war and the Vietnam war-the last one in which Australia was engaged on the coat-tails of the United States-was that the United States military machine has sanitised the viewing so totally that we see only the high-tech weaponry and the maps on the screens as though this is a big game to be played out in a video shop. We are not seeing the real casualties of this war. The amount of saturation bombing of Iraq that has been done by this time must mean that the country is completely potholed, particularly in Baghdad. Why are the allies continuing to bomb Baghdad? It is totally irresponsible and totally unacceptable.

The Gulf war has not only meant extra cash for the militarists but also it has helped to trigger off a new debate about the relevance of the 1986 report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the 1987 Defence White Paper in this country. The warrior class, who proclaim the virtues of peace through strength within the framework of the new world order-what a great euphemism that is; it sounds like the old order revisited, when the only way to solve a problem is to fight-seek to go back to the good old days of forward defence. Australia's defence requirements will be tailored to the needs of the United States military as it extends its role of the world's policeman with or without the endorsement of the United Nations Security Council.

In terms of the United States manipulation and bullying of the United Nations, it is important to remind people that for so many years it was the United States that refused to pay its dues to United Nations organisations. It deliberately set out to undermine this international organisation because it did not like smaller countries having their say. It wanted to maintain its power, which it has now demonstrated through manipulation of the Security Council. So the United States deserves the strongest of criticism for manipulating that international body-first of all, for ignoring it for years and now using it to its own end. It is urgently in need of reform. The United Nations was not set up to go to war. The last time it went to war was in Korea and the Korean people are still suffering for that gross error of the United Nations. We thought that it would never happen again, but it has because of this bullying on behalf of the United States and that has to stop. In future one of the postwar reconstruction measures surely has to be a reform of the United Nations and particularly of the Security Council.

This all has grave implications for our force structure. Clearly we would need to invest in more expensive and heavy warships to serve with the United States Navy a long way from our shores. I contend that we do not need to do this. If the defence of Australia is about the defence of Australia, we do not need to be building submarines, for example. It could also mean extra costs for new kinds of aircraft and all manner of other military requirements for all three branches of the armed services. There are no foreseeable direct threats to Australia and it is hard to imagine any. What we must do is ensure that no threats emerge. That is why we need greater attention paid to foreign affairs budgeting. We need adequate funding to ensure that we remain on very good terms with all our neighbours. It is a much better way of dealing with our international neighbourhood than preparing for war.

Most wars at the moment are civil wars or wars of liberation, many having their origin in disputes over arbitrary colonial boundaries. If Australia's defence needs for the future are going to be tailored primarily to the requirements of the United States version of the new world order, we are likely to be sending ships, planes and personnel to all corners of the world where United States interests are at stake-that is, if it manages to bully and manipulate the United Nations in the future. It is not appropriate for the United Nations to be seen as a warmongering force. A peacekeeping force is a different thing altogether and I would support that. But wherever resource disputes emerge, if what has happened recently in the United Nations is played out again, the United Nations will be almost constantly on a war footing. That would be a grave injustice to the many people in the world who are malnourished, ill-housed and undereducated, and particularly to the world's children.

There are certain conflicts that will not figure as a concern for this kind of intervention. We shall not be called upon to assist in the liberation of East Timor or West Papua. That is because the United States is not particularly interested in those areas. Nor shall we be called upon to liberate Tibet or the north of Cyprus. But these are all countries which could argue, in the same way that Kuwait did, that they were invaded by a larger neighbour. The hypocrisy of this whole exercise is absolutely staggering. I doubt too whether our Services would be required to evict the Israelis from the occupied territories or southern Lebanon. This is an issue which is going to pain the world for decades to come and it will be exacerbated by the war that has erupted in the Gulf at the moment. If the Palestine question had been put on the agenda in August when it was first suggested we may never have resorted to war.

Whatever the conflicts, they will not pose a direct threat to Australia, but some conflicts will be justified in the same terms as the Government justifies Australia's military presence in the Gulf. But it will be very selective, as it has been in the past, depending on orders from Washington. That for me, as an Australian, is a very sad admission to have to make-that we have no independence, we have no sovereignty, when it comes to deciding these really important issues. We follow blindly. Maybe with another leader we would not, but with our current leader I am afraid that is what we are committed to doing. I think that is a great tragedy and a great shame for this nation and it is time we learnt to be independent. We have the capacity to be independent and to be a peacemaking nation in this region of the world instead of following along on the coat-tails of the United States.

This is why I have argued for an alternative strategy of coastal defence within the framework of regional common security and support for non-military forms of conflict resolution. A genuine United Nations force is very different from the current cashbox coalition in the Gulf and Australia's contribution to a United Nations force would be very different from the token RAN deployment in the Gulf. I say `token' because the major contribution that Australia is making to this war is via the United States bases on Australian soil-Pine Gap and Nurrungar-which are feeding satellite pictures, intercepting military messages, and feeding information to the cashbox coalition so that it can sometimes accurately get its targeting right. I think it is a great shame, again, that we are involved in the process of directly being responsible for the killing of innocent Iraqi citizens.

I do not want to be misinterpreted. I have said this in every speech and I must say it again, so I am not misinterpreted as being an appeaser: I do believe that Saddam Hussein should be moved out of Kuwait, but not by force. I do not accept the notion that there is any reward for Saddam Hussein's aggression in sanctions being given more time to work. They would have worked. When I asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) whether he could guarantee that war would work any quicker than sanctions, he gave a very confused reply indeed. There is no guarantee that war will work any quicker than sanctions. There is no guarantee that war will solve any of these problems. Certainly there is no guarantee that we will get a better peace or stability in the Middle East having resorted to violence in this way. It is going to deepen the enmities and that is the tragedy of it.

I would much rather increase funding for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade at the expense of the military budget so that we could upgrade our diplomatic role in the world and assist in the building of a genuine new world order based on non-military forms of conflict resolution, equitable trading relationships and a just payment for resources. As I said at the beginning, I am not opposed to extra funds for the military personnel serving in the Gulf, but I do question the extra funding to the Department of Defence, apart from that which is going to the service men and women. I am very concerned about any future contingencies along these lines. As I have said, I do not think that this will be the first call for extra cash.

I want to quote the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, AIDAB, in terms of some of the countries that are going to be suffering within our direct area of influence-some of the countries that we traditionally give aid to-and which are suffering right now because of the consequences of this war. For example, in the Philippines the loss of remittances and reduced rice production due to losses of up to 70 per cent of urea fertiliser imports are major effects. A Philippines assistance plan donor conference is to be held at the end of February and requests for additional assistance in light of the Gulf war are expected. I wonder whether Australia will cough up there.

Secondly, in Bangladesh, the Finance Minister estimates losses to total $400m to $500m, comprising $200m for increased oil prices, $160m lost as remittances, $36m as cost of repatriation and $120m in lost trade and commerce. Thirdly, in Vietnam-a country which we should have been paying reparations money to for a long time but have been particularly stingy about-the main loss has been through loss of remittances but it has also been affected by costs of repatriation and oil price rises. The estimated loss is $100m.

Fourthly, Sri Lanka has had a loss of remittances and tea exports. Remittances totalled 47 per cent of foreign exchange in Sri Lanka. Fifty-five per cent of tea exports normally go to the Middle East, but sanctions have caused loss of those markets which are the other major source of foreign exchange. The Australian Council for Overseas Aid, ACFOA, requests that the Australian Government make an additional allocation of $15m to cover these costs.

These are the sorts of international responsibilities which we should be meeting instead of paying extra into the defence budget. We should be aware of the fact that this war is costing our near neighbours, who are in dire straits already, dearly. That is what our extra allocation of funding should be going towards if we have any streak of humanitarianism in us whatsoever.

The Gulf war has imposed additional hardships on certain Third World countries, apart from those I have mentioned. The World Bank estimates that the Gulf war has already cost developing countries a loss equal to 60 per cent of all the aid they receive. African countries facing tragic famines, whose problems are overshadowed and given low priority by the world community, are also victims of the Gulf war. While the causes are deep rooted, the case for immediate assistance to threatened people is incontestable on any humanitarian grounds. But I hear a deafening silence from the Government about extra moneys to help pay for our less fortunate neighbours and countries to which we give some aid, but not nearly enough.

As a participant in the Gulf war, Australia has a particular responsibility to ensure that developing countries seriously affected by the conflict are given additional assistance. This is particularly the case because many of those countries are in the Asian region. Australia's relationships with these countries need special attention at this very difficult time. If supplementary funding for Gulf war related expenses is to be provided to the Department of Defence, equivalent funding should be provided to the aid bureau to deal with related economic and social costs of the war to the underdeveloped world.

The major powers in the coalition have in common an indecent thirst for oil and the United States Government in particular has resisted for many years initiatives aimed at introducing measures to conserve oil. If the United States had invested the money it actually spent on Operation Desert Shield in the last five months of 1990 into saving oil, it could eliminate all of its oil imports from the Persian Gulf. That would have eliminated one of the reasons for having got into this war. It is by no means the only one, of course. The main reason is power, which is associated with the thirst for oil, the greed for oil and dependence on oil. With 5 per cent of the world's population, the United States consumes 25 per cent of the world's oil. It is greed and gluttony in the extreme. Underdeveloped countries are now paying for this obsession.

So, there are many social reasons as well as defence related reasons why this war should be stopped. It should also be stopped for environment reasons, which I have only a couple of minutes to address. On environmental grounds alone this war ought to be stopped right now. There is going to be a huge cost in environmental terms for the clean-up operation, for the environmental vandalism that has been committed already with the release of oil into the Persian Gulf--

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom?

—By Iraq. Oil fires will probably begin when the ground war gets under way. I point out to Senator Newman that these atrocities happen on both sides. An enormous amount of pollution is pumped into the atmosphere every time a plane takes off. If Senator Newman knew anything about greenhouse emissions, she would know that it is extraordinarily expensive to the global atmosphere to have all of those planes taking off and dropping their bombs in the Middle East. So on environmental grounds alone, this war must stop. Both sides are guilty of environmental vandalism.

SPEECH.PARA: For these reasons I intend to conscientiously abstain from voting on this legislation. I will not vote against the Bill because I am not opposed to extra payments being made to personnel in the Gulf. I think I have made clear that I am opposed to the principle, along with my concern for the way in which the decision to send the ships was originally made without reference to the Parliament or the Australian community. It is because of this decision that these extra costs have been incurred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91 is about spending money. It is about spending money now on what I believe are the short term tangible military costs of war-costs that can be neatly ruled off in a ledger; costs which have been incurred by the decision of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to commit our country to war. This is a decision with which I disagree.

SPEECH.PARA: In January in my speech in this place I questioned the morality of priorities which allow the spending of $500m a day by the allied countries on Operation Desert Storm. To this point, an estimated $50 billion has been spent, which is equal to the total annual flow of aid from all sources to the developing countries.

I want to focus on that aspect again today. But before doing so, let me place on record my support for the appropriation of compensation for discontinued payments by Iraq on its wheat debt. I have always maintained that it is unfair for any one section of our society to bear the brunt of the policy of imposing sanctions-a policy I support. Bearing the brunt of sanctions has been a significant contributing factor in the rural crisis which is crippling farming families throughout this nation, and this did need to be acknowledged and action taken.

As we have the opportunity to debate the appropriateness of particular expenditure, I would like to question the Government's commitment to pay for the less tangible long term costs of war-the ones that we will not find under `Defence' in the ledger. The human cost of the Gulf war is immense and growing. Untold lives are lost, up to two million refugees are expected and the livelihoods of millions of people in developing countries are affected as a result of guest workers being forced to flee. The Gulf war is making a cruel contribution to increasing global poverty and environmental destruction.

The World Bank estimates that the Gulf war has already cost developing countries $US30 billion. Third World trade with the Gulf countries has also been affected. For example, Sri Lanka's major overseas markets were Kuwait and Iraq, accounting for annual trade worth more than $A50m.

Innocent civilians, as always, are the victims of war. Humanitarian needs are escalating in countries neighbouring Iraq as thousands continue to flee the fighting. The international community, of which we are a part, should and must respond. But the depressed state of the world's economy means that funds are not available to assist people in need. Aid for victims of this war is being taken from programs to assist other needy people around the world.

Australia's announced $4m worth of aid to the victims of war is, of course, welcome. But the tragedy is that it will be taken from programs to assist the victims of famines and emergencies in Africa and elsewhere. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that between 300,000 and two million refugees will flee the Gulf war. It is anticipated that the cost of providing food, shelter and clothing for these refugees will top $US175m. Funding the refugee aid program in Iran, Jordan, Syria and Turkey will drain much needed funds for refugee assistance in Africa, Asia and Central America.

The world food program estimates that 27 million people in 25 African countries are now threatened by famine and that these people need 3.9 million tonnes of food aid. Global poverty and environmental degradation are two sides of the same coin. Failed rains, denuded hillsides and loss of soil compound human suffering. Because of this war, these issues are not gaining the international attention that they urgently require.

Janet Hunt of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid has said that the only proper response is for additional bilateral and multilateral aid to be made available. She also said that speeding up loans and disbursements may help in the short term but, for deeply indebted countries, this merely piles debt on debt. She pointed out that the long term consequences-and these are the ones that we really must take into account-will be devastating for the poorest, who will be squeezed most when governments cut funding.

Western donors and Gulf allies have pledged $13 billion in assistance to be paid by 1992. However, $10.5 billion of that will be restricted to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. So this obviously has political strings attached to it.

So we have to ask: what is to happen to meet the needs of the innocent victims of war? Do we have to have a lottery to determine who is the most needy? These are the long term costs of war which are rarely factored into the real equation. I look forward to a Bill appropriating a similar $57m urgently required by the victims of this war, victims as both a direct and an indirect consequence of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq. That is the same reason the Government has given for our need to appropriate that same amount of money at this time. When we see this Bill we will know that our priorities have shifted somewhat.

In closing, let me restate the Democrats' position: we will be supporting this Bill because we see a clear distinction between the political decision to send troops to war-a decision with which we disagree-and the reality of supporting those troops in their own defence while they are in a war zone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not planned to take part in this debate until I heard Senator Vallentine giving us the anti-American diatribe that she did a few minutes ago. I was so incensed that I felt obliged to make some comments, although they will be pretty brief. Unlike Senator Vallentine's contribution, it is not a written speech prepared ahead of time. It might be somewhat incoherent, but it is also very annoyed.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard Senator Vallentine say something to the effect that this is a war at the bidding of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Although I am a member of the Opposition, I take grave exception to that. This Parliament has voted on the question of this war and both chambers of this Parliament have decided that this war is something which we support. Seventyfour per cent of the Australian population are now considered to support Western involvement in this war. In fact, 66 per cent of the Australian Democrats' supporters support this war. If Senator Vallentine considers herself to be described as `others', 59 per cent of her `others' support Western involvement in this war. So let there be no doubt about it; this is not a war at the Prime Minister's bidding; this is a war that the people of Australia and the Parliament of Australia support.

Senator Vallentine also mentioned that the United States Vietnam veterans are opposing this war. I interjected, but I am afraid I did not seem to get the point across to her that some certainly are opposing this war but that does not mean the Vietnam veterans of America are opposing it, and the same can be said in Australia. While some people oppose it, others do not. We heard a lot of concern for the civil victims of this war. I am concerned for those too, of course, as any thinking person must be. I am also concerned about those young men and women that we and the free nations of the Western world are sending to do our bidding on behalf of the peace and security of the people in Kuwait, who seem to have been sadly neglected in Senator Vallentine's speech. It is only very near to the end that I can remember her mentioning the people of Kuwait at all.

I was roused to speak because Senator Vallentine touched on the words `Vietnam veteran'. I am sick and tired of having the Vietnam veterans used in this emotive sort of debate. I am the wife of a Vietnam veteran. I spent a year with, if you like, a real bleeding heart, but I am sick and tired of having Senator Vallentine parade her bleeding heart on behalf of Vietnam veterans. I know better than she could ever know what it is to send somebody one loves away to war and worry about that person for the whole time he or she is away. My heart goes out to those families that are now in that position in this country and in the countries of the free world, but I still say it is right and proper that this country should have service men and women on duty in the Gulf.

Senator Vallentine talked also about suicides. This is part of why I was talking about the bleeding heart of Senator Vallentine. Let it be quite clearly understood that that high incidence of suicides from the men who returned from Vietnam is largely due to the treatment they were given by this country-and by America-when they returned home. The rejection and the inhumanity that they suffered, and the fact that we had to have a welcome home march 20 years after they came back, was quite disgraceful. No wonder people have found it very hard to adjust to a life of peace in a peaceful society such as ours.

So Senator Vallentine and her supporters are treading on dangerous ground when they use the Vietnam veterans for their own purposes. Those of them who harass and attack our service personnel who are serving in the Gulf and/or their families are on dangerous ground. It is a misguided attempt to criticise the Government by getting stuck into the defence forces. They should have learned by what happened to the Vietnam veterans and contain their criticism of our engagement to the political process and not to the people whose duty it is to serve the will of their duly elected government.

In this debate we are debating, amongst other things, the money being appropriated for our defence commitment. When we are considering putting more money into the expenditure on defence-and properly so on this occasion-there is a need not to forget the veterans of the previous wars who are still needing attention and are being treated quite abominably in some cases. We are seeing a steady whittling away of some of the care and concern and entitlements of veterans from previous wars. It is an appropriate moment to remember them and to take it upon ourselves to see that they are looked after better. There is this indecent haste to integrate the repatriation hospitals into the State hospitals of Australia when those State hospitals are already overburdened with large queues, particularly in Melbourne and Sydney, with people having long waiting times. We are talking about elderly people who are being asked to join very long queues when they too in their time fought for this country. We have a history of having sent people away with flags flying and prime ministerial speeches and, as the years go by, tending to expect them to be treated as welfare recipients and not compensate them for the damage which their war service has done to them.

Only late last year we were involved in having to disallow the third Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions, or GARP 3-generally accepted accounting principles-in this chamber when the Federal Government was trying to change the lifestyle calculations for veterans. It was a cruel hoax that was being pulled on the veterans community through that so-called efficiency move. We should all be alert in this place to these gradual changes to the entitlements of those who fought in previous wars. Only last week we had yet another reminder that we must be vigilant when it comes to things that are precious to veterans. I am thinking now of the Australian War Memorial and the attempt to charge to enter a memorial to our dead.

The thing that also continues to concern me is the apparent change of focus which is occurring at the War Memorial away from a memorial to our dead to other purposes such as social history. This is not the opportunity now, I think, to get into that area, but it is something which we in the Parliament must be alert to. They are all very relevant to what we do when we send men and women away to war. We have a responsibility to them, to their interests and to their care that goes on forever, and we must not, in having them away there now, think that by voting some extra money to make sure they have their supplies we have done all we need for them.

We have people serving on those ships who, for the first time in Australia's history, will not be entitled to a war service loan. That is just incredible. It is the first time in Australia's history that such people will not automatically be entitled to a war service loan. I say `automatically' because there are some older people on the ships or on exchange with foreign units who may be entitled under the old defence service home loan scheme. But the youngsters will not have a war service loan entitlement. It is quite incredible.

We have reservists who have not been called up, so the Government hides behind the fact that they are volunteers. They have been in the reserves for years. They have gone away as senior surgeons and anaesthetists. They are subsidising their own war effort by up to $30,000 to look after our personnel and to give them medical care if they are seriously injured. Those people are financing their own contribution to the war because the Government refuses to reimburse them for the costs incurred in their practices while they are away.

Senator Vallentine also talked about the video game aspect of this war. It has become a fashionable cliche to talk about that. But every time I hear somebody talking about precision bombing and how it all looks a bit like a video game, I think of the years that have gone into training those people, because those weapon systems do not operate themselves. Behind every bomb that gets away, a human being has to have his place. There is no weapon of war that can operate without some human input. In peacetime we should not begrudge the money that is spent on training our personnel because it is only in times like now that we suddenly find out how vital that training is. If our people were up in the air doing the bombing in Iraq, we would be wanting to make sure that they were precision bombers, that they did protect the lives of as many Iraqi citizens as possible, and that they did hit the military targets that they were given. That cannot be done in the last minute when war is suddenly upon us.

Again, Senator Vallentine talked about the warrior class. I was not too sure whether she was referring to the military-as she so often does, as if they are some lesser level of mortals-or whether she meant those of us in here who talk about peace through strength and who are concerned to see that the money needed for defence is spent consistently year in year out so that we are not caught unprepared and so that Australia will not be in the position that Kuwait has found itself in. I think the people of Kuwait could answer Senator Vallentine in her criticism of those of us who believe in peace through strength. It is only through strength that there is any chance of winning Kuwait back. It is only through the strength of friends such as Australia that there is any chance of those people winning back their homeland from the aggressor.

I have said that she does not seem to have much concern for the people of Kuwait, and there was very little mention of them, but she was suggesting that we could somehow get the Iraqis and Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait by non-military means. Talking seems to have done little or no good and sanctions seem to have done little or no good. I am wondering whether she wants to sing them out or point the bone at them so they fade away. Whatever it is, she has not given us any real option as to how we can get Saddam Hussein and his military people out of Kuwait. After all, that is the crux of the matter. We are there to do our bit in helping to get them out of Kuwait.

Our defence needs are to do whatever we possibly can in our country to protect ourselves. Senator Vallentine spoke of our defence needs. I think the lesson of the sudden conflagration in the Middle East is one that we should take to heart. If we are going to be able to defend our country effectively, we must be able to protect ourselves. It costs money. We cannot be self-reliant just by wishing; it needs resources. Senator Vallentine's alternative is totally, utterly naive and she will not listen to reason. Unfortunately, she has some disciples who can subvert, if they are allowed to, our will to defend ourselves and our ability to defend ourselves. We seem so often to ignore the lessons of those who have gone before us-the generations before us-who could have told Senator Vallentine and her followers what happens when we wish for peace but do not prepare for peace in order to defend it.

I would love to think that we could change Senator Vallentine's attitude and that of her supporters. Sadly, when I listened to that long speech-the anti-American attitude and the disgraceful suggestion that we in Australia owe reparations to Vietnam-I thought that there is little chance that those of us who see another way for Australia's future could ever change her attitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a debate on the second reading of the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1990-91. This Bill has been brought forward by the Government to provide an extra $234.1m of funds in the Budget year 1990-91. The motive giving rise to the Bill is, of course, expenditures that the Government could not foresee at Budget time when it framed its last Budget. One is, notably, the rise of conflict in the Middle East, in the Persian Gulf, and the commitment that Australia has made to that theatre of operations and, as a consequence of that commitment, this Bill contains an appropriation of $181.4m for payment by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to meet insurance claims associated with defaults by Iraq on credit sales by the Australian Wheat Board which were insured under the national interest provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act.

SPEECH.PARA: It also contains an appropriation of $52.7m for the Department of Defence to meet equipment and stores expenditure associated with the deployment of elements of the Defence Force in the Middle East. In total, the supplementation for defence costs associated with the Gulf deployment, being a matter of some conjecture and speculation in the press, amounts, we can now say authoritatively, to $68.9m in 1990-91. The balance of $16.2m will be included in the Additional Estimates. A further $27.5m will be provided in subsequent years-$23.6m in 1991-92 and $3.9m in 1992-93.

The Government is, of course, as the proposer of this Bill, in support of it. The Liberal Party-National Party coalition has supported the Bill as well. The Australian Democrats support the Bill. The only opposition to it is in the form of a conscientious abstention from voting by the independent Senator from Western Australia, Senator Vallentine.

A number of the speakers in this debate have used the occasion of this legislation to speak not to the point of the legislation but about the general issue of the war in the Gulf. They have chosen to do so because, clearly, this is a matter of great public interest, of firm national resolve by this country, and because it is a matter that engenders continual passions in some sectors of the community about whether our commitment should have been made or whether it should have been made in a different form.

I do not intend to answer the debates about the war, but I acknowledge that the honourable senators who have joined in that debate hold those views conscientiously. I do not criticise them for that. Where they conflict with Government policy, of course, I think that they are wrong. Where they support us, clearly they are right. It is not for me, as Minister, to now redebate the issues that Parliament was reconvened for on two days in January to debate it in total then.

In summing up, having thanked the contributors to the debate, I would like to take up a couple of points raised earlier by speakers in the debate when they focused on this Bill and the contents of it. Firstly, it is important to stress that the amount of money that the Government has sought in this Bill for payment to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to meet insurance claims associated with defaults by Iraq on credit sales by the Australian Wheat Board results from Australia's observation of the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on 2 August last year.

In the debate the Government has also been criticised for failing to take account of that invasion in the 1990-91 Budget. I think that most honourable senators would acknowledge that the Commonwealth Budget is a very complex set of documents requiring significant effort by both Ministers and their Departments for its compilation. It would be a major task now, in view of the hostilities in the Gulf, to recast the Budget in its entirety, as seemed to be the point of the criticism of some of the speakers.

That is a major task to do; to do it before the normal bringing down of a Budget in August is a task of almost unbelievable complexity. I think it is also fair to point out that the Government could not have been expected to foresee the events of last month back in the first week of August last year. Had Iraq withdrawn from Kuwait shortly after its invasion, as the United Nations enjoined it to do, there would not have been a requirement for this present Bill. The Government chose to assess the situation as it unfolded and developed rather than change its Budget, having declared its Budget precipitately and at the time perhaps needlessly, given that it was always possible during the period of the sanctions that the Iraqi dictatorship would have seen the error of its ways and made what I think would have been the most humane decision and withdrawn to avoid the conflict that has ensued.

I now turn to the question of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I draw to the attention of honourable senators the `urgent and unforeseen criterion' for the Advance to the Minister for Finance, which specifies that the expenditure is to be urgently required and `unforeseen until the last day on which it was practicable to include appropriation for that expenditure in the Bill for this Act' before the introduction of the Bill into the House of Representatives. In other words, there is an emergency pool that can be called upon if unforeseen circumstances arise.

Given the time needed to finalise and print Appropriation Bills, this effectively means a week or two prior to the date of introduction. It would take at least that length of time to ready a Bill in unforeseen circumstances. It seems prudent to me to make a provision such as this so that in the event of circumstances that are not predictable the Government can respond immediately.

The Bills obviously cannot include provision for items in advance of the Government reaching considered decisions on them and hence there will be a need to have recourse to the advance to cover urgent expenditure, the need for which was not apparent when the Appropriation Bills were drafted.

I think that really clears up any questions raised in the debate on the Bills by honourable senators. I congratulate and thank all the honourable senators who spoke in this debate. I welcome the support of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats on this legislation. I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, during Question Time in the House of Representatives. The Minister in the other place chose to attack a press release I issued yesterday relating to the question of external consultants employed by the Department of Defence. I have here an unofficial transcript of Question Time in the House of Representatives and I would like to read a couple of paragraphs which explain my concerns. Mr Bilney said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman's claim that we have increased consultancy expenditure in the Department of Defence over the last four years reminds me of the old adage: there are lies, damned lies and statistics. Her calculations are based on a false figure for the base year that she uses, which is the financial year 1986-87, and she quotes a figure for external consultancies of that year of $2.559m.
Mr Bilney went on to criticise the figures in some detail and ended by referring to a survey questionnaire being done by external consultants on attitudes to ethics among Defence staff. He said:
Were she herself to undergo that questionnaire I suspect she would fail it.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the figures in my press release were based on an answer provided to Mr Prosser on 30 May 1989 by the then Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley. The question on notice asked:
(1) What sum did the Minister's Department spend on consultants in (a) 1986-87, (b) 1987-88 and (c) 1988-89.
He then asked for details of those consultants which are irrelevant to my point. Mr Beazley answered as follows:
(1) (a) During 1986-87 the Department of Defence spent a total of $2.559m on the engagement of external consultants.
(b) During 1987-88 the Department of Defence spent the sum of $12.597m on the engagement of external consultants.
(c) During 1988-89 the Department of Defence spent in total $18.915m on the engagement of external consultants.

The figure for 1989-90 of approximately $23m for external consultants was taken by me from the annual report. I can only imagine that Mr Bilney is trying to repudiate Mr Beazley's answer, in that the growth from 1986-87 to 1989-90 was 801 per cent, as I said in my press release. That is obviously embarrassing to the Minister, but it is no justification for the Minister's reflection on my ethics, which were based on Mr Beazley's response and the annual report for the previous year.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991. The Government announced that the amendments to the Wool Marketing Act 1987 have the principal purposes-for the Government of course-of extending the period of Commonwealth guarantee on approved Australian Wool Corporation borrowings beyond 1 July 1991; of implementing the wool industry supplementary payments scheme and appropriate funds for the scheme; of suspending the operations of the reserve price scheme; of enabling the Minister to issue to the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) guidelines in relation to reducing its indebtedness and/or wool stockpile, with the AWC being required to adhere to those guidelines; and enabling the appointment by the Minister of an administrator of the AWC, or an interim AWC, in the event that, in the Minister's opinion, the AWC is unable to form a quorum at meetings or is not effectively exercising its powers or performing its functions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to reflect that throughout the last couple of years the debate on wool has been very contentious. I reflected on the debate in this place on 15 November 1990 on a series of wool tax amendment Bills when I said:

As everyone in Australia knows, the wool debate has very historical, economic and major development consequences for our country. Certainly, anyone who traces the history of wool throughout Australia will know that it is intricately linked to the economics, politics and community development in many areas. We need to recognise that our national economy is in dire straits and that to a large extent the contribution made by wool to our economy is a most important factor.

I am sure that many members of the House of Representatives and many honourable senators in this place have, in the last few days, drawn extensively from information with regard to wool marketing going back to the original introduction of this scheme in 1972.

They have probably also taken cognisance of the amendments made by the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, in 1987 when he considerably amended and changed that scheme at that time. I would point out that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) adopted a new platform in 1988 and it is worth reflecting on that particular platform. I refer in particular to page 167 which is under section 19, primary industries and energy, and the part of the platform which relates to economic issues:

Labor believes that economic issues such as interest rates, access to finance, the exchange rate, taxation, the level of inflation and differential levels of protection are of more significance to the primary industry and resources sector's profitability than the implementation of commodity-specific policies.

Similarly, we need to be reminded that just prior to the March 1990 election last year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy gave a major speech in an address to the Victorian Rural Press club in Melbourne on Tuesday, 13 March 1990.

His press release was headed `Concepts, Umbrellas, Directions, Frameworks and Integration' and it detailed the Hawke Labor Government's rural policies for its next term. Rather ironically, in the press release the Minister quotes from his own speech at the Press Club when he says:
We will not flinch in supporting the wool industry's reserve price decisions.
And probably more ironically I quote from the detailed part of the Minister's release:
Our policies-
that is, the Labor Party's policies-

have resulted in strong economic growth. As well as being a good thing in itself, this has allowed us to get away from the colonial thinking in our primary and resource industries, to get away from the Branch Office mentality of our secondary industries, to enhance the capacity of our service industries, and to fundamentally restructure our economy.

I am sure those words will come back to haunt Mr Kerin time and again. It is interesting to note the participation of ALP members of parliament in the debates on this important piece of legislation, both in this place and in the House of Representatives. Yesterday in the House of Representatives there were 21 speakers on this legislation: 16 from the Opposition parties, and five from the Labor Party. If one cares to glance at the distributed speakers list for today's contribution, honourable senators will note that there are to be 15 contributions to this debate: one from the Australian Democrats; one from the Australian Labor Party-and I pay credit to Senator West because she has obviously got the guts to come in; and 13 from the Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to speak.
—As well as what we would anticipate as the Minister's summary at the end.
—We do not need to make 13 same speeches.
—That will be judged by many people, according to the contribution. The fact that the Labor Party is not prepared to speak and to represent its constituency in rural Australia stands on its own.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen a sad and sorry saga throughout 1990. What are the wool industry needs? They are certainly confidence and a certainty about the future. Recent comments from the Agricultural Outlook conference, from numerous economic writers and agricultural correspondents throughout Australia, and from major work done by the National Farmers Federation all highlight the pessimistic and very dismal prophetic views that have to be brought to this particular issue. There are tragedies facing the wool growers of Australia. At the Agricultural Outlook conference it was highlighted that the income of this sector would drop some 68 per cent this financial year following a 27 per cent drop on the previous year.

Many honourable members and honourable senators, and particularly members of the Cabinet, will be aware that the National Farmers Federation has recently conducted a very comprehensive and extensive poll entitled, `Country Crisis Financial Survey'. This was conducted, of course, by Mr Cameron who is well-known to the Labor Party through his organisation ANOP Research Services Pty Ltd. It is obviously a very professional document, but it is also very worrying in the issues that arise from it. For example, the average farmer gross income in the wool commodities sector was $228,399 for the financial year 1989-90, for the financial year 1990-91 it will be down to $161,923, and for the financial year 1991-92 it is forecast at $137,549.

The report also highlights the average farm net income pre-tax in the wool commodities sector. For the financial year 1989-90 it was $72,665, and for the financial year 1990-91-the current year-it will be $24,357, which is a drop of 66.5 per cent. As I said, that is at a time when there was a significant drop in the previous financial year, anyway. The average farm production cost as a proportion of income for the financial year 1989-90 was 68.2 per cent and for the financial year 1990-91 it was 85 per cent. Those stark statistics stand on their own and certainly highlight many areas.

Certainly, we are in a time where change is inevitable in Australia and internationally, in economics and in trade arrangements. We must always recognise that world events have had a very significant impact both on our economy and on the wool sector. Most recently we have seen the impact of the Gulf war, but we have also had what one could call `the political cannons' that have been fired at us through China, through Russia and through east Europe. There are also the consequences of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the trading policies of both the United States of America and the European Commission. Of course, these are caught up right across the agricultural sector, but they impact very significantly on the part that relates to the wool community.

If we look at the rural community and its needs throughout Australia, we have to recognise the interdependence of a very fragile-and Labor Party recession induced-economy throughout rural Australia. As I said, the National Farmers Federation surveys have highlighted significantly the country financial crisis in areas such as interest rates, the impact of banking, taxation policies, fuel taxation costs, the inadequate rural adjustment and, of course, a failure in industrial relations. The impact of the banking sector-whether it is on real estate or property values, on mortgages, or on how people have to adapt and change to their banking policies and their finances-gives major problems.

There are many associated small businesses-hundreds of thousands of them-throughout remote and rural Australia and many other industries which have an interdependency on the rural sector, and the wool sector in particular. Jobs stand out for major attention. Regional unemployment is running at three times the level of the already high urban levels. It is impacting in every small town throughout remote and rural Australia. The consequences on family security and lifestyle for hundreds of thousands of Australian families are going to be highlighted in so many ways.

We need to carefully address the issues of rural adjustment and rural counselling. There is a demand for rural adjustment by farmers following the massive reduction in wheat grower and horticultural incomes. This will increase dramatically next financial year with thousands of wool and wheat farmers receiving negative incomes. Farmers are generally excluded from unemployment and sickness benefits, and rural adjustment provides an equivalent means tested assistance/household support for a limited period, as well as helping restructure debt for the more viable but still at risk farm businesses. The Government has to address this issue very significantly in the forthcoming Budget considerations. It cannot walk away from those very important issues.

We are well aware that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, induced a recession for Australia. Other members of the Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions for the last few years have had a preoccupation with perestroika for Australia-restructuring, operating and marching to the tune of the socialist left of the ACTU. I argue that the Federal Labor Hawke Government is not governing in the interests of the nation. It relies totally on rhetoric and no action, and the results and consequences do not match the words and the media hype that are constantly paid for and touted through the Government machine.

When addressing the legislation before us today, it is most important to recognise that it is, firstly, irresponsible and, secondly, inadequate. The Minister, Mr Kerin, has to accept his personal responsibility for the failure to provide leadership. This has been so transparent since his famous speech of 13 March 1990. His actions have been undermined by many other people, both within the Government and within various agencies that he has responsibility for. Whilst he has continually attempted to pass the buck and, on several occasions, to panic, his solutions can be described only as piecemeal and inadequate. We need to question very seriously the relationships that Minister Kerin has with the various industry organisations and leaders that he translates to.

I am pleased to say that there is a very proud record of support on this side of the Parliament from the Liberal and National parties. We have demonstrated an ability to face the reality of often very difficult decisions. We have declined to adopt palliative measures just for sectional interests. That is not in the interests of the industry under any circumstances. Certainly, the Liberal and National parties have always stood for protecting the interests of country people and rural industries.

As I said earlier, it is very interesting to look at the debates in the House of Representatives yesterday. Sixteen members of the Liberal and National parties spoke, many of them woolgrowers who can declare an interest but who can understand and identify with the particular problems as they are arising. I refer anyone to yesterday's House of Representatives Hansard and, in particular, to speeches from important people-woolgrowers-such as Mr Tuckey, Mr Sinclair, Mr Cobb, Mr Connolly, Mr McLachlan, and Mr Anderson. Of course, there were others, but what they said was, in effect, a very sound summary of the issues that needed to be addressed. As I said, I am pleased to be supported in the Senate today in this debate by 13 of my colleagues compared with one member of the Labor Party. I am pleased that some of my colleagues are going to cover a very wide range of issues related to this industry. Senators Brownhill, Crane and Panizza are woolgrowers in their own right and they will cover issues such as the history, the administration, the role of the private buyers, the past problems and the marketing opportunities that face us all. Senator Walters and Senator Calvert, from Tasmania, are also woolgrowers and they will be looking at the responsibility of the regulations and covering issues of uncertainty that affect them, many of our constituents and all of Australia across this issue.

Other senators, such as Senator Chapman, Senator Archer, Senator Vanstone, Senator Macdonald and Senator Knowles, will be looking in particular at the industry information and recommendations and, very importantly, the process of government decision making and the legislative scrutiny that is so important to this legislation.

There are flaws right through this legislation. The Opposition will be moving a number of amendments. At the conclusion of my speech, I will move a second reading amendment in general terms and at the committee stage I will be covering a number of other amendments. In particular, let me refer to amendments that we will be moving to cover the reserve price scheme, limiting woolgrowers' debt, the necessary attention that we must give to the stockpile and the Government's excessive regulatory provisions.

The reserve price scheme, which I am addressing in general terms, will be covered with a second reading amendment. But we all know that the debate has been about the termination-the future-of the reserve price scheme versus the suspension of it. As I said earlier, change is inevitable in today's economic and international trading community. We must make correct future decisions and our process of decision making must be soundly based on strong principles that reflect the reality of economics today and our major trading issues. We believe that in the medium and long term the scheme is not sustainable and that woolgrowers will be better off with the removal of the floor price. In the House of Representatives yesterday, the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Lloyd, referred to an important table of wool facts that was taken from the Australian Wool Corporation's strategy plan of February 1991. Like Mr Lloyd, I seek leave of the Senate to have that table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This table indicates the severity of the debt crisis facing woolgrowers and indicates that the length of that crisis would be greater if the scheme continued. That has been confirmed by individual members of the Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool Council of Australia, who do not particularly want to be named but who, nevertheless, have said it-as have people who are involved in providing credit for woolgrowers and are aware of the financial situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Another of our committee stage amendments refers to the limitations that must be accepted and the disciplines that must be accepted on woolgrowers' debt. It is important to ensure that the blow-out in Corporation borrowings does not occur. Woolgrowers already face massive industry debt in excess of $2.8 billion and will incur substantial individual debt over the coming years as their incomes are halved. Interest payments will be over $400m annually. To increase the Wool Corporation's borrowing to $3.5 billion, as was indicated by the Minister, plus paying for an open-ended supplementary payments scheme, would have critically threatened the viability of the AWC and increased the interest bill to potentially $600m a year. The Government's proposal to introduce a supplementary payments scheme to the end of June to provide equity for the 35 to 40 per cent of growers still to sell their wool will cost a guesstimated $600m to $1 billion. It will be financed by a government grant of $300m and an extension of the AWC borrowing limit from $3 billion to $3.5 billion, therefore putting pressures on growers to place individual reserves on their wool rather than to allow it to potentially be given away in an open-ended scheme. I note that yesterday in the House of Representatives Mr McLachlan said:

. . . there is no incentive-or there has not been up until now-for a grower to do other than to throw his wool on the market, knowing that the difference between what it makes and 700c will be made up by the Government.

Therefore, the coalition will endeavour to limit the scheme to $500m, the $300m government subsidy and the remaining $200m, which is the point of our amendment, from the industry. This would take the current AWC borrowing from $2.8 billion-odd to just over $3 billion.

On the issue of the stockpile we have put forward an amendment to the effect that, except in limited or exceptional circumstances, it is a necessity to apply a freeze to the stockpile for 12 months to allow the market to settle and growers to sell the large amounts of wool still being produced. The subsequent release of that would then be on a well-publicised and predictable basis.

The final point of our committee amendments relates to the excessive regulatory provisions in clause 148(2) (b) of the Bill. This would give the Minister unnecessary regulatory power, including a power to override any section of the legislation. We find this not just bad drafting but totally unnecessary.

The final issue that I would like to address is a challenge. The problems that need to be looked at most critically and importantly are related to marketing. The Government has not given the wool industry any confidence that the marketing policies or marketing provisions will in any way help them. In fact, it can be argued that the actions of the Minister, Mr Kerin, as he went off on a caravan trip around the world last year, have created a lack of certainty and undermined much of the marketing potential for Australia. I notice that the honourable member for Maranoa, Mr Bruce Scott, in the House of Representatives yesterday was also addressing this issue. He raised what I think is an important and exciting challenge. He said:
. . . I would like to see a former member of this House-
that is, the House of Representatives-

Doug Anthony, called on to travel to the Middle East to see if he can re-establish a viable live sheep trade with the Middle East. It is crazy to put sheep into pits when in 1983 we were able to sell seven million sheep to the Middle East. What a tragic waste of resources it would be if we did not pursue every effort to get the live sheep trade operational again.

That issue is complementary to this legislation. It is important to the whole industry and how it is dealt with, whether in regard to live sheep or wool marketing. Marketing is the key to where we should be going. I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but, because of the urgent need to restore the confidence of wool producers and buyers in the long-term future of the industry and in order to end the confusion caused by the Government's vacillating wool pricing policies, the reserve price scheme must be abolished immediately''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to Senator Tambling's contribution with a great deal of interest. I think there should have been more communication on this matter. If we now have so many coalition senators willing to take part in this debate, perhaps that is a clue that if there had been more willing dialogue and constructive conversations earlier we may have been able to find a solution. This lack of commitment until this time has been one of my frustrations-a lack of ability to find out exactly what was being proposed. Senator Tambling gave some of the credentials of those who will contribute to this debate later. My credentials for speaking in this debate are simply that my very first paid employment was within the wool industry. I was employed in a large wool store in Tasmania to shift bales of wool. I did not particularly like it; it was not a very pleasant job. In the days when a wool hook was required to move 400 pounds of wool, a 17-year-old boy soon found out what hard work was.
—It has not done you much harm, the size you are.

—That is a wonderful compliment for which I thank the honourable senator. A great number of my relatives are also closely involved in the wool industry. They range from one family which for some decades has been involved in a small stud breeding enterprise to another family which has been a pioneer in the introduction and development of the coarse wool industries in Tasmania. Another member of my family is involved in the extensive grazing of merinos on the east coast of Tasmania. Other branches of my family are part of a long-established family of premium fine woolgrowing. It is not so much with their information and contributions that I come to this debate, but rather a commitment and an understanding that the wool industry has become so much a part of Australia's economic and social development that it is inextricably linked with the welfare of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: As an introduction to my contribution proper to this debate, I wish to share with the Senate a snippet of information from 600 years ago. For the edification of honourable senators they may like to know that in 1376 Geoffrey Chaucer was controller of customs for Edward III. In that capacity rather than as a poet he was permitted to retain a substantial fine of #70.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a lot of money in those days.

—Yes, it was a considerable amount of money in those days. Geoffrey Chaucer had levied that fine on an unlicensed exporter of wool. I share that information with the Senate to demonstrate the fact that for centuries attempts have been made to regulate the trade in wool. There have been many systems, some less satisfactory than others, but to try to re-establish a so-called free market is to try for something which has probably been non-existent for hundreds if not thousands of years. It denies the lessons of the history of commerce.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that hundreds of years ago it was common for rulers to dispense privileged licences to trade. Even thousands of years ago when Hammurabi ruled what is now Iraq, there were rules governing commerce. These are often referred to as the code of Hammurabi. Systems without regulation have been very few and far between. The experiment of what has been known as the laissez-faire system, where anything goes, occupied only a brief chaotic moment in our commercial history. That system is still looked upon wistfully by some entrepreneurs who see total de- regulation as their chance to rush in for a quick buck. Privileged bullies do make that quick buck, but inexperienced sellers, small producers, isolated producers and single product sellers are always exploited in so-called `free' markets.

We are enticed-seduced, perhaps-by this term `free'. Perhaps that is because in the last few decades a plethora of letterbox junk has convinced us that `free' always means something for nothing and that anything free must be good. I am sure honourable senators will know that nobody gets nothing for nothing in a free wool market. It is simply a market without regulation, untrammelled, unfettered, free, without control, chaotic. I did not need a thesaurus to remind me of those terms. Those words actually describe what the Australian wool market was in the 1960s.

That statement justifies the bemusement felt by Mr Ken Wriedt last weekend when he was reported in the Sunday Tasmanian. Part of the report about Mr Ken Wriedt, who is an ex-senator and an ex-Labor Minister, reads:

. . . in the late 1960s and early 1970s Australia had been selling wool under its value to overseas markets. ``The position was that wool prices had fallen down to 30c a pound . . . which was literally giving our wool away'' he said.
The article dealt with the establishment of the reserve price scheme, for which Senator Wriedt was responsible at the time, and he continued:

`Everyone knew it would be the greatest single thing you could do for the wool industry and for rural Australia. We did it and there was no question it was a great success. It gave the industry the stability it never had before'.

It seems to me that Mr Wriedt now joins a growing list of formerly staunch, proud, Labor achievers who must wonder what this Administration is doing for the best thing this country has ever had going for it.

I think we should look at what has brought about this unbelievably bad situation. It is a truism that our wool industry was doing very nicely just a couple of years ago. Prices were buoyant enough to suggest that the 870c a kilogram would be exceeded for some time to come. When the floor price was moved upwards to 870c, it is my contention that that figure became a market speculation price rather than a guaranteed minimum price for producers, and there is a big difference in the concept.
