Rather than being related to and underpinning the costs of production, that price had become a gamble related to what it was thought the market might bear. Rather than being a floor offering stability, that price had become a hammock. It was slung between, and held up by, the twin posts of buyer confidence and buyer demand. The hammock offered bliss for a brief moment but, of course, an unpleasant dumping when demand began to shake.

Let us have a closer look at demand and confidence. As far as I am concerned, consumer wants only become demands when they are matched with a capacity to pay. At present, the lack of the capacity to buy at anything like a reasonable price is the reason for our wool marketing problems. The want is there and the need is there, but it cannot be translated into a predictable demand.

I suggest that even at 700c-perhaps even at 500c-the Soviet Union is, at present, unable to buy. I must say in passing that the priorities of that country's Administration are somewhat disturbing, because it seems that there is plenty of money that can be found to maintain an armed presence in the Baltic States, and Soviet forces are fuelled and armoured sufficiently well to trample the citizens of Lithuania, so perhaps it is not a case of lack of money at all but rather a case of misdirected priorities. That is something that we really cannot do much about while considering this legislation.

Senator Tambling quite rightly said that wool marketing is the key and Sir William Gunn agrees with him, and I would like to put myself alongside those authorities. It seems patently obvious that our problem is related to the fact that we have not sold the stuff. I have asked questions in this place relating to what alternative marketing strategies are being conducted, suggested, forwarded, implemented or even thought about by this Government and the list of answers is very short. The list of answers should be long and imaginative, and it is only with a long and imaginative list of alternative marketing strategies that we will ever be able to sell materials of any description to people who want them, but who do not necessarily have the cash to turn that want into a consumer demand.

I would now like to consider what caused the lack of confidence. The very first rumours that the floor price would be lowered removed confidence. It is just like the old days of the fixed dollar exchange rate when a well-placed leak about devaluation was a self-fulfilling prophecy. When that floor price was lowered the die was cast. If it could be lowered once it could be lowered again. All the protestations on earth were not going to change that perception. Minister Kerin issued many such protestations, and some buyers might think that he protesteth too much. The protestations were:
My clear message to the market is the 700c is immutable. The next time the floor price is changed will be upward.
That was Mr Kerin on the Australian Associated Press wire service on 31 May. The next was:
The Government's commitment to the 700c kg floor is rock solid.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement in Melbourne on 31 May. I quote again as follows:
I emphasise that this inquiry-
meaning the Vines committee of inquiry-
is about looking ahead. It is not about a fundamental re-examination of the Minimum Reserve Price for wool.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement on 23 July 1990. I quote again:
Against this background, the Government has made four important decisions: 1. to reaffirm its rock solid support for the floor price of 700 cents.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement on 12 September 1990. The next:
I have said before, the Government backs the MRP at 700 cents for this year and it goes without saying that we back it at 700 cents for next year.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement on 12 October responding to the announcement by the Australian Wool Corporation that the wool floor price for 1991-92 would also be 700c. I quote again:

There is now more understanding by buyer countries of the Reserve Price Scheme and its security in law, especially the fact that the Minimum Reserve Price is fixed at 700 cents for at least the next 19 months.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement on 2 December. I quote again:

Let me state here and now that the Government will stand unequivocally behind the 700c floor and give it every support. The Government has given tangible expression to that commitment . . . So let there be no doubt about the Government's resolve to back the AWC in this area. My clear message to the market is that 700c is immutable.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement in Melbourne, again on 31 May 1990. I quote again:

I have given a cast-iron guarantee, which I repeat here, that the Australian Government will not contemplate, under any circumstances, any further downward movement in the wool floor price . . . Any speculation on a further price drop is doomed to disappointment and would only be counterproductive.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement on 7 June 1990. I quote again:
Let me make it quite clear that the inquiry (into wool pricing policy) will not affect the reserve price.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement on 7 June. I quote again:

I stressed to the conference . . . in Dubrovnik, to country delegations, and many individuals, that the 700c/kg floor had the backing of the Australian Government and the Australian industry. They know we will guarantee it now that a once-and-for-all correction has been made.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement on 10 June 1990. I quote again:
Following the meeting-
of the Interim Wool Policy Council-

Mr Kerin said that no consideration was, or would be given by the Council to any reduction in the 700c/kg wool reserve price. The Government and the industry are united in their commitment to 700c/kg.
That was Mr Kerin's press statement on 20 September 1990.

On 26 November a response was made in Question Time by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) who represents the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). Senator Cook said:

As far as the Australian Government is concerned, the current situation is that the Wool Corporation, in consultation with the Wool Council of Australia, has already announced the reserve price for wool next year will be 700c per kilo. The Minister would have the power to intervene to alter that arrangement only if there were disagreement between the Wool Council and the Australian Wool Corporation. As a measure of the Government's respect for the industry, there is no intention to intervene where there is an agreement. We support the current situation. We have no intention of changing it.

Following the litany of protestations, the position was all too evident to the Australian Financial Review. An article written by Cathy Bolt on 12 February most perceptively pointed out what this meant, and contains some things which are most telling. It stated:
Mr Kerin has now put Australia in an invidious position, having travelled to all major buying countries just two months ago and issued assurances everywhere that the floor would not be dropped again.

But one now has to wonder what the consequences will be for Australia's credibility as a business party when a senior minister can sit across the table from major customers and give guarantees which are patently unsustainable.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should not have made them in the first place.

—That is certainly right; they should not have been in the first place. The situation should have been addressed in an entirely different manner. To contribute to this loss of confidence, some other processes were put in train and are described in this article, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Soon after Mr Kerin's mission returned, the Government's Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics released a report highly critical of the reserve price scheme.

Then, in January, the government-appointed Vines inquiry went to Europe at a crucial point in reviving confidence in the reserve price scheme and was so insensitive as to ask processors how they would feel about a 500c floor.
At the same time, a Labor MP, Mr Graeme Campbell sent a letter to a newspaper in one of Italy's major textiles towns warning that the floor price was doomed.
Yet in a response in Question Time on 6 December, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stated:
I adhere to the statements on the wool floor price of my Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

But what did all this lead to? It led to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy being in an invidious position as described in the article I have quoted from. As I said earlier, all this was almost a self-fulfilling prophecy. The chain of events was not necessary; other schemes were possible.

I suggest that rather than declaring a total shift from 870c to 700c, and then to zero, there could have been a closer definition of the classes of wool for which the minimum price would apply. For example, for certain categories of wool, if Corporation purchase was necessary, returns to growers could have been delayed, staggered or penalised in such a way that unpopular categories would be less likely to be overproduced.

That is what we really need from a market-market signals being able to be taken back to the producers. There are many ways of applying limiting criteria to the minimum price scheme. These criteria would have limited the supply of wools which are not readily saleable but would not have meant compromising the wool market's confidence. That is the important point. In attempting to manipulate the market, to alter the market to suit the needs of our entire industry, it would be very important not to compromise that market's future in whatever criteria are applied to give those signals back to the buyers and to the producers.

I say in passing that there are many such propositions, many such refinements, which could have been brought to our minimum price scheme. In fact, the Government attacked it with a very blunt instrument: a cut of 870c across the board to 700c, and now an across the board cut to zero.

Rather than going on with that argument, we should look at what is proposed here today. At this point it is also appropriate to say that what I have said will give a clue to what I think will be necessary in the future and what could be done now; that is, the limited application of some criteria to restrict what is offered or to encourage what could be produced. They are the sorts of measures that will have to be introduced at some stage anyway.

The reason which necessitated the formation of the floor price scheme still exists; namely, that it is not a free market internationally. It is nothing like it and never will be. It is subject to seasonal fluctuations, to geographical variations, to the manipulations of stock exchanges and financial exchange rates, futures trading and so on. It is not a free market, it is not a level playing field and it never will be. Even this abomination which the Government now wants to foist upon the industry is nothing like a free market. It is a market in limbo. It is a market in anticipation. It is a market that is conditioned by the expectation of the grower that 700c, or something like it, will be received; the knowledge of the buyer that the grower cares little about what is paid in the market because that is not the final return; and the expectation of the buyer that a different system will be proposed on 1 July. That is hardly a free market system.

Among the many letters I have received on this subject, one person, Mr Vandervaere, seems to understand the situation very well. I have appreciated his advice and he contacts me regularly. His statement, with which I agree, adds to the vagaries of this so-called free market that is supposed to exist; that is, the question of the stockpile and the psychological influence that its existence will have on market conditions when, if ever, this legislation is passed. Mr Vandervaere said:
The vague but repeated mention of stockpile disposal will ensure that the market will be even lower than it ought to be through the psychological impact even if no sales are actually made.

Those who know anything about marketing will understand the penalties that are imposed on a system by such an overhanging threat. We have a distorted market. Why describe it as free? At the moment it is distorted out of our control by influences over which we do not have complete authority. This is from a Government whose Treasurer (Mr Keating) often refers to needing levers to pull and switches to turn on and turn off. To abrogate all opportunity for manipulation-manipulation to our advantage-is an abrogation which is entirely misguided. It is my suggestion that we should be trying to bring orderly marketing and control of this industry to such a point that we can distort the market to suit our needs; in other words, to do what we want to do in the future.

What do we want the market to do? We want to sell all saleable wool. We want to provide the grower with market signals which will guide the future production of that grower so that we do not form a stockpile of wool which is not in demand. Yet we would still be able to sell the wool-particularly the superfine wool, but the coarser grades as well. We would be able to sell almost 100 per cent of the clip. That is a signal which was unable to be fed back to producers. Of course, they are waking up now. But it is not their fault that it has taken such a long time to make that point to them. Modifications to the reserve price scheme could have achieved such a situation.

I foreshadow an amendment which I will move at the committee stage to try to make the best out of what is offered here-to attempt to shift the financial consequences of these decisions of the Government from the growers back to the Government, where those financial consequences belong. If the Government chooses to make a decision such as this, I believe it should not have the capacity to direct that a section of the community should suffer unduly for that decision having been made. In other words, the amendment which I propose would make the Government wear its own decision.

If the Government had thought, in making this decision, that it would have to carry the full cost of it, it might have looked more carefully at other options. My main problem in this regard is that it seems that the other options which were looked at were not imaginative enough. They were stuck in a schedule and were unable to be removed from a very narrow perspective. The decisions were not made with regard to the overall costs that would have to be borne by the industry.

It seems strange that legislation which is so momentous and of such huge importance had to be introduced without due regard for drafting. The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was able to find an anomaly very early. I have been advised that proposed new section 148 (1) (b) at page 4 of the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill can be described as a classic Henry VIII clause which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee always, and quite rightly, objects to. I understand that the coalition has been able to observe that with the little time that has been available. I foreshadow that if an amendment comes forward in regard to that the Australian Democrats will support it. It is annoying that this proposition comes before us in such momentous legislation and that we have to amend it to get it right.

Even when one objects to the general direction and purport of the Bill, it has to be the responsibility of those who are not in government to do the Government's work for it and to correct its legislation to make it work equitably. The amendment which the Democrats will move at the committee stage will attempt to make the best of it for the growers. I only hope that the coalition will join us in that amendment and at least make the Government wear the cost of its own decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991. The effect of this Bill is to suspend the market reserve price that has worked effectively and well for 17 years, providing both the grower and the wool processing industry with a stable base on which to plan and develop. The reserve price scheme was effective because it took the roller-coaster rides out of the industry. When supply moved ahead of demand, there were depressed prices for the grower; when demand moved ahead of supply, there was disaster for the wool production industry. It was effective because it broke up cartels and buying pies that worked against the true price. Even now, the market gets tried on every couple of weeks or so. The overall proof of the scheme's success was that Australia's wool export sales grew from $1.270 billion in 1972-73 to $6 billion in 1988-89, providing in that year 14 per cent of Australia's overseas total exports.

SPEECH.PARA: The market reserve price scheme has its genesis in the Australian Wool Commission Bill, presented to the House of Representatives in 1970 by the then Minister for Primary Industry, Doug Anthony. Approximately two years later, in September, Ian Sinclair introduced the Australian Wool Corporation Bill, which combined the Australian Wool Commission with the Australian Wool Board to form the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC). It is interesting to read those speeches. In Doug Anthony's address to Parliament he said:

The Government decided that no qualitative or financial limits should be placed on the amount of wool which could be purchased and held by the Commission as such a limitation could adversely affect the operations of the Commission. For example, to declare and publish a fixed limit to the level of stocks which the Commission would be permitted to hold could lead to the embarrassing pressure on the Commission as stocks approached-or were thought by buyers to be approaching-the fixed limits.

That statement by Doug Anthony showed a belief in the industry and a commitment to the scheme, unlike the wimpish lack of support that the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has given the reserve price scheme.
I quote Mr Duthie, the Labor member in 1970 who spoke on that legislation:

There has been collusion at the auction for years. We have studied the pie system and we have proved it to be so. It has kept the price of wool down, there is no competition. There are fewer and fewer buyers attending the wool sales. This has emasculated the auction system.
Those statements were made in 1970 and I fear they are just as relevant today as they were then.

A former Attorney-General, Mr Hughes, said that the Australian trade practices legislation would protect Australian woolgrowers from collusion. In view of the statements by Professor Baxt, the Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, that Australia had the weakest antitrust legislation in any Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nation, I have grave doubts that the assurances Mr Hughes gave will be fulfilled.

It is important to outline briefly the ups and downs in the market that have taken place over the last six years. In order to understand the implications of this Bill-the removal of the floor price as from the commencement of sales on 25 February-it is important to have a brief summary of what has actually happened to the industry over the last seven or eight years. In 1984, the price of wool rose because of a number of factors: the depreciation of the dollar against other currencies; in 1983, the International Wool Secretariat had a wonderfully successful promotion of cool wool, driving demand ahead of supply-no-one was condemning the floor price then; all the free marketeers were happy to cop it sweet and the Stoeckels and Maple-Browns of this world were raking the money in-the international consumer economies were booming and moving; and in 1988 the central Government in Beijing relaxed restrictions on the provinces, allowing the market to rise, pushing wool up to an almost unsatisfiable demand and pushing the price up to 1,250c.

I am told that every Chinese received a woollen suit. I cannot verify that but, in response to the high demand, the Wool Corporation tried to steady the price by running down all its stocks. Wool was so popular then that even that would not dampen the price. Every person in the industry, the AWC, the Wool Council, the Government and the commentators believed that the 870c was sustainable. At that time, the AWC reserves amounted to $1.8 billion. As always happens in primary industry, every boom has a bust; every high has a low. We all realise that primary industries are cyclical but no-one could believe the run of outs that hit the industry.

In the 1988-89 season the market rose to 840 million kilograms; in the 1989-90 season the market dropped to 600 million kilograms; and this season it is down to around 400 million to 500 million kilograms. That is a catastrophe not only for the woolgrower but for Australia as a whole as it is going to affect the whole of our economic system. Wool export earnings fell from the 1988-89 season to the 1989-90 season by $2 billion-from $6 billion to $3.8 billion.

The industry was king hit not once but five times. The Chinese withdrawal from the market because of international problems and the Tiananmen Square incident cost the market 80 million kilograms a year. The internal restructure of the Russian economy, moving into a free market, cost 90 million kilograms in 1989. Those two incidents alone reduced sales by 20 per cent. Another factor was the loss of the Middle East sheep trade in 1983. Australia was shipping seven million sheep into that market. The loss of that market allowed 35 million kilograms of wool to come onto the market every year.

But probably the greatest king hit of all was Mr Kerin's eroding of the floor price last April and May, and probably earlier than that. I sat in Parliament during that time and witnessed the tactics which the Minister used. I say that they were not Marquess of Queensberry tactics; they were goanna tactics. People in the bush were bewildered by them.

After providing Australia with exports earning $5.811 billion in 1987-88, or 14.3 per cent of total export earnings, and $6 billion in the 1988-89 season, the Wool Corporation and the Wool Council had the right to expect some support from the Government when the inevitable happened and there was a downturn in the season. But they never got that support.

At the time the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy launched his attack on the wool industry, the score stood at: AWC stocks, 2.5 million bales; growers' equity, 69 per cent; AWC borrowings, $789m; Government borrowings, nil; trade buying between 60, 70 and 80 per cent. But the Minister had made up his mind. He had received his riding instructions from Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) and Mr Keating that the price was set too high and had to be reduced to get wool moving again. The stocks were up.

The Australian economy was hurting and the cash register had to start ringing. We were going to have a fire sale-not of the Government's assets but the farmers' and woolgrowers' assets. Mr Kerin's tactics were to brief the press to leak stories that the price could not be sustained. There was the odd remark at a door stop-it was a case of a nod being as good as a wink to a blind man.

Meanwhile, the confidence in the floor was eroding. The Corporation was buying more and the trade less. It was John Kerin's non-commitment to the floor price scheme at a press conference on 10 May last year that sent panic into the market and sent clear signals to the buyers to keep out or get burnt.

After that press conference Mr Kerin hit the headlines of every paper in Australia. Let me quote some of them. The Australian Financial Review carried the headline `Wool Mountain Unravels-Price Stability'. Other headlines were: `Kerin Queries Wool-View Gloomy'; `Foreign Buyer Warns of Wool Price Disaster'; `Kerin Attacks Industry Chief Over Wool Crisis'; `Wool Crisis-750 Million Bales-No Buyers'. The Canberra Times carried the headline `Kerin Makes it Clear that the Wool Industry is in Deep Trouble'.

That was a guerilla attack on the great Australian wool industry and Mr Kerin should be condemned for it. At a time when this great Australian industry needed help, support and confidence, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy put the boot into it.

On 15 May last year in the House of Representatives the Minister answered three questions from Labor backbenchers. No doubt these questions were written in Mr Kerin's office and were designed to denigrate and once again undermine the floor price. The press conference, the answers to the questions in both the House of Representatives and the Senate-and Senator Cook played his part in this chamber-leaked stories and press briefings all undermined the 870c floor. Buyers treated the wool auction as though it was the source of the plague. They stayed away in droves.

The Australian Wool Corporation was forced into buying between 70 and 80 per cent of the clip. Before Mr Kerin's intervention the AWC was buying 20 per cent and the trade 80 per cent. The number of bales in stock climbed from 2.5 million to 3.1 million; growers' equity fell from 69 or 68 per cent to around 46 per cent; and AWC's borrowings rose $789m to $1.018 billion. The writing was on the wall for the 870c floor price.

On 31 May Mr Kerin announced that the floor price would be reduced from 870c to 700c. This was done one month before the selling season ceased, forcing the AWC to buy wool at 870c and sell it at 700c. That little episode cost the woolgrowers $500m in one month alone. That is how much their stocks were depreciated and how much equity they lost. That action mortally wounded the minimum reserve price; it very seriously wounded the wool industry as a whole.

The Wool Corporation was then forced to increase purchasing from the 30 per cent levels of the pre-Easter sales up to 90 per cent levels in June. So what started out to be a fire sale turned around and bit the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In the past nine months, with the floor price set at 700c, we have not sold any more wool. But the industry has plunged deeper and deeper into debt. AWC stocks went up, the borrowings went up and growers' equity went down.

Mr Kerin's undermining of the floor price was wrong and went against all the advice the industry gave. The woolgrowers pleaded with him not to alter the floor. The wool exporters sent deputations to Canberra pointing out the dangers to our overseas customers. We actually bankrupted about three of them. The spinners, weavers and cloth makers wrote to Mr Kerin explaining what the consequence of his actions would be. The Wool Corporation offered him advice, and that advice was not to lower the floor because it would stampede the market. The industry knew the market philosophy but Mr Kerin chose to ignore it. Instead, he took his advice from ABARE and the economists and totally rejected any industry advice.

If he had gone to the industry, the Wool Corporation or the Wool Council and sat down with them and explained that he could see difficulties in the future, I think there would have been a response. But even if there had not been, he could have walked away. Mr Kerin may have gone through the motions of having meetings and discussions on many occasions but it was always his intention to alter and drop the floor price.

If the industry's advice had been taken and sales did not pick up and the floor eventually crashed, as it has, Mr Kerin could have done a Pontius Pilate -he could have washed his hands of it, walked away and said, `It is not my fault. Be it on your head'. He could have walked away, exonerated. But that did not happen. Mr Kerin ignored all the advice and he now has to wear the consequences of his action.

On 31 May Mr Kerin announced that the floor price would drop from 870c to 700c. He then guaranteed that the price for the remainder of the 1990-91 and 1991-92 season would remain at 700c. On 11 occasions, the Minister reassured both the growers and the buyers that the price was locked in at 700c. To describe that action, he used words such as `immutable', `rock solid', `cast iron' and `guaranteed'. That is the strongest support any Minister could have offered the floor price. Graziers made financial commitments on that assurance. They had done their budgets; they had been to their bank managers. The market responded to Mr Kerin's promise. Farmers have now found themselves financially disadvantaged. On Monday 11 February the announcement was made that the floor price was suspended.

That action has caused Australia tremendous embarrassment throughout our trading nations. Will we ever be able to hold our heads up in any overseas forums? When we go into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) will anyone take this nation seriously? We are a laughing stock. After so many commitments and promises, Mr Kerin did a 180 degree turn and went back on his word. That is not John Kerin's word, that is the word of this Government of Australia that he treated in such a cavalier fashion. Mr Kerin has got to accept a lot of the responsibility, but not all. After criticising him, I do commend him for going to Russia and extending credit. I must say that after that trip things began to look up; sales began to take off. Again, confidence seemed to be coming back into the market. But for a number of reasons, we lost it.

The Vines committee to investigate wool industry arrangements had one member openly asking how much people were prepared to pay. Fancy a salesman going out and asking what someone would offer to pay for a product. That was confirmed yesterday when the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) in the House of Representatives raised the issue with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy at Question Time. The Minister responded that he was aware and approved of the committee's canvassing the hypothetical 500c floor price. In a skittish and explosive market, once again this frightened the buyers off.

The letter of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) to European and British newspapers added insecurity to an already shaky market. Mr Campbell does not carry a lot of weight around here. In fact, he is considered to be something of a joke around the Parliament-

TALK.START.PARA: —A light weight.

—I said he was a lightweight and a bit of a joke. But he claimed to be a member of the Government. People overseas do not understand our political system. Then there was the failure of Russia to return to the market after a $400m extension of credit. Then we had to have the free marketeers, the Stoeckel and Maple-Brown report. They could not get in front of a television camera fast enough. They were given sufficient press coverage to frighten the market away again. When all these events happened we were right back to go, with the AWC buying up to 70 per cent and 80 per cent again. The position at present with the cessation of sales is that 4.8 million bales are stockpiled. Government borrowings are fluctuating between $2.8 billion and $2.9 billion, and growers' equity is down to between 34 per cent and 36 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry is now facing a desperate position and it is going to require skills, patience and tolerance on all sides to come out of this with as little damage as possible. With a crisis such as this, there is always a tendency for everyone to blame everyone else. That is not going to help. The Government has introduced legislation that I believe is going somewhere to helping the industry, but in my opinion the Bill we are debating puts an ever increasing debt on an ever decreasing number of growers. It has to be recognised that there are going to be casualties in the wool industry. The established grower with no debt will survive. Young people building their properties up will be in diabolical trouble. Farmers and growers who have been through drought will also be in trouble. Already land values in Queensland have come back between 20 per cent and 30 per cent, reducing the equity of the property owner below what is acceptable to his bank manager.

The Kerin proposal gives $300m supplementary payments with a guarantee to the AWC to increase borrowings to another $500m, and to pay the growers up to 700c, which was promised by Mr Kerin for the 1991 and also the 1992 seasons. The Wool Corporation has borrowed money to pay up to 700c for wool that has already come to the auction, until the suspension of sales. The remaining growers who have not auctioned their wool this year are entitled to some equity. Most of the remainder of the growers traditionally come from Queensland, which shears in the second half of the year. Estimates are that there are a further 2.5 million bales either waiting at auction for the recommencement of sales or to come in before the season.

Under the Kerin proposal, if the price at auction reaches 500c, the AWC would have to borrow $592m less the $300m that is a supplementary payment, making a total of $282m. At 400c, the borrowings would have to be $588m. At 300c, borrowings have to go to $900m. The Minister has come to realise now that his $300m supplementary payments and his additional $500m with the extended overdraft to the AWC may not be sufficient to extend the 700c to the wool yet to be auctioned. So he has come up with a further plan-I think it has to go that way-which sets a benchmark and if the wool price does not reach the benchmark the difference is paid between the benchmark and the 700c. It is a difficult plan but I can see it has to go that way.

The additional borrowings of $500m, which takes the Wool Corporation total debt to $3.5 billion, will burden the industry with a debt that is going to require higher taxes on lower prices and fewer growers as the casualties take place and people move away from the wool industry. That is hard to accept. In effect, if the borrowings are allowed to blow out to $3.5 billion and the floor price falls to 300c, it is going to require a tax of 41 per cent to fund those borrowings, and we are going to weaken the strong to protect the weak to make sure the weak get the 700c; I think everyone ends up in a weaker position.

It is difficult to allow borrowings to escalate beyond the capacity of growers to pay. But I am equally convinced that the Government is culpable in the whole sorry mess, as I have said before. The Government's decision on 31 May last year to reduce the floor price from 870c to 700c one month before the season forced the AWC to buy wool at 870c and sell it for 700c. That cost the industry between $600m and $500m. That was a Government decision. It made it. It forced it on the industry. It should therefore compensate the industry for the decision to lift the supplementary payments to $500m.

We cannot force growers to pay for another $500m. That $500m loss is clearly a Government decision. The $500m and the $200m borrowings would go some way to compensating growers, and I believe it is the least the Government can do. I have grave reservations about section 147 of the Bill which gives the Minister the power to replace the AWC board with a new board of administrators. That strikes fear into the hearts of woolgrowers. They want a say in their industry; they have paid for it; they are terrified the Minister might appoint someone with no sympathy or understanding of the industry.

On the matter of the floor price, let there be no misunderstanding. The 700c floor price is finished and growers face an open market on the resumption of sales. But I cannot bring myself to vote for the dismantling of a structure that has served the wool industry so faithfully and well. In 1988 it was a different story. The accolades for the minimum reserve price were unanimous from all sections of the industry, the Government and all other commentators. Not only the wool industry benefited but also the Australian economy as a whole, providing jobs and prosperity for 650,000 people connected with the industry. Who knows what the future holds. I am not prepared to throw the baby out with the bath water and therefore I cannot support the abolishment of the floor price.

The industry faces difficult times. Woolgrowers' incomes will be cut drastically. Their incomes will average a negative $5,700 and will stay around that level for at least two years. There will be a downturn in the whole Australian economy, driving it down further than it is already. The small regional centres are going to be affected as farmers tighten their belts and spend nothing. All sectors of the Australian industry and economy are going to feel the repercussions of this. The loss of export sales and buying power generated by the wool and wheat industries is going to be felt right across Australia.

It is now up to all Australians to get behind this the greatest of all Australian industries. I have confidence in the product that the wool industry produces, and I have greater confidence in the men and women who make up that industry. I know that they will come through. Australia needs them and it needs the contribution that this industry makes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991 with a certain amount of emotion and a lot of feeling. I am a woolgrower and have been all my life, as I have said in this place before, not only in terms of producing that wool but also in terms of being involved in the shearing industry and other aspects of woolgrowing. This is indeed a sad and emotional day for me. It was wheat quotas and the collapse of wool marketing in 1969-70 that were the reasons for my getting involved in agro-politics.

SPEECH.PARA: Leading up to this day I have spent many hours both thinking and researching what was the best solution to the current problem. I was doing this against a background of being not only a supporter of the reserve price scheme but also, unashamedly, a vigorous defender. In wrestling with this problem I came to the conclusion that in the final analysis the decision had to be one that allowed the maximum number of woolgrowers to survive and be with us in five years time. As well as talking about all woolgrowers in both Western Australia and Australia generally, I am also talking about my neighbours and my friends-people that I met in the early 1960s when we went to a place called Jerdacuttup on the south-east coast of Western Australia to open up new land under the conditional purchase scheme. Above all, I want as many of these people as possible to survive this disaster-and it is a disaster.

This is an issue where we have to lift ourselves above politics because we are talking about the industry that has produced more export dollars for this country than any other in any 10-year period we care to nominate. I appeal to those on the other side of this chamber to put prejudiced thoughts behind them and get on with the job of sorting out the best way of handling this disaster. Our objective must be to put the industry back on the top of the tree. Having said that, we must analyse where we went wrong. The Wool Council of Australia, the Australian Wool Corporation and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), must shoulder most of the blame, but I doubt whether any of us in this place or in the other place is totally free of blame in terms of not speaking out more loudly and more vigorously against what became obvious some 12 months ago.

During the past 12 months, the Wool Council and the Wool Corporation have gone along with blind faith that the world would come back and buy our wool regardless of price. The responsible Minister has followed along behind them like a little lap-dog. With the amendments that were made in 1987 to the then Wool Industry Act, which took the discipline out of the reporting process and the financial controls required, the reserve price scheme became a market price centre and ceased to be a price support scheme. We in fact said to the rest of the world, `Pay the price we demand or we will lock it up'. We have in fact behaved like a hoarder of antiques. I seek leave to have section 41 of the Wool Marketing Act 1987 incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
41. (1) The flexible reserve price scheme operated by the Corporation shall be a scheme under which-

(a) reserve prices for the various types of wool being offered for sale at auction in accordance with arrangements referred to in paragraph (d) of sub-section (1) of section 38 of this Act are determined by or on behalf of the Corporation as frequently as the Corporation thinks necessary having regard to the bidding at recent auctions and to all other relevant information available to the Corporation;

(b) if, in respect of any wool submitted for sale at auction in accordance with any such arrangements, a bid equal to or greater than the appropriate reserve price determined by the Corporation is not made, the Corporation is prepared to buy the wool at the appropriate reserve price so determined; and
(c) the Corporation, as and when it thinks expedient, re-offers for sale at auction, or otherwise disposes of, wool acquired by it under the scheme.

(2) The Corporation shall, at fortnightly intervals, make reports to the Minister and the Treasurer concerning the operation of its reserve price scheme, and shall include in the reports such information as the Minister directs concerning-
(a) the reserve prices determined by the Corporation;
(b) wool purchased and wool held by the Corporation; and
(c) sales of wool by the Corporation and proposed offerings of wool by the Corporation.

(3) The Minister shall, from time to time, after consultation with the Treasurer, inform the Corporation in writing of the policies and principles that the Government of the Commonwealth considers should be followed and applied by the Corporation in the operation of its reserve price scheme.

(4) The Minister may, on behalf of the Government of the Commonwealth, if he thinks it necessary to do so, give a direction in writing to the Corporation with respect to the operation of the reserve price scheme of the Corporation, and the Corporation shall comply with the direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let it be a lesson to us all. Since that time we have had two massive jumps in the reserve price and created a situation whereby the only way to keep the scheme operating was an ever-spiralling tax regime and an ever-growing stockpile of wool. On 1 July last year a decision was made in good faith. The reserve price was lowered from 870c to 700c, but I have to say that at that time I did not agree with the decision. From that point, the world's wool buyers, many of whom were hurt badly by that decision, said, `We don't trust you any more'. The fact we have to face is that the reserve price went too high. It became a market price centre and the industry could not afford the costs of it any more. The reality that was not faced was that under this scheme farmers and graziers were going to go on producing more and more wool to the point where we were producing two million bales a year more than our average sales had been over the last 10 years. At the price that was set, there was no opportunity for wool to compete effectively against other fibres. There was little opportunity for development of additional uses for the product, particularly in the area of blends.

SPEECH.PARA: With the announcement of the suspension of sales in late January, the reserve price was effectively finished. The world did not believe, nor did it have faith, that we would not endeavour to fiddle with the reserve price and it could come back into the marketplace and buy with confidence. The real criticism that I have of the Minister in all of this is that he allowed the scheme to go to a level where it was effectively bankrupt and had to cancel wool sales because of lack of finance. For the Government to have guaranteed $2.8 billion of borrowings and not know the precise status of that money is deplorable. If it is good enough for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to say that the South Australian Treasurer should have been keeping a watching brief on the finances of the State Bank of South Australia, then certainly both he and Minister Kerin should have been on top of the financial situation as it pertained to the Wool Corporation.

It is worth noting that, since the scheme was put in place and until recent events, the highest levels of the stockpile have been in 1974-75, with 1,600,016 bales, and at the end of the 1983-84 season, with 1,233,000 bales. We surpassed those figures approximately 12 months ago. At that time I personally gave warnings to the wool industry that the time to move to correct the problem was then. I regret very much that I did not pursue that much more vigorously. I accept, quite readily, part of the blame for that. The situation was obvious, and I should have fought a bit harder, as should have many other people. It is now history. We did not move to correct the oversupply situation, nor sell more wool, either by forward sales by the use of credit or any other mechanism that may have been available. In terms of marketing and promotion of the wool industry, one can say that it has been quite deplorable. We just sat back and thought that the rest of the world would front up. We also did not address the issue of price.

The industry's leadership's solution was to have an ever-increasing taxing regime. In other words, what was being created was, in effect, a dog chasing its tail. First of all it was a proposed tax of 25 per cent, which the Minister rejected with our support. Then it became a 20 per cent maximum tax set at 18 per cent. It was then raised to 25 per cent during the season. Is it any wonder that confidence was lost? Even the industry itself did not know where it was going. This created enormous inequity between producers. The crisis in the industry continued to grow and the answer became to increase the maximum tax regime to 50 per cent and quotas. This would never work because we cannot instantly stop sheep from growing wool. We might be able to decide not to plant a crop, but if we have sheep out in the paddock we cannot stop them from growing wool.

It was at this point that the Opposition, we on this side of the chamber, began to differ markedly from the Government's approach. We rejected quotas outright, said that supply and demand had to be brought into line and suggested that the commercial flock adjustment scheme should be implemented immediately. Instead, the Government and the Australian Democrats passed legislation for increased taxing and gave notice that a quota system was the way to go. In my view, that was the last opportunity that the Wool Corporation had to save the reserve price scheme, and that could be done only by selling more wool and having a major flock reduction scheme, not a quota scheme. Even so, the limited scheme that was put in place did account for close to 10 million sheep at an average cost of approximately $3.70. Had we put a commercial scheme in place, I have no doubt that it would have gone a long way to addressing the oversupply problem.

In going into a free marketplace even in the current situation we still have potentially massive oversupply, particularly when we look at the problems in our traditional markets such as eastern Europe and Russia. I suggest that a commercial slaughter scheme should stay very high on the agenda. I know it was unpalatable but nonetheless it was the most humane way to go in order to maximise the number of farmers staying in the industry and, at the same time, keep a reserve price in place and keep wool at the top of the tree as an export earner. Today we are faced with a stockpile with a value that is close to $5m and a debt that is close to $3 billion. I welcome the Government's decision to provide $300m to assist the Australian Wool Corporation to provide equity to growers who have yet to sell this season.

However, I cannot support giving the Wool Corporation what is virtually an open cheque by lifting the borrowings of the Corporation to $3.5 billion. I believe that is fiscal irresponsibility. I support wholeheartedly the position of the Opposition in respect of putting a cap on the total payout under the deficiency payments scheme. Any shortfall between the market price and the 700c should be met by the sale of assets of the Corporation and a substantial reduction in the overheads of the Corporation. The potential should be there to do this. The AWC will have a very reduced role in terms of staffing and other aspects of expenditure required.

I support aspects of the Bill other than the amendments moved by the coalition, particularly in relation to section 148 (2). I cannot agree in principle that a Minister should have the power to amend any provision of this Act or, for that matter any other Act, by regulation. I do not know whether this has been done before but it would set what I would term a dangerous precedent. If amendments need to be made to Acts, those Acts should be brought back to this Parliament. In fact I think it is absolutely outrageous that this should even be in the Bill before us now.

I turn now to the three very important challenges we have before us. In doing that, it is important that we turn our minds to the best way of resolving these problems and challenges. The first challenge concerns the management of the stockpile. This must be frozen for at least 12 months and a strategy worked out on its management and proper release into the marketplace. It would be an absolute disaster in terms of the recovery period in front of us-allowing the world to adjust to a new marketing situation-even to contemplate releasing that wool. That must be at least 12 months in the future. Some so-called experts-and I have some doubts about the experts who have advised the wool industry in recent years-have suggested it could even be a period of two or three years. In this respect, I appeal to Mr Kerin to utilise the expertise on this side of the chamber when working out the mechanism so that every pearl of wisdom can be contributed to the final decision.

The second issue which needs addressing immediately is the mechanism by which deficiency payments will be made. The payments must be fair and must go only to bone fide wool producers who normally sell wool during this period and they must be processed as quickly as possible. The draft proposals I have seen floating around in recent days have holes large enough to drive a truck through. It is very complicated and if they are not handled carefully we could have the situation where there could be collusion between buyers, and between buyers and growers, to take unfair advantage of the payments. It is important that this problem be addressed. The most important thing is to keep it simple because simplicity is the surest way to ensure fairness. Some of the formulas and documents I have looked at have been hard to follow. Indeed, I have yet to find anybody who understands precisely what they mean. When growers' figures are put into them, they end up being almost impossible to determine.

I have serious reservations about our performance in terms of marketing. For example, America is one of the largest users, if not the largest user, of apparel fibre. According to the figures, America's consumption of wool, particularly Australian wool, has not changed very much over the past decade. In view of our relationship with the United States, why have we not been marketing and promoting wool more in the American marketplace? Why have we not been promoting Australian wool? While I do not object to or knock the promotion of generic wool, why not promote Australian wool? Russia, China and the countries of eastern Europe have been significant users of our wool in recent years. I know, as does everyone else, that they have significant economic problems. These problems have interfered with their ability to operate in the marketplace and have contributed significantly to our problems. However, they are traditional buyers of our products and we should get in there and market the product and come to some arrangement on how the product will be handled. Why have we been storing wool at a cost of $300 a bale every two years? Why were we not using that $300 to invest in these wool industries and keep them operating? It would have made more sense had we invested that $300 in the pipeline and got something out of it at the other end instead of paying it to warehouses and to banks in interest and creating enormous storage problems in this country.

The Minister's trip to eastern Europe and Russia last year was welcome, but it should have occurred at least six to nine months earlier. The problem was with us then. Unfortunately the unequivocal guarantee that the 700c would remain was given at that time and nobody believed it. It would have been better with hindsight-I know it is hindsight now-had none of that been said. We must get back into Europe and win back the confidence of the buyers, the traditional users of Australian wool, which is the best wool in the world. The buyers of Europe were certainly hurt more than the other part of the industry with the drop from 870c to 700c because they were buying our wool at that time and they had our wool in the pipeline. I believe we must look at some way by which we can assist these buyers to overcome their losses. It seems to me that, when we have the sort of stockpile of wool we have today, we must come to some arrangement with them in order to win back their confidence and get them back to their traditional way of not only buying our wool but also of using, promoting and selling the finished product.

We must win back the confidence of the Japanese. I know many of us do not have much sympathy for the antics of the Japanese in a number of areas, but nonetheless the Japanese market is very important to us. It is important that we encourage the Japanese to buy wool. It is also important to get it into China and utilise the facilities of its mills. We have an enormous task in front of us. We should leave no stone unturned in our efforts to get Australian wool into every fibre processing plant in the world.

It is pointless to suspend the reserve price at this time. It will create continuing uncertainty and lack of confidence, such as the lack of confidence which has beset this industry during recent times. As I said earlier in my speech, not only did I support the reserve price scheme but I was also a vigorous defender of it. It has certainly given me much pain to come to this conclusion. I do not believe that in the current situation we can afford to leave it in place because it will just create suspicion that will not go away until the decision is made. I cannot agree to allowing the Wool Corporation's debt to blow out and out. By doing that, we would not only place a horrendous tax burden on producers, including myself, but we would also be mortgaging the children of future woolgrowers. I think that, when we make decisions in this place today, we should think about that debt and about the individuals who are the future woolgrowers of Australia.

As I said at the start of my comments, this is a very sad and difficult day for me as a woolgrower. It is also a very difficult day for the constituents that I know so well in Western Australia and the rest of Australia. I have listened to the debate; I have seen the emotion. In the last 25 or 26 meetings I have been to I have seen grown men cry, and it certainly has been a very draining experience. I hope I never have to go through it again.

I make an appeal, albeit an emotional appeal at this stage: the time has come for us to put our differences behind us and to recognise the situation we are in with the people involved in the shearing industry-the rouseabouts. When I go back home-I am sure this is occurring all over Australia-I am going to find it very difficult to tell these people, including one shearer who has worked for me for 17 years and another who has worked for me for 14 years, that we are going to do our own crutching in a crutching cradle because we cannot afford to pay them. That is when one gets down to the human face of what has happened in this industry.

I hope that the people who share most of the blame-the Minister and members of the board of the Corporation and the Wool Council-will now put their differences behind them, take away some of their blind faith, get out into the world and create a situation where our product can survive. It not only affects us as wool growers, but it also affects the shearers, the crutchers and the people who work in the sheds, the wool stores and a whole host of people in other areas who are directly or indirectly reliant on the wool industry. The industry and the individuals in it are too important for us to continue to attempt to solve this problem through the press.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991. It is not an easy debate for me to participate in as a farmer, a National Party senator, a member of the New South Wales Farmers Association or just an ordinary Australian. A number of conflicting views, opinions, options and solutions have been proffered in this debate. There is a wide divergence of views in the industry, on what growers should do and on what the Parliament should do.

SPEECH.PARA: I can only say that the conclusions I have reached on the industry and the decisions my colleagues in the other place have made and spoken about yesterday have been arrived at after considerable contemplation, much discussion with growers, and considerable reading of charts, figures, forecasts and predictions. I do not for one minute suggest that I get any joy from standing here and saying that I support the abandonment of the reserve price scheme.

This scheme has served the growers well for many years. I can recall its introduction, although I was not in Parliament at that time, and I remember well the chaos and the financial dilemma that the wool industry was in prior to its introduction. I congratulate the Sir William Gunns and the Ron Hunters for their contribution to the industry at that time and the arguments they faced in setting up the scheme, because the wool industry was very divided when that scheme was set up. I also congratulate the Doug Anthonys for what they did at that time. It has served us very well. But times change, and in these uncertain economic times and changing world conditions, no industry can afford to remain static- least of all the rural industries.

Who would have thought, for example, that wheat growers today would be facing such falls in the price of wheat. Only 12 months ago our markets, particularly in the Middle East, looked secure and were growing. Twelve months on, we have world overproduction, an international conflict in Iraq and a trade war being engaged between the European Community and America, and Australian wheat growers are the innocent victims in the side-slashing of that.

For those of us in the National Party, this issue is just that much more personal, and Senator Crane made reference to it a minute ago. Not only are our constituents wool growers, but many of our friends, families and relatives are wool growers. It is especially hard for me and my colleagues to stand here and say to those people-I have come to this realisation- `Your industry is in a mess. The floor price is finished and has to stay finished. You have a massive debt and you have to trade your way out of it. You can't rely on the Australian taxpayer to do it for you.'

It is also important that what we as legislators do with this legislation ensures that the industry gets back on its feet quickly and that appropriate marketing strategies are adopted. I am critical of this legislation in that it does not provide that desperately needed confidence and direction for the industry and that is why the Opposition amendments must be included in the Bill.

The industry must know where it is going and what costs it faces. The open-ended arrangements provided by this legislation are not appropriate. They will do nothing to provide answers to growers who do not know what is happening to their industry-when they will sell their wool, or how much they will get for it.

Our goal must be to settle the wool market as quickly as we can, so that the sales can resume; so that buyers will return to the market confident that the prices they pay are not likely to be devalued next week or next month. While I regret that the reserve price scheme is finished, I have to support moves to ensure that the messages that go through are firmly conveyed to the industry-to the buyers and to the growers, the producers. We must get stability back. We must increase demand and get production back in line with that demand. That cannot happen while growers live in confusion and buyers are too nervous to enter the market.

In looking back over the industry and the history of wool, it is interesting and important-as others have already done-to acknowledge that unlike any other industry, wool has been Australia's shining knight. Australians have ridden on the back of the wool industry for a long time. The industry has seen both good times and bad. Wool is one commodity we grow better than anyone else in the world. But it is no good growing it if we do not have consumers using it. We have to sell it to get the consumers to use it.

In looking at the history of the reserve price scheme, it is interesting to read what the right honourable Ian Sinclair, the former Minister for Primary Industry, had to say last night in the other place. He said:
The scheme I introduced was not one that set a market price. It was a scheme that was designed as a potholing scheme.

In hindsight, if we are to consider when the system got out of kilter, it may well be when the reserve price scheme stopped being a potholer and began to be relied on as a price setter; it became a price support mechanism. I will quote again what the right honourable Ian Sinclair said in the other place last night. He was talking about what happened to the scheme he started off in 1972 and what happened in 1987. He said:

It is fascinating that for so long it proved so successful until the Minister changed the requirement of consultation with Treasury, removed ministerial control over the setting of the floor price and removed the requirement that the comparability of the wool price with that of other fibres be taken as a criterion in determining the market floor.

How and why the changes to that legislation came about is open to conjecture. That removed the ministerial controls which applied in the original 1972 Act. Certainly, it has been a big contributing factor to the problems that we have in the industry at the moment. What started as a policy of minimum price, kept by the Government well below the market level to serve as a safety net in case of sudden market dips, was changed by the Australian Wool Corporation to a policy of price maximisation. In making that change, the Corporation and the industry failed to remember the basic principle of marketing: something is worth only what someone is willing to pay for it.

In the glorious, heady days of the 870c floor, when middle micron wools were making well in excess of that, market signals were ignored, and any of us who were in the industry at the time have to admit that. Naturally, growers increased their production to take advantage of the increase in the floor. I do not think they can really be blamed for that. Neither can they be entirely blamed for not listening to early warning signals. We must remember that 18 months ago the industry had no stockpile to speak of. The turnaround came very quickly.

There were people trying to tell the industry that all was not well. The former Wool Corporation Chairman, David Asimus, warned of potential consumer reaction to the increased floor. He even suggested how long that resistance would take to manifest itself in sales. I am sure that he takes no joy today in knowing that he was right at that time.

Of course, added to the industry's difficulties were the actions of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, who dallied with the industry last year when rumours first started to circulate about the floor price. The statements he made then and has made since have done irreparable damage to the industry. He will be long remembered for his statement last year at the time the floor was lowered to 700c. He said then, and has repeated frequently since:
My clear message to the market is that 700c is immutable. The next time the floor price is changed it will be upward.

He said that in May of last year and has repeated it frequently. He also said in June last year that the Vines inquiry into wool pricing policy would not affect the reserve price. We all now know that this legislation was precipitated by the Vines committee, which-it has been confirmed by the Minister himself-spoke to our European buyers earlier this year about the possibility of the floor price being dropped to 500c. For an industry marketing system that survives on confidence, that was sufficient to send the already nervous buyers out of the market again. What a pity it is that tonight and yesterday we did not have the benefit of the Vines committee report before this debate started. What a pity it is not coming out until the end of March.

Of course, the stockpile started to grow and today the industry faces a stockpile of some 4.7 million bales of wool, a mountain of wool, with a debt of just under $3 billion and the prospect of a blow-out to $4 billion by the end of the selling season. Figures and advice provided to the members of the National Party and the Liberal Party suggest that this situation cannot continue and ought not to be allowed to continue, despite the growers' desires to keep the status quo. Under the existing reserve price and tax scheme there was no affordable way around the problem. There was no way that I, as a member of the Australian Parliament, would allow the Australian woolgrowers to be saddled with more and more debt.

It would have been irresponsible in the extreme to allow the Corporation to continue to amass such a debt. I remind the Senate that there are still 2.5 million bales to be sold before the end of this season, and, of course, the normal demand for the wool in that time is only 1.4 million bales of wool. I can see horrendous problems in that period.

Similarly, it would be irresponsible for this Parliament to allow this legislation to pass without providing a cap on the size of the debt that can be accrued. As I said, I think we would be very irresponsible to allow, as Senator Crane said, the mortgaging of our children-the future woolgrowers. It has been suggested that the assets of the Wool Corporation could be raided to meet the debt. While the Corporation cannot remain blameless and must accept responsibility for some of the industry's problems, we cannot allow the Corporation to be dismantled, although, if it is in the best interests of the industry, there could be a rationalisation of the assets and other cost cuttings.

The Corporation provides a range of valuable services to the wool industry and in the years to come the industry will need those services. It will need help to restructure and rebuild its reputation, and the services that the Wool Corporation provides are going to be invaluable.

I have read the criticisms made by the Wool Council about the Opposition parties. While I accept that it is the Council's right to make such criticisms, I am saddened that its members have not the same courage that I believe we have in the National and Liberal parties to take the hard decisions, to face the realities-bitter and unpalatable as they are-and also to accept their share of the blame, because they too are in part to blame.

I recall last year, when there was so much confusion and so little known about what was going on, that the Wool Council did not communicate with its members particularly well and it did not communicate very well with the Opposition. Maybe the Government was also not particularly well communicated with. I just quote from some points that Mr Lloyd, the shadow Minister for primary industry, made in the other place last night. He said:

The real point is that the National Party is, as it was then, in existence to represent country people, regional people, and particularly-as far as I am concerned-those people who make their living from the land. At all times we have to be aware of what is the best policy for those people. As we have at times indicated that things should be done for those people, equally we have a responsibility to be honest and, if what is in place is no longer to their advantage, say so. And we did, believing that in the medium term and the longer term, with the scheme not sustainable, wool growers would be better off with the removal of the floor price. That is a very grave statement to make, but on the evidence available to me and to others I believe that is an undisputable fact.

I think that he summed up the position very well. We now have to look to the future. Rather than spend the next few weeks and months looking for scapegoats and apportioning blame, it is vital that the industry works together to get back on track.

At the recent rally outside Parliament House growers and their leaders urged a return of confidence to the market and a resumption of wool sales. We in the National Party and Liberal Party believe that our actions will provide that. Sales must resume. We still have too many bales to sell and time is running out. Sales must start again, but they must be allowed to be conducted in a confident and stable market. There are 18 weeks of sales left, with 140,000-odd bales a week, but that can and will happen only if we give clear and unambiguous signals to the industry, to both growers and buyers, that the legislation we are putting in place today is precise and immutable. That is what the Minister, Mr Kerin, cannot give. He is saying to the industry that we shall let the floor price not be on for a little while, but he does not say whether it will come back on, or if it does come back on at what price. For people to have confidence, we have to say that it has gone for the moment. Buyers can purchase knowing that they will not be undercut. Somebody who wants to pay a little less will not get the product; but if somebody pays a little more he will get the wool.

It is also important that the stockpile be frozen for 12 months and disposed of in an orderly and predictable manner according to specified legislation. That is the immediate problem facing the industry. The next problem to be faced is to get production back more in line with demand. We have too many sheep in the country. Some commentators suggest that we have as many as 50 million sheep too many. We have 76,000 growers, 22,000 of whom are specialist woolgrowers owning 175 million sheep. Clearly the wool market cannot sustain that level of production. We need to reduce our wool clip, and that is obvious, but how we do that is not so obvious. Every grower must play a part.

Of course, the Federal Government will account for some reduction by the mere fact that some growers will be forced off their lands by banks, by the sheer impossibility of trying to live on negative incomes. In the estimation of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, some 25 per cent of woolgrowers are `under stress'. Mr Hugh Beggs, the Chairman of the Corporation, puts the figure as high as between 30,000 and 40,000. I only hope that in that eventuality the rural adjustment and assistance measures are adequate to meet the demand, and they must be. I have written to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the last few weeks asking for assistance for people who wish to defer their tax payments on previous years. I want to ensure that people are not penalised in their quarterly payments of provisional tax.

Last year on the wool tax Bills I proposed a slaughter-cull scheme. It is unpalatable, but it is still the best option for reducing our flock. There are still too many old ewes being bred and they need to be got out of the system. I give my commitment to people in the industry on the question of rural adjustment and rural assistance, to people who need counselling and to those affected by this Government's changes to the wool industry that have been brought about by knocking industry confidence in the past year or so.

The third problem that must be addressed is how best to get wool industry compensation. The Australian Council of Wool Buyers has called for an emergency meeting of world wool industry leaders to be convened in Australia to allow the industry at least to put its views on recent events in Australia. We tend to forget that buyers, too, have been hurt and misled. Let us not forget that last year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy toured the world saying that the 700c floor price was immutable.

We tend to forget that there are people on the other side of the industry. It will be a long time before international wool buyers and indeed commodity buyers can trust the word of the Australian Government. We need to redress that lack of trust and to try in some measure to restore Australia's reputation as a reliable supplier. People in the Japanese industry are very concerned, we know that the Italian wool industry is very concerned, and there are other buyers around the world who must be considered. Any industry has to have a bit in it for the producer, the person who mills the fibre, the person who wants to get the commodity at a competitive price with other fibres. People are in this industry together-the growers, the people in the middle industry and the people who are in end industries.

Last year I had the opportunity to meet Mr Bud Leventhal, the President of Burlington Industries, which is widely acknowledged as one of the world's largest textile manufacturers; it employs 6,000 people. I met him at a time when there was much speculation in Australia about the future of the reserve price scheme. He told me that as a buyer he did not really care what the price was just so long as he had continuity of supply and stability of price. That is what we must get going again. Growers and government alike must look after Australia's customers. Judging by the way in which the wool industry has been conducted over the past six months, is it any wonder that the buyers have no confidence and growers are completely confused? I believe that this Hawke Labor Government has misled both sides of the industry, growers and consumers.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, it gives me no great joy tonight to support the dismantling of what has been a remarkable success story in the reserve price scheme. However, it is important that we in the National and Liberal parties demonstrate that we are capable of making tough decisions, and we do so believing them to be in the best interests of woolgrowers specifically and of Australia generally. As I said earlier, in no way could I stand responsibly here and see the Australian woolgrower burdened with even more debt than he has to cope with at the moment. Time will tell if we are right. I have every confidence that history will judge us to be correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool Marketing (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill 1991, which the Senate is now debating, seeks to amend the Wool Marketing Act 1987 to provide for a wool industry supplementary payments scheme and to suspend the reserve price scheme. I believe that this Bill is vital for the survival of the wool industry as we know it at present. Australia has ridden on the sheep's back for years. The wool industry has over time provided so much of our export earnings. It is Australia's greatest earner of export dollars. Some 99 per cent of Australian wool is Australian owned and 97 per cent is exported-or perhaps I should say that it was until the troubles in recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: Wool has always helped Australia to pay its way, yet today in Australia wool has become so expendable that we daily read of farmers who have to shoot their flocks because it is not even profitable to ship these worthless animals to market. As one newspaper headline said, `$1.80 will buy you one beer or 18 sheep'.

The wool industry faces a very difficult time. Production is dramatically ahead of demand, so naturally we are witnessing an ever-increasing stockpile problem. With that are rapidly increasing taxes to finance the purchase and storage of those stockpiles. How dreadful it is that this once great industry has been reduced to such circumstances. I ask honourable senators: how can we have had such a profitable and efficient industry so quickly destroyed in a few years?

Just why are Australian woolgrowers in this current situation? Less than a year ago we debated in this chamber the Government's legislation to drop the wool floor price. The Government may have thought that it was helping the industry by its action of dropping the floor price, but I say to honourable senators that all it did was to help destroy the industry. The marketing scheme had been great for the wool industry and for Australia. Our sometimes first, and sometimes second, largest export earner-the wool industry-had developed and made an enormous contribution to our export earnings. European and Japanese wool buying interests disliked the success of the wool marketing scheme. They were not able to manipulate the market, and they have not benefited from the periodic collapse in price that was familiar prior to 1970 when the scheme was put into place.

For 20 years the Australian wool industry benefited from unprecedented price stability, yet the Government decided to intervene purely because it was unhappy that money was not going quickly enough into the Treasury coffers to cover the enormous balance of payments that it had created. As I told the Senate last year in a number of debates on this issue, nowhere had it been demonstrated-as distinct from asserted-that, were the offer price for Australian wool to be lowered, there would be any kind of direct and significant demand response. Further, and more importantly, it had not been shown that any such response would ensure that gross income to the industry would increase or even be maintained. Our current growing wool stockpiles, I regret, are testament to those predictions.

As I told the Senate, interference by the Government would only ruin the reserve price scheme and ravage future orderly wool marketing. We have to realise that the speculation about the floor price has done marked damage that may not be recoverable. The slightest doubt and lack of resolution only gave the buyers encouragement to continue their resistance to the floor price. Today Mr Kerin and, sadly, woolgrowers are having to adapt to some of those consequences. It is not that wool has been surpassed as a fine material.
