Woolgrowers are not facing a situation where a synthetic fibre has been developed that can replicate the desirable and superior characteristics of wool-not at any price, let alone a comparable one.

We can confirm this fact if we look at sales and exports data in the period prior to the reduction of the floor price last year. In the eight months to 28 February 1990 several traditional large and important wool buying countries with sophisticated and high technology processing industries had substantially improved their wool imports compared with the same period in the previous year. For instance, West Germany had increased its wool imports by 49 per cent; Italy by 9 per cent; the Netherlands by a huge 377 per cent; the United Kingdom by 9 per cent; and Taiwan by 19 per cent. But where countries purchased significantly less wool it has been agreed, in most cases, to be due to a shortage of foreign exchange currency, as in the Soviet Union, China and eastern Europe. The Australian Wool Corporation in its annual report last year said:

Demand . . . fell sharply, partly in response to high market prices in 1988 but also as major export markets in China, Russia and Eastern Europe almost collapsed because of totally unpredictable economic and political changes.

The conclusions, therefore, must be that today we are dealing with normal economic market forces of supply, demand and price. As such, we are constantly focusing at the moment on the supply side of the argument instead of looking at the demand side. The Government, together with the industry, should be doing more to address this aspect of the equation instead of constantly talking about reducing the supplies of wool. That means not only looking at an aggressive marketing system but also searching out markets, which we would never have contemplated in the past.

It should also be looking to find ways in which wool can be marketed not only a luxurious commodity but also as an essential part of everyday living. I well remember the cool wool campaign that the Australian Wool Board took up some years ago, and the great success that that was. Raw wool price has little effect on demand for wool. It did not in the late 1960s and early 1970s before the reserve price scheme began, when prices fluctuated wildly and buyers never minded the price of wool as long as it was relative to the price of other fibres. The only conclusion to be drawn is that the academic economists' approach to the current wool industry battle is badly flawed. It is no good talking all the time about a free market in a world where the free market, regrettably, does not operate. We should be ever vigilant that we do not allow ideology on economic issues and crass politics to misplace the needs of people. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Collins)-by leave-agreed to:

That Senator Reynolds be discharged from further attendance on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority and that Senator Jones, having been duly nominated in accordance with the National Crime Authority Act 1984, be appointed a member of the Committee.
Motion (by Senator Collins) proposed;
That the Senate do now adjourn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a statement on behalf of the President. Earlier today Senator Schacht asked the President two questions concerning the circulation of certain documents to senators by Senator McLean. The first question related to the right of a senator to circulate to other senators documents which the Senate has not permitted to be tabled. The circulation of documents by a senator to other senators is not a matter over which the President, or the Senate itself, has any control. It is a matter entirely within the responsibility of individual senators.

INTERJECT.PARA: The President emphasises, as he did in responding initially to Senator Schacht's question, that the tabling of documents in the Senate automatically authorises the publication of the documents and makes the documents part of the proceedings of the Senate with the full protection of parliamentary privilege. The circulation of documents to senators does not authorise their further publication and does not necessarily attract any privilege. The circulation of documents to senators may be incidental to the transacting of the business of the Senate and may, therefore, attract the protection of section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act, but that is not a matter on which the President wishes to express any concluded view in this or any other particular case.

The second question related to the use of the documents by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its inquiry into the cost of justice in Australia. The Committee could seek to have the documents laid before it and could seek to hear evidence in relation to the documents, but that is a matter for the Committee to determine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must express my concern as to the future of 9,000 disabled Australians in sheltered workshops if there is not a careful reassessment of policy by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) and his Department regarding the Disability Services Act (DSA). I refer to the policy objective of retraining disabled people for open employment, while phasing out segregated employment in sheltered workshops. Whatever the merits of the ideal of open employment and independent living, policy cannot be humane if it ceases to be realistic.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I am posing a simple and relevant question as to whether it is feasible at a time of sharply rising unemployment to be preparing people for jobs that they cannot get. Australia has an unemployment rate of 8.4 per cent, and that in Western Australia has reached 9.3 per cent. It is a sober fact that we could soon be looking at a situation where one Australian in 10 is seeking work. Just what opportunities will this provide intellectually disabled people, no matter how willing? Even more important, should not a humane policy ensure that sheltered workshops are able to provide a meaningful lifestyle to disabled people who otherwise will not be able to work?

There was great concern among employees of workshops and their families when in November last year the Minister was stating that the Government would not arbitrarily close any service that was needed by disabled people while, at the same time, warning against obstructive organisations. If a workshop is arbitrarily excommunicated under the DSA, funding after 1992, to say the least, is in doubt.

Employees and parents are not getting the answers they need and deserve. At a public meeting in Bunbury on 12 January, called by the concerned parents of disabled people attending the Gelorup Training Centre, an officer of the Department was asked the very question I am raising: what chance do the intellectually disabled have of finding work when the non-disabled have difficulty? The answer from the minutes refers to `funding for independent living and services'. It seems that this amounts to making unemployment tolerable.

It has been stated in submissions to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs inquiring into employment of the disabled that in practical terms successful competitive employment placement is directed to those workers who are the least handicapped. Even if they can get and retain jobs, those with greater impairment will need workshops. So too are the families, with parents getting older, who would be caring for them if they were deprived of this activity. All too often there has been denigration of sheltered workshops for paying low wages and failing to provide what is described as meaningful work. There may indeed be some organisations that deserve criticism, but I can only say that it is certainly not my experience of institutions such as the Good Samaritan Industries in Perth.

The fact remains, however, that thousands of Australians will have a continual need for sheltered workshops and the Hawke Labor Government must make a stronger commitment to providing this essential support, if necessary in preference to the implementation of the more idealistic aspects of the Disability Services Act. The reality of the Keating recession makes it irresponsible to pursue these objectives rather than ensure that limited taxpayer funds are used to maintain an essential service.

I do ask whether the Minister will seek from the Department an assurance that the program of open employment under the Disability Services Act is still relevant, given the dramatic deterioration of employment opportunities and whether the continuation of funding for sheltered workshops will be reassessed in the light of the increased difficulties that disabled people are likely to encounter if they have to seek competitive employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to express my concern about the safety of Australian sailors on shore leave in the Middle East. I do this because of the news that I have learnt of the tragic death of a young Italian sailor while on shore leave in Dubai. Cosimo Carlino, aged 19 and from Calabria, served on one of the Italian ships in the Gulf-the Stromboli, a supply ship. The Stromboli was at the end of her mission and was about to return to Italy. Cosimo Carlino was a conscript and the youngest of eight children.

SPEECH.PARA: At 3.30 on the afternoon of 13 Feb- ruary, Rosa Carlino, his mother, received a telephone call from Cosimo who was phoning from a public telephone in Dubai. Cosimo was excitedly telling his mother that he would be home by 1 March and that she must not worry about him, when his voice suddenly stopped short. It was at that very moment that he received a fatal stab wound. He bravely chased his assassin for 150 metres before collapsing, and he died three hours later on the operating table in Dubai hospital.

As reported in Il Globo of 18 February 1991, the murder is regarded as a political crime committed by a supporter of Saddam Hussein, according to the Head of Police of the United Arab Emirates. I am told that the Carlino family has a lot of relatives and Calabrian friends in the Calabrian community in Perth, Western Australia. There was a commemorative mass held in St Lawrence's Church in the northern Perth suburb of Balcatta yesterday evening. I wish it to be placed on record that I send my respects and compassionate good wishes to the Perth relatives and Calabrian friends of young Cosimo Carlino. I must add the sincere hope that suitable security arrangements are in place for the protection of all Australia sailors who might be on shore leave in the Middle East and elsewhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this adjournment debate to inform honourable senators of some developments that have occurred in the past few hours in relation to the Westpac Banking Corporation documents and other matters surrounding these controversial documents. Honourable senators may not be aware that this afternoon these documents were read into the Hansard in the South Australian Legislative Council and, as such, are now public documents, provided that they are quoted from the Hansard of the South Australian Legislative Council. That was done by the honourable Ian Gilfillan, the State Leader of the Australian Democrats in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon, Senator Schacht in a question to the President, as did Senator Calvert on behalf of the President tonight, drew attention to the fact that I had circulated to honourable senators copies of these documents and other materials which I have tabled before in the Senate during the past two and a half years. Senator Calvert drew attention to the fact that I was quite within my rights to do that.

I advise the Senate that in addition to circulating documents to other senators, I also sent copies of the documents to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). It is probably a matter of interest to senators that I received a letter from Dr Hewson's office this afternoon. It was directed to my office manager and states:
Dear Ms Roach
During Question Time today an envelope was delivered to Dr Hewson's office by a member of your staff who said it contained `Westpac papers'.
This material has not been requested by Dr Hewson and I return it to you unopened.
Yours sincerely
Duncan Fairweather
Chief of Staff.

I think that this action by the chief of staff of the Leader of the Opposition and what has subsequently occurred in a telephone conversation with one of my members of staff, namely, an explanation that Dr Hewson was reluctant to accept these documents because he knew that the matter was before a court, frankly raises my concerns considerably.

That raises the question: is the Leader of the Opposition really saying that he does not accept the same responsibilities under privilege that I, for instance, accept. He has precisely the same privileges of the Parliament as does the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and everybody else. I believe that I was quite within my rights to choose to direct those documents to him as a matter of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not have to accept them.

—Of course he did not have to accept them. In refusing them, surely Dr Hewson is indicating something about his attitude. Will he direct the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate to reject them? Will he direct all Opposition senators to take the same position in relation to these documents of profound public importance, which are in wide circulation in this country and which have been subject to deliberation by the Speaker of the House as to whether actions taken by Westpac are in contempt of the Parliament in relation to those documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Is he really going to tell the world that he is not interested in them, that he does not know about them or that he will reject them because they happen to be before a court of the land? I do not believe that such a rejection is really what was intended by the Leader of the Opposition. I simply ask him, on the record here tonight, whether or not he is directing his Leader in this House, his representatives in this chamber and, indeed, his members in the House of Representatives to adopt the same attitude towards these documents. I think that is a reasonable question to put to Dr Hewson.

The third matter I would like to touch on in the adjournment debate is the circumstances in which Mr John McLennan finds himself. I think that most honourable senators are aware of the fact that John McLennan is a key witness who has made a submission to the bank inquiry. He is clearly acknowledged by that Committee as being a key witness because it has scheduled him to appear before a special session of the inquiry in Coffs Harbour on 20 March.

His submission to the Committee has been released for publication. Within hours of that happening, he was served court orders from the Supreme Court of New South Wales constraining him in relation to these matters. He has appeared before the Supreme Court of New South Wales today in relation to these court orders. Indeed, the Speaker of the House was so concerned about these actions that he was represented by Queen's Counsel before the proceedings in the Supreme Court today.

I suggest to honourable senators that John McLennan has been subjected to extraordinary intimidation as a result of this process. I spoke to him this morning; I speak to him often. This morning he said to me-and he allows me to say this to the Senate-that if he had known what was involved in appearing before a parliamentary inquiry, he would not appear before it in a fit. He has paid $10,000 of his own money in the last 48 hours to cope with the implications of the court orders that were placed upon him at the request of Westpac. That is intimidation of an enormous order. Not only that but also he believes-and he is absolutely confident-that his telephone is tapped; he knows that he is being surveilled. He has been served with similar court orders twice because the first time they were served it was a Sunday-and this is one of the humorous dimensions-and it is not legal to serve such court orders on a Sunday. So he was subjected to a similar process twice.

John McLennan believes that he has been intimidated. Intimidation is a psychological thing; it is not a legal thing. The significant thing is that this intimidation has a secondary spin-off to other people who may have been considering appearing before this inquiry or any other inquiry. Indeed, I would argue that, by undertaking these legal processes, not only has Westpac been in contempt of the Parliament but also it has put in place processes which are profoundly threatening to the parliamentary processes hereafter if they are supported by the courts. It will be possible hereafter to follow this example and to bring down injunctions against potential witnesses and intimidate them massively by virtue of doing that. As a result, whether those injunctions are ultimately effective or not they have dramatically interfered with the processes of the Parliament. Therefore, this very process is in contempt of the parliamentary process.

I turn now to yet another incident of someone being a victim of the banks. About 18 months ago, I tabled in this place the case of a Patricia Poulos who was in dispute with Elders Finance Group Ltd, the Commonwealth Bank and Westpac. As I mentioned in this place the other day, Patricia Poulos has in the last 1 1/2 years spent $1m in litigation in the carriage of her cases in the courts of the land against Elders and two leading banks. Today was doomsday for Patricia Poulos because she was to be evicted from her home at midday. I had conversations with Patricia Poulos last night; she rang me. I had three conversations last evening and one this morning concerning her circumstances because she had convinced me-and I have been convinced of this previously-that the eviction orders which were to be put into effect at midday today were based on fraudulent documents and that the fraudulence of those documents had been admitted in court proceedings and were on the record of the court. Those documents-admitted to being fraudulent-were the basis upon which the eviction notices were issued today and which were going to be proceeded upon.

I took it upon myself to have a discussion with the sheriff of Sutherland Court. He had an open and frank discussion with me. He told me that he had no alternative but to proceed but, of course, he did not. He was acting on the instructions of the court. I asked him whether he was aware of the fact that it was alleged, and in fact possible, that the eviction notices were based upon fraudulent documents. He said he was not aware of that and, accordingly, had no alternative but to proceed.

I had also been advised by Patricia Poulos that she was armed and would resist any entry into her property. I advised her under no circumstances to resist by arms. The media moved in on the issue to observe what was going to happen. I advised the sheriff that he was likely to have a very difficult eviction on his hands, one that could be resisted by arms. As a result of that, at least there has been a 24-hour delay on the process which will occur in relation to the Poulos residence.

If one cites the coincidence in one day of a Patricia Poulos being subjected to this, allegedly over the basis of fraudulent documents, by the Commonwealth Bank, and we cite what John McLennan has been through today in the Supreme Court of New South Wales, as a result of injunctions brought down by Westpac, we see examples of the human dimension of what people suffer-in John McLennan's case, of taking what he believes to be appropriate and rightful action as a concerned and informed citizen and seeking to appear before a parliamentary inquiry and, in Patricia Poulos's case, of going through all the processes of the court at enormous expense and believing that she has been evicted from her home on the basis of fraudulent documents. We could not get a better illustration of what the human dimension of people in disputes with their banks is all about.

I simply draw the attention of honourable senators to the documents which have been incorporated in the Hansard of the South Australian Parliament. Those documents are in the hands of all honourable senators. They are now public. They are on the airwaves of the nation tonight. They deserve to be there. Westpac will be judged and damned by its own words and its own documentary evidence, which is now public evidence. I believe that we have taken, as a nation, a significant step towards honest banking.

Everything that I have done over the last 2 1/2 years and in the last 72 or more hours in relation to those documents I do not resile from in the slightest. I truly believe them to be as they have been described-among the most potent documents in terms of what they, in their own words, admit as to having been the be- haviour of Australia's leading bank. I urgently request that my colleagues peruse those documents and react to them responsibly. I urgently urge Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to consider the documents and give me their response. I got Dr Hewson's response-I got the documents back.
I simply put the developments of today before the Senate. I can assure the Senate that quite clearly there will be further developments to report in future debates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At about the same time as the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Kim Beazley, yesterday was launching what I call retribution on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), journalists at the respected Melbourne newspaper, the Age, walked off the job on a 24-hour strike to protest editorial interference by the Fairfax receiver, as their Sydney colleagues at the Sydney Morning Herald had done the day before.

SPEECH.PARA: At the other end of Melbourne, in the Flinders Street fortress of the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd, a division of News Corp Ltd, a few brave journalists were canvassing support for a meeting tomorrow night to protest editorial censorship on Gulf war stories, particularly those of a local flavour which show Australian resident muslims in a sympathetic light.

These journalists-who have Hobson's choice of working for either Murdoch or Fairfax-were putting their jobs on the line over what they see as editorial `bias'. Yet we have not heard a peep out of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Senator Ray, or their colleagues in the Opposition, about bias in the reporting of the Gulf war by any other news gathering organisations, apart from the numerous vitriolic attacks on the ABC. We know that the Prime Minister prefers to get his news live, though heavily Americanised, from Cable News Network (CNN), courtesy of Channel Ten.

This week the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) has brought down a report accusing the Ten network in receivership of being in breach of section 89q of the Broadcasting Act and has yet to investigate whether one of Ten's major lenders, the United States based Citicorp Bank, may indeed be in breach of foreign ownership restrictions. It is believed that the Tribunal is awaiting a Government decision on whether an offence has been committed.

With this entire mess to sort out, the Communications Minister has decided that the time is right to pick on the ABC for alleged bias in its Gulf war coverage. I think that last night Senator Cooney made some provocative and thought provoking statements on the matter of bias. Can we conclude that bias is only bias when the national broadcaster is not toeing an overtly jingoistic line and refuses to be the Government's press agent over the Gulf war? Or do we conclude that the attacks on the alleged bias in ABC Gulf war coverage are the political equivalent of the stealth bomber-big, ugly and deadly but carefully designed to creep up and prevent advance warning of what is to come?

I believe that the issue of bias is only a smoke-screen to distinguish the real issue, which is that the ABC is now approaching the end of the first triennial block of `inflation proof' funding. During the three-year funding block to date, the Corporation has suffered effective real cuts of $82m to its operating budget. The results have been severe restrictions on its ability adequately to service several defined and diverse audiences, as clearly stated in its charter. In order to redress current inadequacies and restore programming vital to its specialised audiences, the $82m lost over the past three years must be returned in total in the 1991-92 Budget allocation.

By alleging bias and an inadequate complaints procedure, the Government, I believe, is attempting to deflect attention away from its statutory and financial responsibilities to the Corporation. Moreover, it is also a means of avoiding the serious issue of providing adequate funding, and not just restoring what rightfully belongs to the Corporation. There is a need to provide a capital injection for property and re-equipment of the Corporation; to establish an adequate funding base from which future adjustments will be made; to exempt the ABC from arbitrary cuts; and to guarantee that any additional revenue gained by the ABC is to be retained by the Corporation and not deducted from ongoing direct government funding.

The allegations of bias and the call for a watchdog complaints committee are even more than a cynical revenue driven exercise. This is another example of how this Government tampers piecemeal with legislation-in this case it will need drastic surgery to both the Broadcasting Act and the ABC's own special Act of Parliament-while at the same time attempting a major overhaul and restructuring of the broadcasting industry. Is it any wonder that the media industry is constantly complaining that the Government changes the rules while the last few minutes of the game are in progress? Although successive governments have attempted to muzzle the ABC since its inception in 1932, none have succeeded. In the main, this has been because of public outrage.

I think this Government has chosen its time and chosen its ground very carefully. Any criticism of the Gulf war is now seen as a distinct lack of patriotism and, in the ABC's case, akin to national treason. But that may change as the coalition forces embark on a ground offensive and the CNN cameras catch casualties live instead of Christmas lights from fighter planes. In the national interest, it is a very bad time to attempt to muzzle the ABC.

The existence of a watchdog authority could serve to intimidate producers and program makers. In a country where most of the media is controlled by a handful of people, this would seriously jeopardise the functioning of the only independent broadcaster left to the people of Australia.

In the current political climate, where both the Government and the Opposition are in favour of the Gulf war, and the only Federal parliamentary opposition to the war in our democracy is eight Australian Democrats senators, one independent senator, Senator Jo Vallentine, and Ted Mack, MHR, the ABC has a moral and democratic right to its independent viewpoint.

The Minister said that it was bad for the ABC to be investigating itself as it did recently in its internal investigation into its own coverage of the Gulf war. Other critics have suggested that the report was akin to police investigating the police. But I think there is one big difference. Viewers and listeners can switch off the television set or switch over to CNN, provided the Ten network is still allowed to operate. No viewer is forced to accept the findings, or alleged bias, of the ABC. As its charter maintains, the ABC is not a mass market medium. It has a specialised function and role in society. It is the Government which seems to wish to treat the ABC as it would a commercial television network.

In his speech yesterday, Minister Beazley argued that the ABC should be more accountable in the same way as commercial broadcasters were subject to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. He even suggested the ABT as the potential watchdog over the ABC. It is the Government which seems to wish the ABC to accept sponsorship, advertising and audience rating figures, as if the commercial broadcasting industry is some kind of shining example for the ABC to follow. It is the Government which wishes to subject the ABC to the same regulations as the commercial broadcasting industry. But I would argue that the ABC was not intended to be, nor should it become, just another commercial network answerable to market forces and the banks.

Eight cents a day is a very small price to pay for freedom. Some Australians may be willing to pay more than this. This Government and any future government should be warned that no government is going to be allowed to take away this precious right without a fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no wish to unduly prolong the sitting of the Senate this evening, although this being the adjournment, the only senators that are sitting in this chamber are senators who wish to be here, of course; there is no need to stay. I rise to respond just briefly to what Senator Kernot said. I reject categorically and out of hand her assertion that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) is `picking on the ABC' and applying what she says is the pressure to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) because it is convenient to do so at this time. She has accused the Minister of putting direct pressure on the ABC because of this alleged bias-I quote her again-`trying to treat the ABC as if it were a commercial network'.

SPEECH.PARA: Like a lot of people-certainly in the Australian Labor Party, but I would cast the net wider than that-I grew up with the ABC. I grew up with the Goon Show, Around the Horne, and all those wonderful programs of the ABC before television. I have to tell you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I can remember a life before television. I can remember when the first television set arrived in the city in which I lived. I was very young at the time but I can still remember it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mork and Mindy are still alive in the Democrats.
—And they are still alive in me, too.
—Are you an argonaut?

—No, I was never an argonaut. But I have to confess I listened to the Argonauts. I principally grew up relying on the ABC news, and still do. The ABC remains my chief source of news so far as the electronic media is concerned. Like a lot of people in public life, being a public affairs junkie, I listen to the news, and AM and PM and The World Today, Lateline-the lot. I even watch Paul Lyneham on the 7.30 Report. I take it all in--
—You should be fixing up the waterfront, not watching television.

—The reason I am able to do all that-and I hate to say this-is that I get by with about five hours sleep a night. Maybe it is my guilty conscience. Through the miracle of video cassette recorders I am able to watch a great deal of the news. I do not watch all of the programs, but I am pleased to say that my staff record the bits I am interested in. I rely on the ABC for the majority of the news. I simply assert to Senator Kernot that I know Mr Beazley's particular personal views on the ABC. He has the same admiration and commitment for the organisation that I have, and many people on this side of the chamber have.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I make those points-without being tedious about it-is that I think Senator Kernot, with respect, is being a little precious about the ABC. It is because it is not a commercial television channel that it is more important, in my view, to ensure that we as a parliament have a more critical role to play in our assessment of the ABC's performance than a commercial television channel, because it is a public broadcaster; it is our broadcaster. It prides itself-as it should-on the impartial way in which it approaches its very responsible job of informing Australia about the news.

I have a view on bias-like everyone else in public life-and I say this without hesitation because the public record will show that I have never complained about bias in reporting, whether it is by the ABC or the Northern Territory News, our only daily newspaper, provided that bias is contained in that part of the reporting which is identified as being opinion. I would be appalled at the suggestion that bias, so-called, should be removed from journalism. It is bias that has a stimulating effect on people who read and see it; it is bias that provokes by its very nature the debate which the Fourth Estate has got such an essential role as part of our democratic system role in promoting; and it is bias which-dare I say it-entertains as well as informs.

In my view, all journalists, whether they work for the ABC or not, have an absolute obligation-indeed, I know that the Australian Journalists Association's ethics say this-to keep that bias out of reporting. In my view, it does not just apply to the ABC; it applies to everyone. But where it is identified as opinion-much of the television coverage on the Gulf war has clearly been identified as opinion-I think that what fair-minded broadcasters have to do, but particularly the ABC, is to ensure, as I have recently said in relation to the controversy over the sacked announcer from the public radio station, not that they do not present that opinion, in so far as it is possible in the time they have available to them, but that a broad range of opinions are expressed on that subject.

I think that is all one can ask of any broadcaster. Like everyone else, I have been intrigued and interested to see that the Gulf war, as well as providing the dreadful and ongoing tragedy, has also provided the most extraordinary boost for every retired colonel, general and air force major-they all seem to become consultants and analysts after they retire from the armed services-that it is possible to collect in one spot to talk about the war. There is no question that it is within those reports that the perceptions of bias to a great extent have occurred. The reason I comment on that is that in a recent interview panel I saw-I think it was on the ABC-talking about bias, one of the people being interviewed in terms of his analysis of whether he thought there had been bias or not struck a chord with me when he said that there had been so much continuous wall to wall coverage on the television channels on the Gulf war, there had been so much information flow coming in, that it would be very difficult to precisely determine without detailed analysis afterwards whether there had been any consistent bias one way or the other.

Frankly, in much of the coverage I saw-and like everyone else I have been hopping from one channel to the other-I agreed with that analysis. But the ABC has a special place in news and public broadcasting in Australia that is not shared by the commercial television channels. The reason I make that point is that I want to refute Senator Kernot's statement that we can deal with the question of bias on the ABC-and she said this-`by simply switching it off'. With respect, that is what she said-if people are upset about bias on the ABC they can simply turn it off and switch to another channel. That is what I meant when I said, with respect, that Senator Kernot was being a bit precious about the ABC.

The reason I do not think that the ABC should be afraid-and I know that it is not-of any analysis of the broadcasting or the current affairs programming that it runs is that I know how sensitive it is, from personal experience, and how responsive it is to the responsibilities that it does have to prepare balanced reports. After 15 years in public life I am well aware of that. The ABC in the Northern Territory has been publicly accused of bias on many occasions. It reached a point where the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Paul Everingham, complained so trenchantly about bias in respect of the only public affairs program on radio not just on the ABC but in the Northern Territory. That was a program called After Eight- or Morning Extra I think it was called in those days-the only public affairs broadcast on radio on which he refused, publicly, to appear or to give interviews to any of its journalists.

In respect of those matters, I know that the ABC meticulously records, literally minute by minute, the amount of air time on the radio and the television that it gives to a particular point of view. I know from personal experience that it is in a position to respond with some degree of accuracy, on the occasions that have come to my notice, to accusations of bias with some informative opinion about whether it is biased or not. The reason I make that point is, from my experience with the ABC, it does not resent accusations of bias being made against it in the sense that it feels it is being unfairly singled out. The ABC does not respond to it by saying, `Why do you pick on us?'.

In my experience with the ABC, it simply acknowledges that it does play a role which subjects it to this accusation of bias far more than any other broadcaster does, because the ABC is the public broadcaster and is therefore much more liable to this kind of criticism than any other broadcasting organisation. Having said that, to put this debate in context, I say that it is not simply the ABC that is being singled out as some special case. In fact, there is currently raging in Great Britain a very large debate on the bias being alleged against the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC). If we can accuse the BBC of bias, we can accuse our public broadcaster of bias without feeling faint and falling in a heap about it.

I conclude by pointing out to Senator Kernot, as I did today, that the matter of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is not a matter that has suddenly leapt up in the context of the Gulf war. Australia is in the most unusual situation of being at war. So it is hardly surprising that the extent and passion of feeling about bias in our national broadcaster is higher at the moment than it would be under other circumstances. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is conducting its own inquiry into the bias, accuracy and impartiality of current affairs programs in Australia generally. As much as I have my own personal view about bias, I believe that a free press is an absolutely essential part of a democratic society; a democratic society cannot survive without a free press. Because of those very elements, the public debate about perceived bias, not just in the ABC but in any other element of the media, will go on all the time; and so it should. I am perfectly happy to say that if I have any complaints about the ABC I will deal with them by writing to Backchat.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.14 p.m.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act-Revocations (2) of determinations of allowances and further determinations of allowances-

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, and the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Treasurer aware of the release of confidential taxpayer documents by the Commissioner of Taxation (as reported in the media, for example, in the Australian Financial Review of 12 June 1990).

(2) In view of the seriousness of this matter and the potential for there to have been a breach of secrecy provisions, has the Treasurer made enquiries concerning this issue; if so, could a comprehensive report be made to Parliament.
(3) If enquiries have not yet been made, could an undertaking be given to the effect that enquires will be made, followed by a full report to Parliament.
(4) What further action does the Government propose in this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer and the Attorney-General have provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that certain documents were released pursuant to a request under the Freedom of Information Act 1982 (the FOI Act) and that, as a consequence, an article appeared in the Australian Financial Review of 12 June 1990 which drew on information contained in those documents. Prior to the release of the documents they were extensively edited with a view to deleting any material that might possibly have indicated the identity of the taxpayers concerned. I understand that some material which, to someone with close knowledge of the people associated with the taxpayer, might have identified one of the taxpayers involved was accidentally not deleted. This was regrettable and steps have been taken to avoid any repetition.

(2) When the secrecy provisions of the income tax legislation are read in conjunction with the FOI Act it is clear that there is not an absolute embargo on the release of information. In this case the information was released by officers authorised in accordance with the FOI Act and in the belief that they were acting in conformity with their obligations under the FOI Act. I am informed that the advice of the Attorney-General's Department was sought. Amongst other things this advice referred to section 92 of the FOI Act which relevantly provides:
`92. Where access has been given to a document and-
(a) the access was required by this Act to be given . . . ; or

(b) the access was authorised by a Minister, or by an officer having authority, in accordance with section 23 or 54, to make decisions in respect of requests, in the bona fide belief that the access was required by this Act to be given,
neither the person authorising the access nor any person concerned in the giving of the access is guilty of a criminal offence by reason only of the authorising or giving of the access.'
All the evidence brought to my attention indicates that the taxation officers concerned acted in good faith. In the circumstances I do not propose to institute further enquiries.
(3) See 2 above.
(4) See 2 above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) ``Does the booklet issued by the Australian Taxation Office to companies and superannuation funds state that companies and funds should ``endeavour to submit the request in a reasonable time to allow the Tax Office to process the ruling .......... before the due date for assessment.''
(2) ``In order to maintain certainty before the law could the Minister please clarify what is regarded as reasonable time.''

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The statement was contained in the information package on the Companies and Superannuation Fund Self Assessment System.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Contracts

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 10 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's department or any agency for which the Minister is responsible entered into any contracts with Gary Morgan's company, Roy Morgan Research Centre, since 1975; if so, for each contract since 1975:

(b) what was the fee;

(d) was the Centre specifically asked by the Minister's department or agency to supply a copy of the questionnaire;
(e) did the Centre supply a copy of the full questionnaire used to conduct the survey; if so, please provide a copy of the full questionnaire;

(g) were there any questions asked by the Centre which were not included in the report supplied by the Centre; if so, what were they;
(h) please provide a copy of the Centre's report;

(l) did the proposal to commission the survey emanate from within the Minister's department or agency or from within the Minister's office or another department or agency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the constitutionality of the Prime Minister's decision to deploy Australian Defence Forces to the Persian Gulf:

(1) While Section 63 of the Constitution refers to the Governor-General in Council, but Section 68 does not, do the Governor-General's reserve powers include the command of the Defence forces, and should this apolitical power ensure that any decision to deploy the nation's Defence Force is drawn from a consensus of the Parliament, rather than at the behest of one political force.

(2) Although a formal declaration of war has not been made, and following the convention used in the Vietnam War probably will not be made, should the Governor-General have been consulted by the Executive Wing of Government, which is responsible to Parliament, in accordance with Section 68 of the Australian Constitution which provides that the Governor-General is Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces (even though it is only a titular command, and gives the Governor-General no independent command of the Armed Forces).
(3) What recourse of action is open to citizens who feel that their rights have been abrogated by the Prime Minister's action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no requirement under section 68 of the Constitution for Parliamentary consensus in relation to a decision to deploy the Defence Force. Section 68 of the Constitution provides that:
`The command in chief of the naval and military forces of the Commonwealth is vested in the Governor-General as the Queen's representative'.
The current legal position with respect to section 68 is summarized at page 346 of the Final Report of the Constitutional Commission as:
`It is clear beyond doubt that whatever powers the Governor-General may exercise pursuant to this section, these powers are ones that are exercisable only on the advice of the responsible Minister.'

Ministerial responsibility for the Defence Force has been recognised by Parliament in section 8 of the Defence Act 1903 which provides that the Minister for Defence shall have the general control and administration of the Defence Force.
(2) It follows from the answer to Q. 1 that there is no requirement for the Government to consult with the Governor-General before making a decision in respect of the Defence Force.

(3) Accountability to Parliament for the decision to deploy the Defence Force is maintained through Ministerial responsibility to the Parliament. A citizen who feels that his or her rights have been affected by the decision to deploy elements of the Defence Force to the Persian Gulf can take political action through his or her Parliamentary representative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 23 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Administrative Services no longer operate a contract system to undertake the minor maintenance requirements of Commonwealth departments; if not, does it mean that contracts, some of which have been held for as long as 20 years and more, have been cancelled.

(2) Is it a fact that instead of a centralised contract system each department may now employ its own staff to undertake maintenance work; if so, what is the estimated number of extra staff to be employed by each department, and what is the estimated cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian Construction Services, within my department, uses a combination of contract and in-house resources to undertake maintenance work. The proportions are varied as workload fluctuates, to ensure maximum utilisation and efficiency of the existing ACS workforce. Currently, 45% in value of total maintenance work is performed by private contractors.

For minor maintenance, it is more effective for departments to arrange execution of this type of work directly. In 1988 the Government agreed to increase minor maintenance delegation levels to departments, from a limit of $1,500 in value of work to $2,000. In the case of the Department of Defence, the limit is now $6,000.
Since the delegation levels were increased, no contracts have been cancelled. Contracts have reached the end of specified periods and have not been extended in the following circumstances:
- by mutual agreement between the contracting parties;
- where options to extend have not been taken up;
- by request of the client due to changed work requirements;
- as a result of changes in ownership/occupancy of properties;
- as a result of non performance of the contract.

(2) Each department has the authority to arrange or carry out maintenance work within its delegation by whatever means it deems most efficient. I do not have figures of what staff are employed by departments for the purpose of undertaking maintenance work, nor the cost of that employment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 23 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which countries and/or shipping lines have agreed to accept the guidelines introduced in February 1990 for the discharge of ballast water in Australian waters.
(2) What monitoring is done to establish that the guidelines are being observed.
(3) Are reports made to AQIS, the Minister for Resources or elsewhere; if so, by whom and how often.
(4) Since February 1990 how many infringements have been detected.
(5) If there have been any infringements detected, what action has been taken, by whom and with what results.
(6) If none have been detected, does it mean that there have positively been no infringements or that the operation is incapable of appropriate monitoring.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Currently approximately 80% of all vessels entering Australian ports are complying with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service's (AQIS) voluntary guidelines (Controls on the discharge of Ballast Water and Sediment from Ships Entering Australia from Overseas).

The major category of non-complying vessels is the larger bulk carriers entering ports in northern Australia. With the cooperation of the Australian Chamber of Shipping the shipping companies involved are being requested to increase their compliance level. Australia is at the forefront of moves internationally, under the auspices of the International Maritime Organisation, to develop uniform guidelines for ballast water control.

(2) Quarantine staff monitor all ships arriving from overseas for compliance with the guidelines. Ballast water samples are collected and sent to the Australian Government Analytical Laboratory in Melbourne for analysis for the presence of dinoflagellates.
The results of the analysis are provided to AQIS at regular intervals and the response to individual cases is determined according to circumstances.

(3) Regular summary reports on compliance levels and analytical results are provided to senior AQIS staff and members of the working groups established to address economic, scientific and regulatory aspects of the problem.
The Minister for Resources is briefed regularly on significant relevant developments e.g. detection of toxic dinoflagellates.
(4) During the period over which AQIS has been monitoring ballast water samples three confirmed cases of toxic dinoflagellates have been detected.

(5) When infringements are detected quarantine staff are directed to closely monitor the activities of the vessel while it is in port and follow up contact is made with the agent of the vessel to stress the importance of the problem and request compliance with the guidelines.
To date industry representatives and ship agents have been responsive to AQIS' requests.
(6) See (4) above.
